CERTIFICATION
      We, Allen Mavrides, Mayor, and Mia Swartz, Director of Finance, of Munroe
Falls, Ohio, pursuant to Ohio Revised Code 731.23 and 731.42, hereby certify
that the general and permanent ordinances of the City of Munroe Falls, Ohio, as
revised, rearranged, compiled, renumbered as to sections, codified and printed
herewith in component codes are correctly set forth and constitute the Codified
Ordinances of Munroe Falls, Ohio, 1987, as amended to December 31, 2024.
                        /s/ Allen Mavrides
                        Mayor
                        /s/ Mia Swartz
                        Director of Finance

PRELIMINARY UNIT
ADOPTING ORDINANCE
ADOPTING ORDINANCE NO. 16-87
PASSED July 7, 1987
Proposed by General Government Services
   AN ORDINANCE TO APPROVE, ADOPT AND ENACT THE CODIFIED ORDINANCES; TO REPEAL
ORDINANCES IN CONFLICT THEREWITH; TO PUBLISH THE ENACTMENT OF NEW MATTER, AND
DECLARING AN EMERGENCY.
   WHEREAS, the Council of Munroe Falls, Ohio, has had the matter of
codification and general revision of the ordinances before it for some time,
and
   WHEREAS, it has heretofore entered into a contract with the Walter H. Drane
Company to prepare and publish such codification, and
   WHEREAS, the codification of such ordinances, together with the new matter
to be adopted, the matters to be amended and those to be repealed are before
the Council,
BE IT ORDAINED, by the Council of the Municipality of Munroe Falls, Ohio, that:
   Section 1. That the ordinances of the City of Munroe Falls, Ohio, of a
general and permanent nature, as revised, codified, rearranged and consolidated
into component codes, titles, chapters and sections are hereby approved,
adopted and enacted as the Codified Ordinances of Munroe Falls, Ohio 1987.
   One book-form copy of the Codified Ordinances shall be certified as correct
by the Mayor and the Clerk-Treasurer, attached to this Ordinance as a part
hereof, and filed with the permanent ordinance records of the City of Munroe
Falls, Ohio, 1987.
   Section 2. That the provisions of this Ordinance, including all provisions
of the Codified Ordinances, shall be in full force and effect from and
immediately after passage of this Ordinance and its approval by the Mayor. All
ordinances and resolutions or parts thereof enacted prior to January 18, 1987,
which are inconsistent with any provision of the Codified Ordinances, are
hereby repealed as of the effective date of this Ordinance, except as follows:
   (a)   The enactment of the Codified Ordinances shall not be construed to
affect a right or liability accrued or incurred under any legislative provision
prior to the effective date of such enactment, or an action or proceeding for
the enforcement of such right or liability. Such enactment shall not be
construed to relieve any person from punishment for an act committed in
violation of any such legislative provision, nor to affect an indictment or
prosecution therefor. For such purposes, any such legislative provision shall
continue in full force notwithstanding its repeal for the purpose of revision
and modification.
   (b)   The repeal provided above shall not affect:
      (1)   The grant or creation of a franchise, license, right, easement or
privilege;
      (2)   The purchase, sale, lease, or transfer of property;
      (3)   The appropriation or expenditure of money or promise or guarantee
of payment;
      (4)   The assumption of any contract or obligation;
      (5)   The issuance and delivery of any bonds, obligations or other
instruments of indebtedness;
      (6)   The levy or imposition of taxes, assessments or charges;
      (7)   The establishment, naming, vacating or grade level of any street or
public way;
      (8)   The dedication of property or plat approval;
      (9)   The annexation or detachment of territory;
         (10)   Any legislation enacted subsequent to January 18, 1987.
   Section 3. That the Clerk-Treasurer, pursuant to Ohio R.C. 731.23, shall
cause to be published in a manner required by law a summary of the new matter
contained in the Codified Ordinances.
   Section 4. That this Ordinance is hereby declared to be an emergency measure
necessary for the immediate preservation of the public health, safety and
welfare of the residents of Munroe Falls and for the further reason that there
exists an imperative necessity for the earliest publication and distribution of
the Codified Ordinances to the officials and residents of the City, so as to
facilitate administration, daily operation and avoid practical and legal
entanglements, and provided that it receives the affirmative vote of two-thirds
of the members elected to Council, it shall take effect and be in full force
from and immediately upon its passage and approval by the Mayor; otherwise, it
shall take effect and be in full force from and after the earliest period
allowed by law.
Passed      7-7-87
Approved   Gerald L. Hupp
          Mayor

EDITOR'S NOTE
   The arrangement and numbering of the Codified Ordinances into component
codes, titles, chapters and sections are based on an adaptation of the decimal
numbering system which is similar to that used in the Ohio Revised Code, and in
accord with the best accepted practice in instituting a codification. Each
section is self-identifying as to code, chapter and section number. For
example, 305.06 indicates that the code number is 3, the chapter number is 305
(or the 5th chapter within code 3), and the section number is .06. The code and
chapter numbers appear left of the decimal, with the code number preceding the
first two digits left of the decimal, and the chapter number being all digits
left of the decimal. The section number appears right of the decimal. As
another example, 113.10 indicates the code number is 1, the chapter number is
113 (or the 13th chapter within code 1), and the section number is .10.
   This numbering system has the advantage of inherent flexibility in allowing
for an almost endless amount of expansion. Codes, titles and chapters initially
are odd-numbered, thus reserving the use of even numbers for future
legislation. Sections within chapters are consecutively numbered, except that
penalty provisions are usually assigned the number .99 as used in the Revised
Code. Newly created sections subsequent to the original codification may be
indicated by three digits right of the decimal in the event the law properly
belongs between two consecutively numbered sections. For example, newly created
575.061, 575.062 and 575.063 follow 575.06 and precede 575.07 to be placed in
their logical position.
   Section histories enable a user to trace the origin of the law contained in
the section. The history indicates the derivation by reference to either its
passage date and the ordinance number originally assigned to it at that time,
or to its inclusion in any prior code. Sections without histories indicate that
the section contains new matter which was ordained by the Adopting Ordinance
which enacts the Codified Ordinances.
   The Comparative Section Table is included to show the disposition of every
ordinance included in the Codified Ordinances. It indicates whether a given
ordinance was consolidated with another into one section or split into two or
more sections. Cross references direct the user to subject matter reasonably
related to material contained within a given chapter.

TABLES OF SPECIAL ORDINANCES
EDITOR'S NOTE: The Codified Ordinances of Munroe Falls cover all ordinances of
a general and permanent nature. The provisions of such general and permanent
ordinances are set forth in full in the Codified Ordinances.
   References must be made frequently to many special ordinances, particularly
those related to property, such as dedications, vacating of property,
easements, purchase, sale, etc. In the following Tables A through I, all such
ordinances are listed. These tables list ordinances chronologically by subject,
and include both a citation to and brief description of each ordinance.
      
Table A - Franchises
      
Table B - Easements
      
Table C - Vacating Streets and Alleys
      
Table D - Dedication and Plat Approval
      
Table E - Acquisition and Disposal of Real Property
      
Table F - Lease of Real Property
      
Table G - Street Grade Levels and Change of Street Name
      
Table H - Annexation and Detachment of Territory
      
Table I - Zoning Map Changes

OF THE MUNICIPALITY OF
MUNROE FALLS, OHIO
EDITOR'S NOTE: The Charter was originally adopted on November 2, 1976. Dates
appearing in parentheses following a section heading indicate those provisions
were subsequently adopted or amended on the date given.

PREAMBLE
   We the people of Munroe Falls, in the County of Summit and the State of
Ohio, in order to secure for ourselves and to extend to future generations the
benefits of municipal home rule and to exercise all of the powers of local
self-government under the Constitution and the general laws of the State of
Ohio, do hereby adopt this Charter for our Municipality.
ARTICLE I
NAME AND BOUNDARIES
SECTION 1.01. NAME AND BOUNDARIES.
   The Municipality now existing and known as Munroe Falls, in the County of
Summit and the State of Ohio, shall continue to be a body politic and
corporate, under the name of the City of Munroe Falls, or the Village of Munroe
Falls, as the population requires, and with the same boundaries, with powers
and authority to change its boundaries and annex other territory contiguous
thereto in the manner authorized by the general laws of the State of Ohio.
ARTICLE II
POWERS OF THE MUNICIPALITY
SECTION 2.01. POWERS OF THE MUNICIPALITY.
   The Municipality shall have all the powers, general or special, governmental
or proprietary, expressed or implied, which may be possessed or assumed by
municipalities under the Constitution and the general laws of the State of
Ohio. No enumeration of specific powers in this Charter shall be held to be
exclusive.
   All powers of the Municipality shall be exercised in such manner as may be
provided herein, or in the absence of such provision, in such manner consistent
with this Charter as may be prescribed by ordinance, and if not provided for in
this Charter or by ordinance, then in such manner as may be provided by the
general laws of the State of Ohio then applicable.
ARTICLE III
FORM OF GOVERNMENT
SECTION 3.01. FORM OF GOVERNMENT.
   The form of government established by this Charter shall be known as "Mayor-
Council", consisting of the Council and the Mayor elected by the voters of the
Municipality, and possessing respectively the legislative and the executive and
judicial powers specified in this Charter. The Municipality shall have only
such other officers as are provided for in this Charter or in ordinances
enacted hereunder.
ARTICLE IV
MAYOR
SECTION 4.01. QUALIFICATIONS.
   The Mayor shall have been, for at least one year prior to the date of the
Mayoral election a resident, and a qualified elector of this Municipality or
territory annexed thereto, and during that term of office shall continue to be
a resident and qualified elector of this Municipality. The Mayor shall hold no
other elective public office. The Mayor shall not, except as otherwise provided
herein, be otherwise employed by, nor hold any other office in this
Municipality except non-voting ex-officio member of the Planning Commission.
(Amended 11-4-97) (Amended Res. 2021-01, Passed 02-16-21)
SECTION 4.02. ELECTION AND TERM.
   The Mayor shall be elected at the regular Municipal election and every four
(4) years thereafter for a term of four (4) years commencing on January 1st
next following such election and shall hold office until a Successor is elected
or appointed and is qualified.
(Amended 11-6-12) (Amended Res. 2021-01, Passed 02-16-21)
SECTION 4.03. EXECUTIVE POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The Mayor shall:
   (a)   be the chief executive officer of the Municipality. The Mayor shall
supervise the administration of all the affairs of the Municipality, and the
conduct and the administration of all departments and divisions thereof.
   (b)   have the power, subject to the provisions of this Charter and
applicable Civil Service regulations, to appoint, promote, discipline,
transfer, reduce, or remove any officer or employee of the Municipality, except
those required by this Charter to be elected, or those whose terms of office
are fixed by this Charter.
   (c)   be the chief conservator of the peace within the Municipality. The
Mayor shall see that all laws, resolutions and ordinances are enforced therein.
   (d)   execute on behalf of the Municipality all authorized contracts,
conveyances, evidences of indebtedness and all other instruments to which the
Municipality is a party, and shall, where required, attach thereto the official
seal of the Mayor’s office.
   (e)   keep the Council advised of the condition and the needs of the
Municipality, and the Mayor shall recommend to Council such measures as the
Mayor may deem necessary or expedient for the welfare of the Municipality. The
Mayor shall have a voice in the deliberations of Council, but shall have no
vote.
   (f)   prepare and submit to Council an annual budget and such other reports
as the Mayor may deem necessary, or which Council may request.
   (g)   be the official and the ceremonial head of the Municipality.
   (h)   The Mayor in exercising his/her appointing authority to appoint or
dismiss members to the Parks and Recreation Board under Article XI, Section
11.01, Planning Commission, under Article XII, Section
12.01, Board of Zoning Appeals, under Article XIII, Section
13.01, and Charter Review Commission, under Article XVIII, Section
18.01, shall submit the proposed action individually for confirmation by
Council.
(Amended 11-6-12) (Amended Res. 2021-01, Passed 02-16-21)
SECTION 4.04. JUDICIAL POWERS.
   The Mayor shall have all the judicial powers granted from time to time by
the general laws of the State of Ohio to mayors of municipalities of the class
of this Municipality.
SECTION 4.05 VETO POWER.
   Every ordinance or resolution adopted by Council shall be signed by the
President of Council or other presiding officer, attested by the Clerk of
Council and presented promptly to the Mayor within fourteen (14) days.
   The Mayor may approve or disapprove the whole or any part of any resolution
or ordinance appropriating money, but otherwise the Mayor’s approval shall be
addressed to the entire resolution or ordinance.
   If the Mayor approves such legislation, the Mayor shall sign it and file it
with the Clerk of Council. If the Mayor disapproves such legislation, or any
item of such legislation appropriating money, the Mayor shall file it, together
with the Mayor’s objections, in writing, with the Clerk of Council. The Mayor’s
objections shall be entered in full on the journal of Council.
   Unless the resolution or ordinance is filed with the Clerk of Council with
the Mayor's written notice of disapproval within ten (10) days after the
presentation to the Mayor, it shall take effect as though the Mayor had signed
it.
   Upon the Mayor's disapproval, as provided herein, the Council may, but not
later than its next regular meeting, reconsider the legislation, and if, upon
such reconsideration, the legislation is approved by at least five (5) of the
members of Council, it shall take effect notwithstanding the disapproval of the
Mayor.
(Amended 11-6-07) (Amended Res. 2021-01, Passed 02-16-21)
SECTION 4.06. VACANCIES.
   Permanent Vacancy. In the event of the death, resignation or removal of the
Mayor, the President of Council shall become the Mayor to serve for the
unexpired term or until the beginning of the term of the Successor duly elected
and qualified. In the event the President of Council shall decline or become
unable to serve in the Office of Mayor, the Vice President of Council shall
become the Mayor to serve for the unexpired term or until the beginning of the
term of the Successor duly elected and qualified. Such Successor shall be
elected to the Office for the unexpired term at the first regular municipal
election that occurs more than 40 days after the vacancy has occurred except
that when the expired term ends within one year immediately following the date
of such election, an election to fill the unexpired term shall not be held and
the President of Council or Vice President of Council shall serve in the Office
for the balance of the unexpired term.
(Amended 11-4-97; 11-6-12)
SECTION 4.07. TEMPORARY ABSENCE.
   When the Mayor for any reason is unable to perform the duties as Mayor, the
President of Council shall become the Acting Mayor, and while so acting shall
have all powers of the Mayor, to the exclusion of the power to dismiss an
employee of the Municipality, but he shall not thereby cease to be the
President of Council. In the event the President of Council for any reason is
unable to perform the duties as Acting Mayor, the Vice-President of Council
shall become the Acting Mayor, and while so acting shall have all the powers
and duties of the Mayor, to the exclusion of the power to dismiss an employee
of the Municipality, but shall not thereby cease to be the Vice-President of
Council.
(Amended 11-6-07; 11-6-12) (Amended Res. 2021-01, Passed 02-16-21)
ARTICLE V
COUNCIL
SECTION 5.01. QUALIFICATIONS.
   Each member of Council shall have been, for at least one year prior to the
date of their election and/or appointment a resident, and a qualified elector
of this Municipality or territory annexed thereto and during that term of
office shall continue to be a resident and a qualified elector of this
Municipality. A member of Council shall not be otherwise employed by this
Municipality and shall hold no other office, except as otherwise provided by
this Charter or by ordinance enacted hereunder. Any member of Council who
violates any of the qualifications herein enumerated shall be removed from
their office, but failure to maintain said qualifications shall not render void
or ineffective any action of Council in which said member participated.
(Amended 11-4-97; 11-6-07) (Amended Res. 2021-01, Passed 02-16-21)
SECTION 5.02. COMPOSITION AND TERM.
   Upon the effective date of this Charter Amendment, the Council shall consist
of seven (7) members, three (3) members to be elected from designated Wards
(one per Ward) and four (4) members elected at-large, each for four (4) year
terms except as herein provided. In the next Municipal election, November 2011,
three (3) seats on Council will be up for re-election. One (1) of those seats
will be assigned to Ward II. The second and third seats shall be the at-large
seats described herein above. In November 2013, four (4) Council seats will be
up for re-election. One (1) of those seats will be assigned to Ward I and one
(1) of those seats will be assigned to Ward III. The third and fourth seats
shall be the at-large seats described herein above. A qualified elector seeking
election to a seat on Council assigned to a designated Ward must be a resident
of that Ward on the date of the election and throughout his/her term of office.
In the event that there is no candidate for a designated Ward, the vacancy in
the Ward may be filled by a qualified elector residing in another Ward of the
Municipality as long as there are no qualified elector residents within that
Ward expressing a desire to serve on Council. Thereafter, at each regular
Municipal election, members of Council shall be elected to fill the terms
expiring on the next calendar year.
(Amended 11-6-07; 11-2-10)
SECTION 5.03. RESERVED.
(Amended 11-6-07)
SECTION 5.04. PRESIDENT AND VICE-PRESIDENT OF COUNCIL.
   The Council shall at each Organizational Meeting, by majority vote, elect
from its Members a President of Council who shall preside at meetings of
Council and a Vice President of Council who shall preside at meetings of
Council in the absence of the President of Council. The President and Vice
President of Council, neither by virtue of holding such offices nor in
performing the duties of Acting Mayor, as provided in Section 4.07 of this
Charter, shall be deprived of their powers and rights or be relieved of any of
their duties and obligations as Members of Council except during such period as
the President or Vice President of Council shall be the Acting Mayor and shall
cast votes on legislation only when necessary to break a tie vote. Otherwise,
while serving in the capacity as Acting Mayor, the President or Vice President
of Council shall not otherwise vote on legislation.
(Amended 11-6-12) (Amended Res. 2021-01, Passed 02-16-21)
SECTION 5.05. VACANCY; PRESIDENT OF COUNCIL.
   A vacancy in the office of President of Council shall be filled by the Vice-
President of Council becoming the President of Council, and the office of Vice-
President of Council shall be filled by a member of Council elected by a
majority vote of Council.
   In the event that the President or the Vice-President of Council shall fill
a vacancy in the office of Mayor, a vacancy shall thereby be created in
Council, which shall be filled before the vacancy in the office of Vice-
President of Council is filled.
SECTION 5.06. INVESTMENT AND RESERVATION OF LEGISLATIVE POWER.
   The legislative power of the Municipality shall be vested in Council, but
the people reserve to themselves the power to propose to Council ordinances,
resolutions and amendments to this Charter, and to adopt or to reject the same
at the polls.
SECTION 5.07. LIMITATION OF LEGISLATIVE POWER.
   The limitations contained or implied in this Charter and in the general laws
of the State of Ohio and in the Constitution of the State of Ohio on the powers
of Council to enact legislation shall also limit the powers of the people to
enact legislation. The Council shall not abdicate or transfer to others any of
the powers with which it is vested.
SECTION 5.08. SESSIONS.
   On January 2nd of each year, Council shall convene and organize at the
Council Chambers of the Municipality, or convene and organize virtually as may
be authorized pursuant to Section
5.16 of the Charter. The Mayor or a member of Council appointed by the Mayor
shall preside as temporary chairman only until the President of Council is
elected. If January 2nd falls on a Saturday, Sunday, or holiday the
organizational meeting shall be held on the next regular business day.
   Thereafter, Council shall meet at such times as may be prescribed by
resolution or ordinance, except that it shall hold regular meetings at least
once each calendar month. All regular meetings of Council shall be held at the
Council Chambers, or virtually as may be authorized pursuant to Section
5.16 of the Charter, and shall be open to the public in accordance with
ordinance.
(Amended 11-6-07; 11-8-22)
SECTION 5.09. SPECIAL MEETINGS.
   Special meetings of Council shall be called by a vote of Council taken at
any regular meeting or special meeting thereof, or shall be called by the Clerk
of Council upon the written request of the Mayor, or of the President of
Council, or of any three (3) of the members of Council.
   Notice, in writing, of each such special meeting called at the request of
the Mayor, or of the President of Council, or of any three (3) members of
Council, shall state the date and the time, and the subject or subjects to be
considered thereat. The Clerk of Council shall cause such written notice to be
served to all officials holding elective office, either personally or by
leaving a copy thereof at their usual place of residence, not less than twenty-
four (24) hours preceding the time for the meeting. In the event that a special
meeting is called by a vote of Council at any regular or special meeting from
which any member of Council is absent, written notice of such special meeting
shall be given such absentee in the manner and the form hereinbefore provided.
Service of such notice may be waived by an instrument in writing signed prior
to the hour of such meeting, and the Mayor and any Councilman shall be deemed
conclusively to have waived such notice by their attendance at any such
meeting. All special meetings of Council shall be held at the Council Chambers
and shall be open to the public.
   Special meetings may be held virtually as authorized by Section
5.16 of the Charter.
(Amended Res. 2021-01, Passed 02-16-21) (Amended 11-8-22)
SECTION 5.10. OPERATING RULES OF COUNCIL.
   Council may, by resolution, adopt operating rules not in conflict with this
Charter and deemed necessary to the reasonable conduct of its duties.
Otherwise, the Council shall conduct its meetings in accordance with the most
current edition of Robert's Rules of Parliamentary Procedure.
SECTION 5.11. ESTABLISHMENT OF A QUORUM; DETERMINATION OF RESULTS OF VOTES OF
COUNCIL.
   A quorum shall exist when a majority of the prescribed membership of Council
is present at any regular or special meeting of Council. When a quorum does not
exist, a majority of those members who are present may compel the attendance of
unexcused absent members in such manner and under such penalty as may be
prescribed by resolution.
   To determine the results of any vote of Council it shall be calculated on
the full prescribed membership of Council as stated in this Charter.
SECTION 5.12. CLERK OF COUNCIL.
   A.   The Director of Finance of the Municipality shall be the Clerk of
Council until such time as Council shall provide ordinance for the separation
of the two positions. At that time the Clerk of Council shall be appointed by,
and may be removed by, the affirmative vote of a majority of the members of
Council.
   B.   The Clerk of Council or a designated employee shall attend all meetings
of Council and shall keep a record of its proceedings in a journal as
prescribed in Section
20.07 of this Charter.
(Amended 11-4-97)
SECTION 5.13. EMPLOYEES OF COUNCIL.
   Council may employ such employees as it may deem necessary for the proper
discharge of its legislative duties. Any person employed by Council shall serve
at the pleasure of Council.
SECTION 5.14. DEPARTMENTS, BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS.
   Council may establish, abolish, combine or expand departments, boards and
commissions as the needs of the Municipality may require, except for those
established by this Charter.
SECTION 5.15. VACANCY.
   A vacancy in the Council shall be filled by a majority of all of the
remaining members of Council. The Mayor shall fill a vacancy in Council by
appointment only if Council has failed to do so within thirty (30) days from
the date the vacancy occurred. The person elected or appointed to fill the
vacancy shall have the proper qualifications for the particular office, as set
forth in this Charter. The person elected by Council or appointed by the Mayor
shall hold the office until a successor is elected and qualified.
   A successor shall be elected and qualified by the electorate at the next
regular Municipal election. However, if the vacancy occurs within thirty (30)
days of, or after the filing deadline for the next Municipal election, in this
event, the successor shall hold office for the balance of the unexpired term of
the member in whose office the vacancy has occurred.
(Amended 11-7-00)
SECTION 5.16.   VIRTUAL MEETINGS OF COUNCIL AND OTHER PUBLIC BODIES.
   Council, as well as any other public body of the Municipality, may elect to
meet virtually in lieu of an in-person meeting, but only in the event that the
public body first determines, by the assent of at least two-thirds of its
members, that meeting virtually is necessary due to either a public health
emergency or due to an emergency caused by inclement weather. Such meetings
shall continue to be open to the public in accordance with ordinance.
(Amended 11-8-22)
ARTICLE VI
LEGISLATIVE PROCEDURE
SECTION 6.01. FORM OF LEGISLATION.
   All Council legislation shall be by ordinance or by resolution which shall
have been considered and introduced by a Committee of Council in written or
printed form. Legislation shall contain no more than one subject which shall be
clearly expressed in its title. Legislation shall have prior review by the
Director of Law for form and content for conformity with the provisions of this
Charter and of the Constitution and of the general laws of the State of Ohio.
Such legislation shall have endorsed upon it the approval of the Director of
Law, however, Council may proceed with consideration of legislation without
such endorsement upon the affirmative vote of five (5) of the members of
Council.
SECTION 6.02. REQUIREMENT OF THREE READINGS.
   All ordinances and resolutions shall be read at three (3) different meetings
of Council, of which at least two (2) must be regular meetings. All readings
shall be by title only, unless otherwise voted by a majority of the members of
Council. Council may vote to suspend the rule requiring three (3) separate
readings which shall require the affirmative vote of at least six (6) of the
members of Council.
SECTION 6.03. EXCLUSIONS FROM SUSPENSION OF THREE READINGS.
   The following subjects may not be considered under the suspension of the
requirement of three (3) separate readings rule:
   (a)   any change of the boundaries of the Municipality
   (b)   any granting of a franchise
   (c)   any resolution declaring the necessity of an improvement or service to
be paid for in whole or in part from special assessments
   (d)   any enactment, amendment, or repeal of any zoning or building
ordinance or resolution
   (e)   any establishment or change of financial compensation for any official
holding elective office.
SECTION 6.04. ADOPTION OF LEGISLATION BY COUNCIL.
   An affirmative vote of a majority of the members of Council shall be
required for the adoption of any ordinance or resolution. The vote shall be
taken by roll call. These votes shall be on a rotational basis, by names, as
determined by the Clerk of Council.
SECTION 6.05. ADOPTION OF EMERGENCY LEGISLATION.
   Each ordinance or resolution considered to be an emergency shall contain a
statement of the necessity for such emergency action. The enactment of
emergency legislation shall require the affirmative vote of at least five (5)
of the members of Council.
SECTION 6.06. SUBJECTS EXCLUDED FROM DECLARATION OF EMERGENCY.
   No action of Council authorizing the following subjects shall be enacted as
an emergency measure:
   (a)   any change of the boundaries of the Municipality
   (b)    any granting of a franchise
   (c)   any resolution declaring the necessity of an improvement or service to
be paid for in whole or in part from special assessments
   (d)   any enactment, amendment, or repeal of any zoning or building
ordinance or resolution
   (e)   any establishment or change of financial compensation for any official
holding elective office.
SECTION 6.07. EFFECTIVE DATE OF LEGISLATION.
   All resolutions and ordinances providing for the appropriation of money, or
for improvements petitioned for by the owners of a majority of front footage of
property to be benefited and specially assessed for, and any emergency
resolution or ordinance, as defined in this Charter, shall take effect
immediately unless a later date be specified therein, upon its approval by the
Mayor, or upon the expiration of the time within which it may be vetoed by the
Mayor, as the case may be.
   No other resolution or ordinance shall become effective until thirty (30)
days after it is adopted.
SECTION 6.08. PUBLIC NOTICE.
   All ordinances and resolutions shall be given public notice prior to the
first reading, during deliberation, and after enactment. Any proposed ordinance
or resolution shall be conspicuously posted in at least two (2) convenient
public places in the Municipality prior to the first reading. It must remain
posted during the first reading and during subsequent readings.
   Further public notice is required once a resolution or ordinance is adopted
and approved by the Mayor, or upon the expiration of the time within which it
may be vetoed by the Mayor, or upon its passage after the veto of the Mayor.
This shall be the final and corrected version of the original presentation.
   Such notice shall be posted in at least five (5) public places in the
Municipality as selected by ordinance of Council and shall remain in place at
least ten (10) days after the effective date of the ordinance or resolution.
   Notices to bidders for the construction of public improvements or for
contracts, in the form required by the general laws of the State of Ohio, shall
be published in one (1), but not more than two (2) newspapers of general
circulation within the Municipality once each week for not less than two (2),
nor more than four (4), consecutive weeks before the opening of bids.
SECTION 6.09. POWER TO FIX COMPENSATION.
   Council shall fix the compensation of the Mayor, of the members of Council,
of each officer or employee, and members of any board or commission of the
Municipality whether elected or appointed as provided in this Charter.
SECTION 6.10. DATE BY WHICH COMPENSATION MUST BE FIXED.
   Council shall fix the compensation of the Mayor and of the members of
Council, not later than (70) days prior to the date of the next election in
which the elections of these officials occur. No elected official shall have
their compensation reduced without their consent. No elected official, other
than a council member, shall benefit from a change in compensation during the
official's term of office. This exception is made for council members' terms as
said terms are staggered and unequal treatment for council members would result
without this exception. All council members shall receive the same
compensation. However, the Council President may receive additional
compensation for the duties required of the Council President.
   Council shall set the compensation of other employees or appointed officers
and members of any board or commission of the Municipality as may be provided
by ordinance. (Amended 6-19-84)
(Amended Res. 2021-01, Passed 02-16-21)
SECTION 6.11. HOW COMPENSATION SHALL BE FIXED.
   Council shall fix the compensation of elective officers by ordinance or
resolution and such ordinances or resolutions shall be read at three (3)
Council meetings, of which one (1) may be a special meeting. Such ordinances or
resolutions shall not be subject to the suspension of this rule.
SECTION 6.12. REQUIREMENT OF BOND.
   The Mayor, the fiscal officer and any other official or employee of the
Municipality specified by Council by ordinance shall give bond in such amount
and with such surety as may be approved by Council. The premium on such bonds
shall be paid by the Municipality.
SECTION 6.13. REMOVAL OF ELECTED OFFICIALS.
   The office of an elective officer of the Municipality shall be declared
vacant by resolution of Council upon the determination that the elected
official:
   (a)   does not possess, or has ceased to possess, the qualifications of
office, or
   (b)   has failed to take the required oath or to give any bond required of
said official within twenty (20) days after the effective date of their
appointment or election, or notification to give a new or additional bond, or
   (c)   while in office, has been convicted of a felony or crime involving
moral turpitude, or
   (d)   has been adjudicated mentally incompetent, or
   (e)   is guilty of personal interest, gross misconduct, gross neglect of
duty, misfeasance, malfeasance, or nonfeasance in office, or
   (f)   has violated their oath of office.
   In addition to the grounds for removal provided above, Council may remove
any of its members for persistent failure to abide by the rules of Council, or
for absence without justifiable excuse from three (3) consecutive Council
meetings.
   The decision of Council to remove an elective officer shall be made only
upon concurrence of five (5) of the members of Council after public hearing
upon the charge or charges brought; and provided further, that the accused
elective officer shall have been notified, in writing, of the charge or charges
against them at least fifteen (15) days in advance of such public hearing; and
provided further, that the elective officer or their counsel shall have been
given an opportunity to be heard, to present evidence, and to examine witnesses
appearing in support of such charges.
   The decision of Council after compliance with this section shall be final.
   The elective officer so removed shall not be eligible for appointment to the
vacancy created thereby.
(Amended Res. 2021-01, Passed 02-16-21)
ARTICLE VII
DIRECTOR OF FINANCE
SECTION 7.01. QUALIFICATIONS.
   The Director of Finance of the Municipality shall have knowledge and
experience in accounting, taxation, budgets, and financial control.
(Amended 11-4-97)
SECTION 7.02. APPOINTMENT AND REMOVAL.
   The Director of Finance of the Municipality shall be appointed and may be
removed by the Mayor subject to confirmation by Council.
(Amended 11-4-97)
SECTION 7.03. DUTIES.
   The Director of Finance shall be the fiscal officer of the Municipality and
shall:
   (a)   Keep the financial records of the Municipality, exhibiting accurate
statements of all taxes and assessments, receipts and disbursements, moneys due
to and moneys owing to and all property owned by the Municipality;
   (b)   Advise the Mayor and Council concerning the financial condition of the
Municipality and examine all payrolls, bills, and other claims against the
Municipality and issue no warrants unless the Director of Finance finds that
the claim is in proper form, and that an appropriation has been made, and funds
are available;
   (c)   Be the custodian of all public moneys of the Municipality and keep and
preserve such moneys in the place or places authorized by ordinance and
disburse the same as may be required by law or ordinance;
   (d)   Examine and audit the accounts of all other officers, employees and
departments and not allow the amount set aside for an appropriation to be
overdrawn or to be drawn for any other purpose and require evidence that the
amount of any claim presented to them is due;
   (e)   Be responsible for the preparation and the submission of appropriation
measures and assist the Mayor and the Council in the preparation of estimates,
budgets and other financial matters and at all times keep the Mayor and Council
fully advised as to the financial condition and needs of the Municipality;
   (f)   Keep and have custody of the records, ordinances, resolutions, rules,
regulations and bylaws adopted by Council and of its proceedings, and of all
boards, commissions and other bodies of the inspection;
   (g)   Perform the duties now and hereafter imposed on auditors, treasurers
and clerk- treasurers of municipalities under the general laws of the state of
Ohio and perform such other duties, consistent with their office, as may be
required by this Charter, by ordinance or resolution, or as directed by the
Mayor.
(Amended 11-4-97) (Amended Res. 2021-01, Passed 02-16-21)
SECTION 7.04 CONTRACTS AND COMPETITIVE BIDDING.
   (a)   Contracts involving expenditures by the Municipality in excess of a
dollar amount as may be specified from time to time by ordinance shall be
awarded to the lowest and most responsive bidder after approval by Council and
competitive bidding unless Council determines that competitive bidding is not
required. Council shall not be required to accept any bid.
   (b)   Council, by a vote of five (5) or more members, may authorize
expenditures exceeding the financial limitations established in paragraph (a)
above without public bidding when it is either impractical to award the
contract under competitive bidding procedures or it is cost effective and in
the best interests of the City to award the contract without public bidding.
Contracts that may be awarded without public bidding include, but are not
limited to: acquisition, sale, lease or other disposal of real estate;
discharge of non-contractual claims against the Municipality; personal and
professional contracts for services; contracts with a construction manager to
oversee a public project; contracts for the products or services of public
utilities; contracts for the joint use of facilities of other Municipalities;
and in the event of an emergency or catastrophe to protect the public health,
safety, welfare or property.
(Enacted November 5, 2002.)
ARTICLE VIII
DIRECTOR OF LAW
SECTION 8.01. QUALIFICATIONS.
   No person shall be the Director of Law unless they are duly admitted to
practice law in the State of Ohio.
(Amended Res. 2021-01, Passed 02-16-21)
SECTION 8.02. APPOINTMENT AND REMOVAL.
   The Director of Law or other attorneys of the Municipality shall be
appointed by and may be removed by the Mayor subject to confirmation by
Council.
(Ord. 29-97. Passed 7-15-97.) (Amended Res. 2021-01, Passed 02-16-21)
SECTION 8.03. DUTIES.
   The Director of Law shall:
   (a)   serve the Mayor, the Council, the administrative departments and the
officers, boards and commissions of the Municipality as legal counsel in
connection with Municipal affairs;
   (b)   represent the Municipality in all proceedings in any court or before
any administrative board;
   (c)   perform such other duties, consistent with their office as may be
required by this Charter, by ordinance or by resolution of Council, or as
directed by the Mayor.
(Amended Res. 2021-01, Passed 02-16-21)
SECTION 8.04. CHARTER CHANGE.
   The Law Director shall be authorized to make typographical corrections to or
changes or deletions in, as well as changes in the form of, the Charter;
however, the changes shall relate to matters of form only. Any such
modification, change, or correction shall, in all cases, be approved by
resolution of Council, prior to going into effect. In no event shall any such
modification, change, or correction affect the construction, meaning,
substance, or intent of the Charter as adopted and amended by the people.
   The Law Director may correct obvious misspellings and typographical errors.
   The Law Director may divide the text of any section or paragraph into
shorter paragraphs or subparagraphs and letter or number the same to improve
clarity and ease of reference.
   The Law Director may renumber the sections and rearrange their order to
provide:
   (a)   More coherent grouping of sections related in subject matter; and
   (b)   Continuous, consecutive numbering of sections.
   Upon the adoption of any amendment that creates or abolishes an office or
offices or changes the powers or duties of any officer or agency of the City,
the Law Director shall make necessary correlative changes in existing sections
that refer to such offices, officers, or agencies by deleting therefrom, as the
case may be, the name of the office abolished or title of the officer or agency
no longer having such powers or duties and inserting therein, as the case may
be, the name of the office created or the title of the officer or agency then
having such powers or duties.
(Added 11-7-17 by Charter Change Approved by the Voters)
(Amended Res. 2021-01, Passed 02-16-21)
ARTICLE IX
DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC SAFETY
SECTION 9.01. APPOINTMENT AND REMOVAL.
   The Mayor shall perform the duties of the Director of Public Safety until
such time as Council provides by ordinance for the separation of the two
positions. Thereafter, the Director of Public Safety shall be appointed and may
be removed by the Mayor subject to confirmation by Council.
SECTION 9.02. DUTIES.
   The Director of Public Safety shall be the head of the Department of Public
Safety, including the Division of Police and the Division of Fire, and shall be
responsible for the enforcement of all police, fire, health, safety and
sanitary regulations that may be prescribed by resolution or by ordinance of
the Municipality or the general laws of the State of Ohio.
SECTION 9.03. DIVISION OF POLICE.
   (a)   The Division of Police shall consist of a Chief of Police and such
other officers, and personnel as provided for by Council. The Chief of Police
shall be appointed and may be removed by the Director of Public Safety, subject
to confirmation by Council. Other officers, and personnel shall be appointed
and may be removed by the Director of Public Safety and subject to applicable
civil service provisions of this Charter.
   (b)   The Chief of Police shall be a certified police officer and have had
prior supervisory police experience.
(Amended November 3, 1992) (Amended Res. 2021-01, Passed 02-16-21)
SECTION 9.04. DIVISION OF FIRE.
   (a)   The Division of Fire shall consist of a Fire Chief and such other
officers, firefighters and personnel as provided for by Council. The Fire Chief
shall be appointed and may be removed by the Director of Public Safety subject
to confirmation by Council. Other officers, firefighters and personnel shall be
appointed and may be removed by the Director of Public Safety and subject to
applicable civil service provisions of this Charter.
   (b)   The Fire Chief shall be certified by the State Board of Emergency
Medical, Fire, and Transportation Services in accordance with Section 4765.55
of the Ohio Revised Code to the State of Ohio's minimum requirements for the
levels of Firefighter II as set forth in the Standards for Fire Fighter
Professional Qualifications, for the level of Fire Safety Inspector as set
forth in the Standard for Professional Qualifications for Fire Inspector and
Plan Examiner, for the level of Fire Service Instructor, and in accordance with
Section 4765.30 of the Ohio Revised Code to the State of Ohio's minimum
requirements for the level of Paramedic, and for the level of EMS Instructor,
and have the ability to supervise subordinates and fire department functions.
(Amended November 3, 1992; November 8, 2022) (Amended Res. 2021-01, Passed 02-
16-21)
ARTICLE X
DEPARTMENT OF ROADS AND UTILITIES
SECTION 10.01. QUALIFICATIONS.
   The Director of Public Services shall be selected on the basis of their
executive and administrative qualifications with special reference to their
experience in, and knowledge of, accepted practices in respect to the duties of
their office as hereinafter set forth, but the Director of Public Services
shall not be required to be an engineer.
(Amended Res. 2021-01, Passed 02-16-21)
SECTION 10.02. APPOINTMENT AND REMOVAL.
   The Director of Public Services shall be the head of the Department of Roads
and Utilities, and shall be appointed and may be removed by the Mayor subject
to confirmation by Council.
SECTION 10.03. DUTIES.
   The Director of Public Services shall have the responsibility for
construction, improvement and maintenance of all public works, buildings,
grounds, roads, streets, and all other places owned by the Municipality. They
shall have charge of and shall supervise the maintenance of all municipal
property and equipment and the storage of all material and supplies. The
Director of Public Services may employ such assistants and employees, subject
to appropriations by Council, as may from time to time be necessary for the
proper discharge of their duties.
   The City Engineer shall be State certified and shall be responsible for the
issuance of all building and zoning certificates, supervise the administration
and the enforcement of the Building and Zoning ordinances and perform such
other duties as may be requested by ordinance or resolution of Council or as
directed by the Mayor.
   If the position of Engineer has not been created, and/or if vacant, the
Director of Public Services shall be responsible for the issuance of all
building and zoning certificates, supervise the administration and the
enforcement of the Building and Zoning ordinances, and perform such other
duties as may be required by this Charter, by ordinance or resolution of
Council or as directed by the Mayor.
(Amended November 5, 2002.) (Amended Res. 2021-01, Passed 02-16-21)
ARTICLE XI
PARKS AND RECREATION BOARD
SECTION 11.01. ORGANIZATION.
   The Park and Recreation Board shall consist of seven (7) electors of the
Municipality not holding other Municipal office in the Municipality. The seven
(7) electors shall be appointed and may be removed by the mayor subject to
confirmation of Council.
   Of the four (4) electors to be appointed for the term beginning January 1,
2023, the Mayor, as the appointing authority, shall appoint four (4) members
for a three year term. Of the three (3) electors to be appointed for the term
beginning January 1, 2024, the Mayor, as the appointing authority, shall
appoint three (3) members for a three-year term. Thereafter, all terms will be
three-year terms. A vacancy occurring during the term of any member shall be
filled for the unexpired term by an appointment by the Mayor, subject to
Council's confirmation. If the Mayor fails to fill a vacancy, within thirty
days of the vacancy, council shall fill the vacancy. Council shall, within
thirty days of the Mayor's appointment, confirm or deny confirmation of that
appointment. Council shall appoint one of its members to serve as a
Representative on the Parks and Recreation Board effective January 1, 2023.
Said appointee will be a non-voting member of the Board.
(Amended 6-2-81; 11-6-07; 11-6-12; 11-8-22)
SECTION 11.02. OPERATING PROCEDURES.
   The Board shall elect from its members a Chairman, a Vice-Chairman, a
Secretary, and such other officers as it may deem necessary.
   The Board shall elect or re-elect its officers at a regular meeting in
January of each year. A majority of the members of the Board shall constitute a
quorum and the affirmative vote of a majority of the members of the Board shall
be necessary for any official action.
   The Board shall adopt its own rules and regulations and shall keep a
complete journal of its proceedings.
   The Board shall meet at least once a month.
SECTION 11.03. POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The Parks and Recreation Board shall:
   (a)   promulgate rules, regulations, and policies regarding the use of parks
and recreation areas;
   (b)    make such recommendations and reports to the Mayor, Council, Planning
Commission, and other officers, departments, divisions, and boards and
commissions as it deems advisable regarding the acquisition, development,
maintenance, repair, and operation of parks, playgrounds, recreational
facilities and programs of the Municipality. The Board may cooperate with
organized groups concerned with recreation programs and may stimulate citizen
interest in the care and preservation of parks and historical and scenic sites;
   (c)    consult with the Planning Commission on all matters of mutual
interest;
   (d)    have such other powers and duties relating to the use and maintenance
of parks and recreation areas as may be conferred upon it by Council;
   (e)    recommend the amount of any fees or charges for the use of park and
recreational facilities; however, Council shall set all such fees or charges.
The Board may also make recommendations regarding the planting and care of
trees, plants, and shrubs in the parks, recreational grounds, and scenic sites
within the Municipality;
   (f)    make recommendations to the Mayor and City Council regarding
anticipated budgetary needs for fulfillment of the intent and purpose of the
Board's powers and duties.
(Amended 11-6-07) (Amended Res. 2021-01, Passed 02-16-21)
ARTICLE XII
PLANNING AND ZONING COMMISSION
SECTION 12.01. ORGANIZATION.
   The Planning Commission shall consist of one (1) member of Council elected
by Council annually at its organizational meeting and of four (4) electors of
the Municipality not holding other Municipal office in the Municipality. The
four (4) electors shall be appointed and may be removed by the Mayor subject to
confirmation by Council. The Mayor shall have the right to remove a Member of
the Planning Commission with or without cause. The Mayor shall be an ex-
officio member of the Commission, but shall have no vote.
   Of the four (4) electors to be appointed, all such appointments shall be for
a four (4) year term.
    A vacancy occurring during the term of any member shall be filled for the
unexpired term in the manner authorized for an original appointment.
   Council, at its organizational meeting, may elect a second member of Council
to serve and vote at a Planning Commission meeting when the primary elected
Councilmember is unable to attend a meeting.
   The Commission shall meet at least once each month.
(Amended 11-8-05; 11-6-12) (Amended Res. 2021-01, Passed 02-16-21)
SECTION 12.02. OPERATING PROCEDURES.
   The Commission shall elect from its members a Chairman, a Vice-Chairman, a
Secretary, and such other officers as it may deem necessary.
   The Commission shall elect or re-elect its officers at its first regular
meeting in January of each year. A majority of the voting members of the
Commission shall constitute a quorum and the affirmative vote of a majority of
the voting members of the Commission shall be necessary for any official
action.
   The Commission shall adopt its own rules and regulations and shall keep a
complete journal of its proceedings.
   In addition to the assistance provided by the staff personnel of the
administrative departments, the Commission may, when it is deemed necessary,
solicit Council for the appointment of an administrative assistant to assist in
the clerical duties associated with the needs of the Commission.
   Authority of the Planning Commission shall be in accordance with standards
established by ordinance or the general laws of the State of Ohio.
(Amended Res. 2021-01, Passed 02-16-21)
SECTION 12.03. POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The Planning Commission shall:
   (a)   plan the overall growth, development, redevelopment, rehabilitation
and renewal of the Municipality, inaugurate studies, conduct surveys, hold
public hearings, develop plans and maps, and prepare reports that are necessary
to this Commission's function;
   (b)   continuously review and report to Council its recommendations
concerning the Municipality, subdivision expansions, and planning and zoning
ordinances;
   (c)   act as platting commissioners for the Municipality;
   (d)   administer all planning and zoning ordinances, develop means to
enhance communications between the Commission and other governmental or private
planning agencies so as to secure the maximum benefit to the Municipality from
the activities of such agencies;
   (e)   assume such additional powers as may be established by Council and
undertake such powers and duties as provided by the general laws of the State
of Ohio to the extent not in conflict with the provisions of this Charter;
   (f)   request information relative to its duties and require the same to be
furnished, in a reasonable length of time, from departments of the
Municipality;
   (g)   request assistance from the Mayor to direct such staff members and
departments that may be involved to make such special studies as may be deemed
necessary by the Commission;
   (h)   make examinations and surveys which may pertain to and are deemed
necessary by the Commission to develop plans that are in the best interests of
the Municipality.
(Amended Res. 2021-01, Passed 02-16-21)
SECTION 12.04. MANDATORY REFERRAL.
   No public building, street, boulevard, parkway, park, playground, bridge,
tunnel, publicly or privately owned utility or part thereof shall be
constructed or authorized to be constructed in the Municipality, nor shall any
street, avenue, parkway, boulevard or alley be widened, narrowed, relocated,
vacated, or its use changed, or any ordinance referring to zoning or other
regulations controlling the use or the development of land be passed unless and
until the action proposed to be adopted shall have been submitted to the
Planning Commission for report and recommendation and such report or
recommendation has been completed by the Commission. Such report or
recommendation shall require the affirmative vote of a majority of the members
of Council for adoption or authorization.
(Amended Res. 2021-01, Passed 02-16-21)
SECTION 12.05. FUNDS.
   A sufficient sum shall be appropriated by Council each year to carry out the
planning and zoning provisions of this Charter.
ARTICLE XIII
BOARD OF ZONING APPEALS
SECTION 13.01. ORGANIZATION.
   The Board of Zoning Appeals shall consist of five (5) electors of the
Municipality not holding other Municipal office in the Municipality. The five
(5) electors shall be appointed and may be removed by the Mayor subject to
confirmation of Council.
   Of the five (5) electors to be appointed to the terms beginning January 2,
1977, one (1) shall be appointed to a term of one (1) year, one (1) to a term
of two (2) years, one (1) to a term of three (3) years, one (1) to a term of
four (4) years, and one (1) to a term of five (5) years. Thereafter, each
regular appointment shall be for a term of five (5) years. A vacancy occurring
during the term of any member shall be filled for the unexpired term by an
appointment by the Mayor, subject to Council's confirmation. If the Mayor fails
to fill a vacancy, within thirty days of that vacancy, Council shall fill the
vacancy. Council, shall, within thirty days of the Mayor's appointment, confirm
or deny confirmation of that appointment.
(Amended 6-2-81) (Amended Res. 2021-01, Passed 02-16-21)
SECTION 13.02. OPERATING PROCEDURE.
   (a)   The Board shall elect from its members a Chairman, a Vice-Chairman, a
Secretary and such other officers as it may deem necessary.
   (b)   The Board shall elect or re-elect its officers at its first regular
meeting in January of each year and thereafter meet at least once each month if
an appeal is pending before them.
   (c)   The Board shall elect or re-elect its officers at its first regular
meeting in January of each year. A majority of the members of the Board shall
constitute a quorum and the affirmative vote of a majority of the members of
the Board shall be necessary for any official action.
   (d)   The Board shall adopt its own rules and regulations and shall keep a
complete journal of its proceedings.
   (e)   In addition to the assistance provided by the staff personnel of the
administrative departments, the Board may, when it is deemed necessary, solicit
Council for the appointment of an administrative assistant to assist in the
clerical duties associated with the needs of this Board.
   (f)   Procedure before the Board of Zoning Appeals shall be in accordance
with standards established by the Zoning Ordinance.
(Amended November 3, 1992) (Amended Res. 2021-01, Passed 02-16-21)
SECTION 13.03. JURISDICTION.
   The Board of Zoning Appeals shall have the power to hear and to decide
appeals for exceptions to and variances in the application of resolutions,
ordinances, regulations, measures and orders of administrative officials or
agencies governing zoning and building in the Municipality, as may be required
to afford justice and to avoid unreasonable hardship.
(Amended Res. 2021-01, Passed 02-16-21)
ARTICLE XIV
CIVIL SERVICE COMMISSION
SECTION 14.01. CIVIL SERVICE COMMISSION.
   The Civil Service Commission is hereby created by virtue of this Charter.
Except as otherwise provided in this Charter, determination of whether
positions are classified or unclassified, the appointments, promotions,
discipline, demotions, removal, and other undertakings regarding classified
personnel together with all other rights and remedies associated with or
related to those positions shall be determined and governed by the rules and
regulations of the Civil Service Commission as previously promulgated by the
Civil Service Commission and adopted by City Council. The Civil Service
Commission may, from time to time, amend its rules and regulations with the
approval and adoption by the City Council. Any such approved rule may supersede
a general State Civil Service Statute.
(Amended 11-4-97)
ARTICLE XV
TAXATION AND FINANCE
SECTION 15.01. LIMITATION ON RATE OF TAXATION.
   The Council's power to levy taxes shall be subject to the limitations now
and hereafter provided by the Constitution and general laws of the State of
Ohio. Nothing contained in this Charter shall be construed as authorizing the
levy of any taxes in excess of such limitation or the change of any tax credit
that has been granted to the residents of this Municipality, by this
Municipality, without the vote of the electors of this Municipality.
(Amended November 4, 2003)
SECTION 15.02. ADDITIONAL LEVIES.
   The authority of the Council to submit additional levies to a vote of the
electors, under the authority of the Constitution or the general laws of the
State of Ohio shall not be deemed impaired, or abridged by reason of any
provision in this Charter.
SECTION 15.03. DEBT LIMITATION.
   Council shall have no power to increase taxes or indebtedness beyond the
limits specified in the Constitution and the general laws of the State of Ohio.
   The term "net indebtedness" as used herein, shall have the meaning, and such
indebtedness shall be calculated, in the manner provided by the Constitution
and the general laws of the State of Ohio, as the same may be amended from time
to time for the issuance of notes and bonds of this Municipality.
SECTION 15.04. LIMITATIONS UPON THE RATE OF TAXATION - FIRE PROTECTION.
   The Council of the City of Munroe Falls may levy taxes upon all taxable
property assessed and listed for taxation according to its value, for the
purpose of providing payment of permanent, part-time, or volunteer firemen. In
no year shall such levy exceed one and one-half (1.5) mills for each dollar of
assessed valuation unless otherwise approved by the voters. The levy so
authorized shall be placed upon the taxable duplicate for the full amount
thereof. Said levy shall be considered as within the ten mill limitation for
purposes of determining the fund created therefrom.
(Amended November 5, 2002.)
SECTION 15.05. LIMITATION UPON THE RATE OF TAXATION - AMBULANCE, PARAMEDIC AND
OTHER EMERGENCY MEDICAL SERVICE.
   The Council of the City of Munroe Falls may levy taxes upon all taxable
property assessed and listed for taxation according to its value, for the
purpose of providing payment for ambulance, paramedic, or other emergency
medical service. In no year shall such levy exceed one and seven-tenths (1.7)
mills for each dollar of assessed valuation unless otherwise approved by the
voters. The levy so authorized shall be placed upon the taxable duplicate for
the full amount thereof. Said levy shall be considered as within the ten-mill
limitation for the purposes of determining the fund created therefrom.
(Amended November 5, 2002.)
ARTICLE XVI
INITIATIVE, REFERENDUM AND RECALL
SECTION 16.01. INITIATIVE AND REFERENDUM.
   (a)   Except as otherwise provided in this Charter, ordinances and
resolutions may be proposed by initiative petition, and ordinances and
resolutions adopted by Council shall be subject to the referendum to the extent
and in the manner provided by the Constitution and the general laws of the
State of Ohio. However, unlike the general laws of the State of Ohio, the Board
of Elections shall submit the initiative or the referendum petition to the
electors of the Municipality at the next primary, special or general election
to be held in the Municipality not less than sixty (60) days after filing said
petition with the Board of Elections.
   (b)   Ordinances and resolutions proposed by initiative petition and adopted
by the electors shall not be subject to veto by the Mayor.
(Amended November 3, 1992) (Amended Res. 2021-01, Passed 02-16-21)
SECTION 16.02. RECALL OF OFFICIALS.
   The electors shall have the power to remove from office by a recall election
any elected officer of this Municipality. If an elected officer shall have
served at least six (6) months of their term, a petition demanding their
removal may be filed with the Clerk of Council, who shall note thereon the name
and the address of the person filing such petition and the date of such filing.
   Such petition shall state the grounds for removal and shall be signed by
qualified electors equal in number to at least fifteen percent (15%) of the
total votes cast in the Municipality for the office of Governor at the last
gubernatorial election.
   Within ten (10) days after the day on which such petition shall have been
filed, the Clerk of Council shall determine whether or not the petition meets
the requirements hereof. If the Clerk of Council finds the petition
insufficient, they shall promptly certify the particulars of such deficiencies
to the person who filed the petition with the Clerk of Council and shall make a
record of such delivery. Such person shall be allowed a period of twenty (20)
days after the date on which such delivery was made in which to make the
petition sufficient. If the petition is sufficient, the Clerk of Council shall
deliver the petition to Council and shall make a record of such delivery.
   If such officer does not resign their office within five (5) days after the
day on which such delivery is made, the Council shall thereupon fix a day for
holding a recall election, not less than sixty (60) days or more than one
hundred twenty (120) days after the date of such refusal to resign. At such
recall election this question shall be placed on the ballot: "Shall (name of
officer) be allowed to continue as (name of office)?" with provision on the
ballot for voting affirmatively or negatively on such question. If a majority
of the votes cast are in the negative, immediately upon the certification by
the Board of Elections of the result of the election such officer shall be
considered removed, their office shall be deemed vacant, and such vacancy shall
be filled as provided in this Charter.
   The officer removed by such recall election shall not be eligible for
appointment to the vacancy created thereby.
(Amended Res. 2021-01, Passed 02-16-21)
ARTICLE XVII
AMENDMENTS TO THE CHARTER
SECTION 17.01. SUBMISSION OF AMENDMENTS TO THE ELECTORS.
   Council may, by affirmative vote of at least five (5) of the members of
Council, submit to the electors any proposed amendment to this Charter; or,
upon petition signed by at least ten percent (10%) of the number of electors of
the Municipality who voted in the most recent gubernatorial election setting
forth any proposed amendment to this Charter, Council shall submit such
proposed amendment to the electors in accordance, in each instance, with the
provisions of the Constitution of the State of Ohio.
SECTION 17.02. ADOPTION OF AMENDMENT.
   If any such amendment is approved by a majority of the electors voting on
the amendment, it shall become a part of this Charter; except if two (2) or
more inconsistent proposed amendments on the same subject are submitted at the
same election, only the proposed amendment receiving the largest affirmative
vote, but not less than a majority, shall become a part of this Charter.
ARTICLE XVIII
CHARTER REVIEW COMMISSION
SECTION 18.01. COMPOSITION AND TERM.
   In January, 1982, and not later than each five (5) years thereafter, the
Mayor shall, with the confirmation of Council, appoint a commission of seven
(7) qualified electors of the Municipality holding no elective office or
compensated position of the Municipality, as members of a Charter Review
Commission to serve until their duties as provided in the following section are
completed.
SECTION 18.02. DUTIES.
   The Charter Review Commission shall, in meetings open to the public, review
the Municipal charter, and, no later than July 1 of the same year, recommend to
Council such amendments, if any, to this Charter as is conducive to the public
interest.
ARTICLE XIX
NOMINATIONS AND ELECTIONS
SECTION 19.01. NOMINATIONS.
   The nominations of all elected officials provided in this Charter shall be
in the manner provided by the general laws of the State of Ohio for nonpartisan
nomination of candidates for elective offices in municipalities.
SECTION 19.02. ELECTIONS.
   A general election for the choice of elective officers provided in this
Charter shall be held on the first Tuesday after the first Monday of November
in odd-numbered years. Such elections shall be known as regular Municipal
elections. Such other elections shall be held as may be required by law or
provided for in this Charter. Any matter which, by the terms of this Charter,
may be submitted to the electors of this Municipality at any special election
may be submitted at the time of any municipal election or the first Tuesday
after the first Monday in May or on such other date as may be set for primary
elections by the State of Ohio. Except as otherwise provided in this Charter,
all elections shall be held and conducted and the results thereof ascertained
and certified as provided by the general laws of the State of Ohio and by the
election of authorities therein provided for.
(Amended 11-7-00)
SECTION 19.03. DIVISION OF MUNICIPALITY INTO WARDS.
   Upon the effective date of this Charter Amendment, the Municipality shall be
divided into three (3) Wards, the boundaries of which are established by the
six (6) precincts within the City of Munroe Falls as redefined from time to
time by the Secretary of State and the Summit County Board of Elections. Ward I
shall consist of Precincts A and F (currently Wards 1 and 6), Ward II shall
consist of Precincts B and D (currently Wards 2 and 4), and Ward III shall
consist of Precincts C and E (currently Wards 3 and 5).
(Enacted 11-6-07; Amended 11-2-10)
ARTICLE XX
GENERAL PROVISIONS
SECTION 20.01. PERSONAL INTEREST.
   No officer or employee of this Municipality shall directly or indirectly
solicit, contract for, receive, or be interested in, any gift, profit, wages or
salaries from or on account of any contract, job, work, or service with, or
for, the Municipality, other than the compensation and expenses for the
performance of duties as may be fixed by Council.
SECTION 20.02. EFFECT OF PARTIAL INVALIDITY.
   The determination by a court of competent jurisdiction that any part of this
Charter is invalid shall not invalidate or impair the force or effect of any
other part of the Charter except to the extent that such other part is wholly
dependent for its operation upon the part declared invalid.
SECTION 20.03. EFFECT OF THE CHARTER UPON EXISTING LAWS AND RIGHTS.
   The taking effect of this Charter shall not affect any pre-existing rights
of the Municipality, or any right or liability or pending suit or prosecution,
either on behalf of or against the Municipality or any officer of the
Municipality, or any contract entered into by the Municipality or for its
benefit, or any franchise granted by the Municipality, or any pending
proceedings for the authorization of public improvements or the levy of
assessments by the Municipality. Except as a contrary intent appears in this
Charter, all acts of Council in effect on the date this Charter becomes
effective shall continue until lawfully amended or replaced.
SECTION 20.04. INTERPRETATION OF THE CHARTER.
   The article and the section headings contained in this Charter have been
inserted for convenient reference and are not intended to define, or to limit
the scope of, or otherwise affect, any provision of this Charter.
   The interpretation of terms contained in this Charter shall be in accordance
with those interpretations expressed in the general laws of the State of Ohio,
except where expressed otherwise in this Charter.
SECTION 20.05. PROVISION FOR SATURDAYS, SUNDAYS AND HOLIDAYS.
   The time within which any act is required to be done under this Charter
shall be computed by excluding the first day and including the last day, except
that when the last day falls on a Saturday, Sunday or on a legal holiday, then
the act may be done on the next day which is not a Saturday, Sunday or a legal
holiday.
   If the day on which any action required to be taken under this Charter is a
Saturday, Sunday or a legal holiday, then the act may be done on the next day
that is not a Saturday, Sunday or a legal holiday.
(Amended 11-6-07)
SECTION 20.06. EFFECTIVE DATE OF CHARTER.
   The provisions of this Charter shall become effective January 1, 1977 except
as may otherwise be provided for in this Charter.
SECTION 20.07. JOURNALS OF THE MUNICIPALITY.
   The Council, all committees composed of four (4) or more members of Council
and all boards and commissions appointed by the Mayor or by Council shall keep
correct journals of their proceedings. Such journals shall be open to public
inspection at all reasonable times. The journals of all public bodies of the
Municipality shall record the vote of each member of the body.
SECTION 20.08. CONTINUATION AND APPOINTMENT OF OFFICERS AND ABOLITION OF
OFFICES.
   The Mayor, Clerk-Treasurer and members of Council holding office on the
effective date of this Charter shall continue in their respective offices until
the expiration of the terms thereof and shall have the powers and duties of
such offices as provided in this Charter. Any vacancy in any such office shall
be filled in the manner provided in this Charter.
   The elective office of Clerk-Treasurer is abolished as of the conclusion of
the term of the incumbent of such office on the effective date of this Charter
or upon the sooner occurrence of a vacancy in such office. The Planning
Commission and Board of Zoning Appeals existing prior to the adoption of this
Charter are abolished as of the effective date hereof.
   The terms of the members of the existing Parks Committee, Planning
Commission, and Board of Zoning Appeals shall terminate on January 1, 1977.
SECTION 20.09. EXECUTIVE SESSIONS.
   (a)   Members of any public body in and for the City of Munroe Falls may
hold an executive session to discuss the following subjects after a majority of
a quorum of the public body determines at regular or special meetings, by roll
call, to hold such sessions:
      1.   Public personnel appointment, employment, discipline or complaints
against public personnel;
      2.   Purchase of property for public purpose;
      3.   Conference with an attorney for the public body concerning disputes
involving the public body that are to be subject of pending or imminent court
action;
      4.   Negotiation or bargaining with public employees regarding
compensation or other terms of employment;
      5.   Other matters required to be kept confidential by federal or state
laws or rules; and,
      6.   Security arrangements where disclosure of the matters discussed
might reveal information that could be used for the purpose of committing, or
avoiding prosecution for, a violation of the law.
(Amended November 3, 1992) (Amended Res. 2021-01, Passed 02-16-21)
SECTION 20.10. NOTICE OF SUSPENSION, DEMOTION OR REMOVAL.
   (a)   The Director of Public Safety, when divested from the office of the
Mayor, shall in the case of suspension, demotion or removal of the Chief of
Police, Chief of the Fire Department, Clerk/Treasurer, or Superintendent of
Roads and Utilities, furnish such individual a copy of the order of suspension,
demotion, or removal. Such order shall be filed with the Clerk of Council.
Within ten (10) days following the filing of such order, said individual may
file an appeal, in writing, with the Clerk of Council. In the event such an
appeal is filed, the Clerk of Council shall forthwith notify the Mayor, and the
Council shall hear such appeal within thirty (30) days from and after its
filing with the Clerk of Council, and by an affirmative vote of at least five
(5) members of Council, it may affirm, disaffirm, or modify the action taken.
   (b)   If the position of Director of Public Safety has not been created,
and/or if vacant, the Mayor shall act as the Director of Public Safety.
(Amended November 3, 1992; 11-6-07) (Amended Res. 2021-01, Passed 02-16-21)
SECTION 20.11   DEFINITIONS.
   The term qualified elector as used herein shall mean an individual eligible
to register to vote within the Municipality.
(Enacted 11-6-07)
