PART ONE - ADMINISTRATIVE CODE
TITLE ONE - General Provisions
         
Chap. 101.   Codified Ordinances.
         
Chap. 103.   Official Standards.
         
Chap. 105.   Bids and Contracts.
CHAPTER 101
Codified Ordinances
101.01   Designation; citation; headings.
101.02   General definitions.
101.03   Rules of construction.
101.04   Revivor; effect of amendment or repeal.
101.05   Construction of section references.
101.06   Conflicting provisions.
101.07   Determination of legislative intent.
101.08   Severability.
101.99   General penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   See sectional histories for similar State law
   Statute of limitations on prosecutions - see Ohio R.C. 718.06; GEN. OFF.
501.06
   Codification in book form - see Ohio R.C. 731.23
   Imprisonment until fine and costs are paid - see Ohio R.C. 1905.30, 2947.14
   Citation issuance for minor misdemeanors - see Ohio R.C. 2935.26 et seq.
   Ordinances and resolutions - see ADM.
Ch. 123
   Rules of construction for offenses and penalties - see GEN. OFF.
501.04
101.01 DESIGNATION; CITATION; HEADINGS.
   (a)   All ordinances of a permanent and general nature of the Municipality
as revised, codified, rearranged, renumbered and consolidated into component
codes, titles, chapters and sections shall be known and designated as the
Codified Ordinances of Munroe Falls, Ohio, 1987, for which designation
“Codified Ordinances” may be substituted. Code, title, chapter and section
headings do not constitute any part of the law as contained in the Codified
Ordinances.
(ORC 1.01)
   (b)   All references to codes, titles, chapters and sections are to such
components of the Codified Ordinances unless otherwise specified. Any component
code may be referred to and cited by its name, such as the “Traffic Code”.
Sections may be referred to and cited by the designation “Section” followed by
the number, such as “Section 101.01".
101.02 GENERAL DEFINITIONS.
   As used in the Codified Ordinances, unless another definition is provided or
the context otherwise requires:
   (a)   “And” may be read “or”, and “or” may be read “and”, if the sense
requires it.
(ORC 1.02(F))
   (b)   “Another” when used to designate the owner of property which is the
subject of an offense, includes not only natural persons but also every other
owner of property.
(ORC 1.02(B))
   (c)   “Bond” includes an undertaking and “undertaking” includes a bond.
(ORC 1.02(D), (E))
   (d)   “Council” means the legislative authority of the Municipality.
   (e)   “County” means Summit County, Ohio
   (f)   “Keeper” or “proprietor” includes all persons, whether acting by
themselves or as a servant, agent or employee.
   (g)   “Land” or “real estate” includes rights and easements of an
incorporeal nature.
(ORC 701.01(F))
   (h)   “Municipality” or “City” means the Municipality of Munroe Falls, Ohio.
   (i)   “Oath” includes affirmation and “swear” includes affirm.
(ORC 1.59(B))
   (j)   “Owner”, when applied to property, includes any part owner, joint
owner or tenant in common of the whole or part of such property.
   (k)   “Person” includes an individual, corporation, business trust, estate,
trust, partnership and association.
(ORC 1.59(C))
   (l)   “Premises”, as applied to property, includes land and buildings.
   (m)   “Property” means real and personal property.
(ORC 1.59(E))
      “Personal property” includes all property except real.
      “Real property” includes lands, tenements and hereditaments.
   (n)   “Public authority” includes boards of education; the Municipal,
County, State or Federal government, its officers or an agency thereof; or any
duly authorized public official.
   (o)   “Public place” includes any street, sidewalk, park, cemetery, school
yard, body of water or watercourse, public conveyance, or any other place for
the sale of merchandise, public accommodation or amusement.
   (p)   “Registered mail” includes certified mail and “certified mail”
includes registered mail.
(ORC 1.02(G))
   (q)   “Rule” includes regulation.
(ORC 1.59(F))
   (r)   “Sidewalk” means that portion of the street between the curb line and
the adjacent property line intended for the use of pedestrians.
   (s)   “This State” or “the State” means the State of Ohio.
(ORC 1.59(G))
   (t)   “Street” includes alleys, avenues, boulevards, lanes, roads, highways,
viaducts and all other public thoroughfares within the Municipality.
   (u)   “Tenant” or “occupant”, as applied to premises, includes any person
holding a written or oral lease, or who actually occupies the whole or any part
of such premises, alone or with others.
   (v)   “Whoever” includes all persons, natural and artificial; partners;
principals, agents and employees; and all officials, public or private.
(ORC 1.02(A))
   (w)   “Written” or “in writing” includes any representation of words,
letters, symbols or figures. This provision does not affect any law relating to
signatures.
(ORC 1.59(J))
101.03 RULES OF CONSTRUCTION.
   (a)   Common and Technical Usage. Words and phrases shall be read in context
and construed according to the rules of grammar and common usage. Words and
phrases that have acquired a technical or particular meaning, whether by
legislative definition or otherwise, shall be construed accordingly.
(ORC 1.42)
   (b)   Singular and Plural; Gender; Tense. As used in the Codified
Ordinances, unless the context otherwise requires:
      (1)   The singular includes the plural, and the plural includes the
singular.
      (2)   Words of one gender include the other genders.
      (3)   Words in the present tense include the future.
(ORC 1.43)
   (c)   Calendar; Computation of Time.
      (1)   Definitions.
         A.   “Week” means seven consecutive days.
         B.   “Year” means twelve consecutive months.
(ORC 1.44)
      (2)   If a number of months is to be computed by counting the months from
a particular day, the period ends on the same numerical day in the concluding
month as the day of the month from which the computation is begun, unless there
are not that many days in the concluding month, in which case the period ends
on the last day of that month.
(ORC 1.45)
      (3)   The time within which an act is required by law to be done shall be
computed by excluding the first and including the last day, except that when
the last day falls on Sunday or a legal holiday, then the act may be done on
the next succeeding day which is not a Sunday or a legal holiday.
         When a public office, in which an act required by law is to be
performed, is closed to the public for the entire day which constitutes the
last day for doing such act or before its usual closing time on such day, then
such act may be performed on the next succeeding day which is not a Sunday or a
legal holiday. If any legal holiday falls on Sunday, the next succeeding day is
a legal holiday.
(ORC 1.14)
      (4)   When legislation is to take effect or become operative from and
after a day named, no part of that day shall be included.
(ORC 1.15)
      (5)   In all cases where the law shall require any act to be done in a
reasonable time or reasonable notice to be given, such reasonable time or
notice shall mean such time only as may be necessary for the prompt performance
of such duty or compliance with such notice.
   (d)   Authority. When the law requires an act to be done which may by law as
well be done by an agent as by the principal, such requirement shall be
construed to include all such acts when done by an authorized agent.
   (e)   Joint Authority. All words purporting to give joint authority to three
or more municipal officers or other persons shall be construed as giving such
authority to a majority of such officers or other persons, unless it shall be
otherwise expressly declared in the law giving the authority or inconsistent
with State statute or Charter provisions.
   (f)   Exceptions. The rules of construction shall not apply to any law which
shall contain any express provision excluding such construction, or when the
subject matter or context of such law may be repugnant thereto.
101.04 REVIVOR; EFFECT OF AMENDMENT OR REPEAL.
   (a)   The repeal of a repealing ordinance does not revive the ordinance
originally repealed nor impair the effect of any saving clause therein.
(ORC 1.57)
   (b)   An ordinance which is re-enacted or amended is intended to be a
continuation of the prior ordinance and not a new enactment, so far as it is
the same as the prior ordinance.
(ORC 1.54)
   (c)   The re-enactment, amendment or repeal of an ordinance does not, except
as provided in subsection (d) hereof:
      (1)   Affect the prior operation of the ordinance or any prior action
taken thereunder;
      (2)   Affect any validation, cure, right, privilege, obligation or
liability previously acquired, accrued, accorded or incurred thereunder;
      (3)   Affect any violation thereof or penalty, forfeiture or punishment
incurred in respect thereto, prior to the amendment or repeal;
      (4)   Affect any investigation, proceeding or remedy in respect of any
such privilege, obligation, liability, penalty, forfeiture or punishment; and
the investigation, proceeding or remedy may be instituted, continued or
enforced, and the penalty, forfeiture or punishment imposed, as if the
ordinance had not been repealed or amended.
   (d)   If the penalty, forfeiture or punishment for any offense is reduced by
a re-enactment or amendment of an ordinance, the penalty, forfeiture, or
punishment, if not already imposed, shall be imposed according to the ordinance
as amended.
(ORC 1.58)
101.05 CONSTRUCTION OF SECTION REFERENCES.
   (a)   A reference to any portion of the Codified Ordinances applies to all
re-enactments or amendments thereof.
(ORC 1.55)
   (b)   If a section refers to a series of numbers or letters, the first and
the last numbers or letters are included.
(ORC 1.56)
   (c)   Wherever in a penalty section reference is made to a violation of a
series of sections or of subsections of a section, such reference shall be
construed to mean a violation of any section or subsection included in such
reference.
   References in the Codified Ordinances to action taken or authorized under
designated sections of the Codified Ordinances include, in every case, action
taken or authorized under the applicable legislative provision which is
superseded by the Codified Ordinances.
(ORC 1.23)
101.06 CONFLICTING PROVISIONS.
   (a)   If there is a conflict between figures and words in expressing a
number, the words govern.
(ORC 1.46)
   (b)   If a general provision conflicts with a special or local provision,
they shall be construed, if possible, so that effect is given to both. If the
conflict between the provisions is irreconcilable, the special or local
provision prevails as an exception to the general provision, unless the general
provision is the later adoption and the manifest intent is that the general
provision prevail.
(ORC 1.51)
   (c)   (1)   If ordinances enacted at different meetings of Council are
irreconcilable, the ordinance latest in date of enactment prevails.
      (2)   If amendments to the same ordinance are enacted at different
meetings of Council, one amendment without reference to another, the amendments
are to be harmonized, if possible, so that effect may be given to each. If the
amendments are substantively irreconcilable, the latest in date of enactment
prevails. The fact that a later amendment restates language deleted by an
earlier amendment, or fails to include language inserted by an earlier
amendment, does not of itself make the amendments irreconcilable. Amendments
are irreconcilable only when changes made by each cannot reasonably be put into
simultaneous operation.
(ORC 1.52)
101.07 DETERMINATION OF LEGISLATIVE INTENT.
   (a)   In enacting an ordinance, it is presumed that:
      (1)   Compliance with the constitutions of the State and of the United
States is intended;
      (2)   The entire ordinance is intended to be effective;
      (3)   A just and reasonable result is intended;
      (4)   A result feasible of execution is intended.
(ORC 1.47)
   (b)   An ordinance is presumed to be prospective in its operation unless
expressly made retrospective.
(ORC 1.48)
   (c)   If an ordinance is ambiguous, the court, in determining the intention
of Council may consider among other matters:
      (1)   The object sought to be attained;
      (2)   The circumstances under which the ordinance was enacted;
      (3)   The legislative history;
      (4)   The common law or former legislative provisions, including laws
upon the same or similar subjects;
      (5)   The consequences of a particular construction;
      (6)   The administrative construction of the ordinance.
(ORC 1.49)
101.08 SEVERABILITY.
   If any provision of a section of the Codified Ordinances or the application
thereof to any person or circumstance is held invalid, the invalidity does not
affect the other provisions or applications of the section or related sections
which can be given effect without the invalid provision or application, and to
this end the provisions are severable.
(ORC 1.50)
101.99 GENERAL PENALTY.
   Whenever, in the Codified Ordinances or in any ordinance of the
Municipality, any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an
offense or a misdemeanor, or whenever the doing of any act is required or the
failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful, where no specific penalty is
otherwise provided, whoever violates any such provision shall be punished by a
fine not exceeding one hundred dollars ($100.00). A separate offense shall be
deemed committed each day during or on which a violation continues or occurs.

CHAPTER 105
Bids and Contracts
105.01   Bidding requirements.
105.02   Local preference.
105.03   Lowest and best bid defined.
105.04   Bid opening of sealed competitive bids, modification.
105.05   Bid opening by reverse internet auction.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Bids and proceedings - see Ohio R.C. 731.14 et seq.
   Contract interest - see GEN. OFF. see Ohio R.C. 735.09; GEN. OFF.
525.10
   Police protection contracts - see Ohio R.C. 737.04
105.01 BIDDING REQUIREMENTS.
   (a)   (1)   The Mayor may enter into a contract for the purchase of
emergency supplies, materials, services, insurance and/or labor involving less
than seventy-five thousand dollars ($75,000.00) during a calendar year without
the necessity of competitive bidding upon written approval from the President
of Council and/or the Vice President of Council in the absence of the
President.
      (2)   The Mayor may enter into a contract to purchase supplies,
materials, services, insurance, and/or labor involving not more than seventy-
five thousand dollars ($75,000.00) during a calendar year without written
approval from Council or the necessity of competitive bidding.
   (b)   Unless Council finds the required materials, labor, service or
insurance is of a specialized nature as not to lend itself to competitive
bidding and/or an emergency exists, contracts exceeding seventy-five thousand
dollars ($75,000.00) in a calendar year, shall be the lowest and best bidder
after advertisement for not less than two nor more than four weeks in a
newspaper of general circulation within the City. However, contracts entered
into pursuant to Ohio R.C. 713.23(D), 125.04 or 5513.01, or with another
political subdivision or instrumentality of the State, or available from a
qualified nonprofit agency pursuant to Ohio R.C. 4115.31 through 4115.35 are
exempt from competitive bidding.
   (c)   Upon findings by the Council of the City of Munroe Falls that real
estate is not needed for public use, the real estate may be sold or leased upon
either of the following procedures:
      (1)   The real property shall be advertised for sale or lease once a week
for three consecutive weeks in a newspaper of general circulation within the
City of Munroe Falls and shall be conveyed to the highest bidder upon approval
by the majority of the Council of the City of Munroe Falls.
      (2)   Without advertising a sale or lease of the real property may be
made to a named grantee at a fixed price and/or term when the Council of the
City of Munroe Falls specifically authorizes said sale or lease by a two-thirds
vote of its members.
   (d)   (1)   Beginning on the effective date of this section through calendar
year 2024, seventy-five thousand dollars ($75,000.00);
      (2)   For each calendar year thereafter, the amount for the previous
calendar year increased by three percent (3%) as determined and published by
the director of commerce.
(Ord. 08-00. Passed 3-6-00; Ord. 13-2007. Passed 6-19-07; Ord. 05-08. Passed 4-
1-08; Ord. 02-2010. Passed 5-4-10; Ord. 2015-13. Passed 12-22-15; Ord. 2017-04.
Passed 2-7-17; Ord. 2024-05. Passed 8-20-24.)
105.02 LOCAL PREFERENCE.
   (a)   In determining the lowest and best bid for supplies, commodities,
materials, equipment, furnishings or general services, Council shall exercise a
preference for local preference as provided herein. The local preference shall
also apply to contracts for the building, repair or renovation of public
buildings or improvements.
   (b)   Bidders having established their principal place of business, defined
as a business with a significant economic and physical presence in Munroe Falls
for two successive calendar years prior to the bid opening date, shall be
preferred as lowest and best.
   (c)   To qualify for local preference, bidders shall state on the bid
documents their principal place of business, the business address where work
will be administered (post office boxes will not be accepted in lieu of a
street address) and the date of establishment. Each bidder shall have only one
principal place of business.
   (d)   Local preferences shall not be applied as provided herein for any bids
where prohibited by federal or state laws or regulations.
   (e)   Local preferences shall only be applied in considering the lowest and
best bid.
   (f)   Formal bid local preference and informal bid local preference shall
not apply when purchases or services are made for professional services or made
from an approved bid list, online auction, auction or when purchasing water,
gas, electricity, or services from another political subdivision of the State
of Ohio or the State of Ohio.
(Ord. 2024-05. Passed 8-20-24.)
105.03 LOWEST AND BEST BID DEFINED.
   (a)   The City will award contracts to the lowest and best bidder. The
following factors are significant in determining whether a bid is the lowest
and best bid and may be considered and applied by city officials, in their
discretion, when determining the lowest and best bid for supplies, commodities,
materials, equipment, furnishings or construction, renovation, maintenance,
repair, businesses or general services.
      (1)   The bidder's familiarity with the project.
      (2)   Adequacy of the equipment for the project.
      (3)   The bidder's record on similar projects.
      (4)   The bidder's experience in the relevant field in the preceding
twelve months, including the original contract price for each job undertaken
and the cost of any change order and overruns.
      (5)   The bidder's compliance with deadlines.
      (6)   The bidder's prior performance on any project taken for the City of
Munroe Falls.
      (7)   The bidder's financial solvency.
      (8)   Whether the bidder has ever sued or been sued by a public entity
over a public project.
      (9)   The bidder's bonding record.
      (10)   The bidder's compliance record with, and maintenance of,
unemployment and workers' compensation laws for all employees.
      (11)   The bidder's compliance record with, and maintenance of, federal
and state wage laws for all employees.
      (12)   The bidder's compliance record with, and maintenance of, the Fair
Labor Standards Act for all employees.
      (13)   The bidder's compliance record with, and maintenance of,
Occupational Safety and Health Administration regulations for all employees.
      (14)   The experience, training, and skill of the bidder's workforce in
writing.
      (15)   The number of years the bidder has been in the relevant
businesses.
      (16)   The continuity of the bidder's workforce.
      (17)   The bidder's past compliance with employee drug testing.
      (18)   Past compliance with local and state income tax laws.
      (19)   The bidder's participation in a state accredited apprenticeship
program when it is required by Ohio prevailing wage law.
      (20)   Any other factor determined to be relevant.
   (b)   Bid specifications shall contain provisions conforming to subsection
(a) of this section. Evidence of the factors they wish to be considered is the
responsibility of the bidder.
   (c)   City officials may reject any or all bids, or parts of bids, for any
reason if acceptance is not in the best interest of the City.
(Ord. 2024-05. Passed 8-20-24.)
105.04 BID OPENING OF SEALED COMPETITIVE BIDS, MODIFICATION.
   All bid documents shall be delivered to the office of the department where
the bids are to be received in a single sealed envelope prior to the time of
the bid opening. Unless the time is extended by the City, the bid for which the
award is to be made shall be opened at the time and place named in the
advertisement for bids and shall be publicly read. Except as otherwise provided
herein, written or oral notice of any extension shall be given no later than
forty-eight hours prior to the original time and date fixed for the opening to
all persons who have received or requested specifications. Any modification of
the plans or specifications and estimates of cost for the project for which
bids are solicited shall be issued and mailed or otherwise furnished to persons
who have obtained or requested plans or specifications for the project. If any
modification of the plans or specifications and estimates of cost for the
project is issued seventy-two hours or less prior to the published time for the
opening of bids, excluding Saturdays, Sundays, and legal holidays, the time for
opening of bids shall be extended one week.
   No further advertising of bids is required under this section. Any notice
required herein may be accomplished by facsimile transmission. Notice shall be
complete upon mailing or transmission.
(Ord. 2024-05. Passed 8-20-24.)
105.05 BID OPENING BY REVERSE INTERNET AUCTION.
   If the City is required by law to purchase services or supplies by
competitive sealed bidding and the City determines that the use of a reverse
internet auction is advantageous to the political subdivision, the political
subdivision, in accordance with the Ohio Revised Code and any rules and
ordinances of the City shall adopt, may purchase services or supplies by
reverse internet auction.
   Except as otherwise provided herein, written or oral notice of any extension
shall be given no later than forty-eight hours prior to the original time and
date fixed for the opening to all persons who have received or requested
specifications. Any modification of the plans or specifications and estimates
of cost for the project for which bids are solicited shall be issued and mailed
or otherwise furnished to persons who have obtained or requested plans or
specifications for the project. If any modification of the plans or
specifications and estimates of cost for the project is issued seventy-two
hours or less prior to the published time for the opening of bids, excluding
Saturdays, Sundays, and legal holidays, the time for opening of bids shall be
extended one week. Any notice or modification required by this section may be
made by posting the notice or modification on the internet site of the reverse
auction and only if the bid documents announce that such notices and
modifications will be so posted.
   No further advertising of bids is required under this section. Any notice
required herein may be accomplished by facsimile transmission. Notice shall be
complete upon mailing or transmission.
(Ord. 2024-05. Passed 8-20-24.)

525.10 
121.01 RULES OF COUNCIL.
   (a)   Organization of Council.
      (1)   On January 2 of each year, Council shall convene and organize at
the Council Chambers of the Municipality, unless there are no newly elected
Council members to be sworn. If there are no newly elected Council members to
be sworn, Council shall convene and organize prior to its first meeting of the
year. The Mayor or a member of Council appointed by the Mayor shall preside as
a temporary chairman only until the President of Council is elected.
(Ord. 38-2002. Passed 11-19-02.)
       (2)   Council shall, at each organizational meeting by majority vote,
elect from among its members a President of Council, who shall preside at all
meetings of Council, and a Vice-President of Council, who shall preside at
meetings of Council in the absence of the President of Council.
      (3)   The President of Council and the Vice-President of Council, neither
by virtue of holding such offices nor in performing the duties of Acting Mayor,
as provided for in Section
4.07 of the Charter; shall be deprived of their powers and rights or be
relieved of any of their duties and obligations as members of Council.
      (4)   Council, at its organizational meeting, shall elect from its
membership, a member of the Planning and Zoning Commission, and may elect a
second member of Council to serve and vote at a Planning and Zoning Commission
meeting when the primary elected council member is unable to attend a meeting.
      (5)   Council shall at each organizational meeting organize itself into
the standing committes as set forth below:
         A.   The Community/Economic Development Committee shall:
            1.   Consist of not less than three of the members of Council.
               2.   Meet at least once each month.
            3.   Conduct meetings open to the public.
         B.   The Finance/Audit Committee shall:
            1.   Consist of not less than three of the members of Council and
the President of Council.
            2.   Meet at least once each month on the third Tuesday of each
month, or as needed by the Finance/Audit Committee.
            3.   Conduct meetings open to the public.
         C.    The General Government Services Committee shall:
            1.   Consist of not less than three of the members of Council.
            2.   Meet at least once each month.
            3.   Conduct meetings open to the public.
         D.   The Public Safety Committee shall:
            1.   Consist of not less than three of the members of Council.
            2.   Meet at least once each month.
            3.   Conduct meetings open to the public.
(Ord. 38-00. Passed 4-5-00; Ord. 01-2006. Passed 1-17-06; Ord. 2022-06. Passed
5-17-22.)
   (b)   Meetings of Council.
      (1)   Council shall meet at such times as may be prescribed by resolution
or ordinance, except that it shall hold regular meetings at least once each
calendar month.
      (2)   All regular meetings of Council shall be held at the Council
chambers of the Municipality and shall be open to the public.
      (3)   A quorum shall exist when a majority of the prescribed membership
of Council is present at any regular or special meeting of Council. When a
quorum does not exist, a majority of those members who are present may compel
the attendance of an unexcused absent member in such manner and under such
penalty as may be prescribed by resolution.
      (4)   The Order of Business for this Council shall be, unless the order
is changed by motion of Council, as follows:
         Call to Order
         Opening
         Roll Call
         Approval of Minutes
         Reports of Officials
            Report of the Mayor
            Report of the Law Director
            Report of the President of Council
            Report of the Director of Finance
            Report of the Roads and Utilities Superintendent
            Report of the Police Chief
            Report of the Fire Chief
         Reports of Committees
            Finance/Audit Committee
            General Government Services Committee
            Public Safety Committee
            Community/Economic Development Committee
            Planning Commission Report
            Parks and Recreation Board
         Persons to Appear before Council
         Ordinances for 1st Reading
         Ordinances for 2nd Reading
           Ordinances for 3rd Reading
         Resolutions for 1st Reading
         Resolutions for 2nd Reading
         Resolutions for 3rd Reading
         Old Business
         New Business
         Adjournment
(Ord. 29. Passed 9-5-00; Ord. 39-00. Passed 9-5-00; Ord. 07-2005. Passed 3-15-
05.)
   (c)   Special Meetings of Council.
      (1)   Special meetings of Council shall be called by a vote of Council
taken at any regular meeting or special meeting thereof, or shall be called by
the Clerk of Council upon the written request of the Mayor, or the President of
Council, or of any three of the members of Council.
      (2)   Notice, in writing, of each such special meeting called at the
request of the Mayor, or of the President of Council or of any three of the
members of Council, shall state the date and the time, and the subject or
subjects to be considered thereat. The Clerk of Council shall cause such
written notice to be served to all officials holding elective office, either
personally or by leaving a copy thereof at their usual place of residence, not
less than twenty-four hours preceding the time for the meeting. In the event
that a special meeting is called by a vote of Council at any regular meeting or
special meeting from which any member of Council is absent, written notice of
such special meeting shall be given such absentee in the manner and the form
herein provided. Service of such notice may be waived by an instrument in
writing signed prior to the hour of such meeting, and the Mayor and any
Councilman shall be deemed conclusively to have waived such notice by his
attendance at any such meeting.
      (3)   All special meetings of Council shall be held at the Council
chambers of the Municipality and shall be open to the public.
   (d)   Legislation.
      (1)   All Council legislation shall be by ordinance or by resolution
which shall have been considered and introduced by a committee of Council in
written or printed form.
      (2)   Legislation shall contain no more than one subject which shall be
clearly expressed in its title.
      (3)   Legislation shall have prior review by the Director of Law for form
and content for conformity with the provisions of the Charter and of the
Constitution and of the general laws of the State. Such legislation shall have
endorsed upon it the approval of the Director of Law.
      (4)   Council may proceed with consideration of legislation without the
endorsement of the Director of Law upon the affirmative vote of two-thirds of
the members of Council.
      (5)   All ordinances and resolutions shall be read at three different
meetings of Council, of which at least two must be regular meetings.
      (6)   All readings shall be by title only, unless otherwise voted by a
majority of the members of Council.
      (7)   Council may vote to suspend the rule requiring three separate
readings which shall require the affirmative vote of at least three-fourths of
the members of Council, except as follows:
         A.   Any change of the boundaries of the Municipality;
         B.   Any granting of a franchise;
         C.   Any resolution declaring the necessity of an improvement or
service to be paid for in whole or in part from special assessments;
         D.   Any enactment, amendment, or repeal of any zoning or building
ordinance or resolution; or
         E.   Any establishment or change of financial compensation for any
official holding elective office.
      (8)   Each ordinance or resolution considered to be an emergency shall
contain a statement of the necessity for such emergency action.
      (9)   The enactment of emergency legislation shall require the
affirmative vote of at least two-thirds of the members of Council.
      (10)   No action of Council authorizing the following subjects shall be
enacted as an emergency measure:
         A.   Any change of the boundaries of the municipality;
         B.   Any granting of a franchise;
         C.   Any resolution declaring the necessity of an improvement or
service to be paid for in whole or in part from special assessments;
         D.   Any enactment, amendment, or repeal of any zoning or building
ordinance or resolution; or
         E.   Any establishment or change of financial compensation for any
official holding elective office.
      (11)   An affirmative vote of a majority of the members of Council shall
be required for the adoption of any ordinance or resolution, except as may be
otherwise provided for herein. The vote shall be taken by roll call. These
votes shall be on a rotational basis, by names as determined by the Clerk of
Council.
      (12)   The determination of the results of any vote of Council shall be
calculated on the full prescribed membership of council as stated in the
Charter.
      (13)   All resolutions and ordinances providing for the appropriation of
money, or for improvements petitioned for by the owners of a majority of front
footage or property to be benefited and specially assessed for, and any
emergency resolution or ordinance, as defined by the Charter, shall take effect
immediately unless a late date be specified therein, upon its approval by the
Mayor, or upon the expiration of the time within which it may be vetoed by the
Mayor, as the case may be. No other resolution or ordinance shall become
effective until thirty days after it is adopted.
      (14)   It shall be in order to amend a resolution or ordinance at any
time, but if such ordinance or resolution be of a general or permanent nature,
and such amendment is made after the second reading, it shall again be read, as
amended, as the second reading, and laid over to the next meeting of Council
for final action.
   (e)   Amendment of Council Rules.
      (1)   These rules may be amended, altered or new rules adopted at any
time; but in the case of any amendment, alteration or adoption of new rules,
the matter shall be referred to a select committee of three or more members of
Council, and such amendment, alteration, or new rules shall be read on three
different days, unless the rules shall be suspended by an affirmative vote of
three-fourths of the members of Council.
   The requirements of (e)(1) shall not apply in the case of a motion to adopt
any future edition of Robert's Rules of Order, Newly Revised.
      (2)   Any amendment, alteration or adoption of new rules shall be upon a
majority vote of the members.
      (3)   Except as otherwise provided in these rules or by specific motion
of Council, Robert's Rules of Order, Newly Revised, shall govern the
proceedings and deliberations of this Council.
(Ord. 01-08. Passed 1-2-08; Ord. 02-08. Passed 1-2-08; Ord. 03-08. Passed 1-15-
08; Ord. 11-2009. Passed 12-15-09.)

notices or reports required by law or ordinance to be published shall be
published by posting copies thereof for ten days in the following places:

      (3)   North Akron Savings Bank - 34 South Main Street
      (4)   Munroe Falls Police Department - 33 Munroe Falls Ave.
      (5)   Munroe Falls Fire Department - 33 Munroe Falls Ave.
   (b)   The posting shall be in a conspicuous place in such buildings and
readily available to all members of the public at reasonable hours.
(Ord. 06-98. Passed 7-7-98.)
123.02 DESTRUCTION OF MUNICIPAL RECORDS.
   (a)   No person shall maliciously alter, deface, mutilate, destroy, conceal,
remove, withdraw or transfer from the Munroe Falls Town Hall, the whole or part
of any record, authorized to be kept by law of or pertaining to any Municipal
office or officer, or other public official or duty of any one of them, except
in the course of his official duties.
(Ord. 11-66. Passed 4-5-66.)
   (b)   Whoever violates this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of the
third degree.

135.01 SHORT TITLE.

Ordinance.”
(Ord. 2015-03. Passed 4-7-15.)
135.02 LAW DIRECTOR SERVES ONLY THE CITY OF MUNROE FALLS.
   The Law Director of the City serves only the City of Munroe Falls and no
other political subdivision or governmental entity. City Charter Section 8.03
and this chapter are the exclusive statement of the Law Director’s duties. Any
provision of the laws of the State, including but not limited to Ohio R.C.
3313.35, which seeks to impose duties upon the Law Director to perform services
for the benefit of any other political subdivision or governmental entity is in
conflict with the Charter and this chapter and is of no force and effect.
(Ord. 2015-03. Passed 4-7-15.)

CHAPTER 139
Department of Roads and Utilities
139.01   Fees.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Qualifications - see CHTR. Sec.
10.01
   Appointment and removal - see CHTR. Sec.
10.02
   Duties - see CHTR. Sec.

139.01 FEES.
   (a)   The costs of the use of the Municipal Engineer, the Superintendent of
Roads and Utilities and any and all other Municipal employees for work required
to be performed for inspection of construction, review of plans, and
preparation of plans shall be calculated at the employee's regular rate of pay
plus the fringe benefits attributable to the employee plus two dollars and
seventy-two cents ($2.72) per hour attributable to overhead for the employee.
   (b)   If an ordinance of the Municipality specifies a different rate for
work performed, the specific rate provided in such ordinance shall take
precedence over this section.
   (c)   Work performed by the Municipal consulting engineer shall be charged
to third parties at the same rate appearing in the ordinance authorizing the
renewal of the contract with the consulting engineer. The charge shall be
billed for those services rendered and designated by ordinance as an expense of
such third party.
(Ord. 23-87. Passed 8-4-87.)

CHAPTER 150
Records Commission
150.01   Members of City Records Commission.
150.02   Power and duties.
150.03   Regulations and time frames.
150.04   Compensation, terms, and vacancies.
150.05   Record retention program to be adopted.
150.01 MEMBERS OF CITY RECORDS COMMISSION.
   (a)   There is hereby created a City Records Commission to review the record
retention program and the disposing of outdated records and other materials.
This Commission shall consist of four members as follows:
      (1)   Chief Executive Officer for the City (Mayor), or the Mayor's
appointed representative, who shall also serve as the Chairperson for the
Commission; and
      (2)   Chief Fiscal Officer for the City (Director of Finance); and
      (3)   Chief Legal Officer for the City (Law Director); and
      (4)   One citizen of the City to be appointed by the Chairperson.
   (b)   The Commission shall also appoint a Secretary, who may or may not be a
member of the Commission, and who shall serve at the pleasure of the
Commission.
(Ord. 2022-13. Passed 11-15-22.)
150.02 POWER AND DUTIES.
   The function of the City of Munroe Falls Records Commission shall be to
provide rules for retention and disposal of records of the City and to review
applications for one-time record disposal and schedules of record retention if
not stated in the adopted Records Retention Schedule (RC-2) referenced in
Section
150.05 and to review applications for one-time disposal of obsolete records and
other materials and schedules of record retention and disposition submitted by
City of Munroe Falls department heads. The Commission at any time may review
any schedule it has previously approved and for good cause shown may revise
that schedule.
(Ord. 2022-13. Passed 11-15-22.)
150.03 REGULATIONS AND TIME FRAMES.
   The Records Commission will meet every six months. The Chairperson shall
call the meeting. There shall be a minimum of three members of the Commission
to constitute a quorum. It shall be a public meeting; meeting all the
requirements for a public meeting and there shall be minutes kept of the
meeting and given the Clerk of Council.
(Ord. 2022-13. Passed 11-15-22.)
150.04 COMPENSATION, TERMS, AND VACANCIES.
   The members of the City Records Commission shall serve without compensation.
The term of office for the Mayor shall be commensurate with the mayoral term of
office. The Finance Director shall be the length of the position. The term for
the Law Director would be for the length of the contract with the City. The
term for the citizen member shall be for a two-year period. Any vacancy of an
unexpired term of the citizen member shall be filled by the Mayor for the
unexpired term.
(Ord. 2022-13. Passed 11-15-22.)
150.05 RECORD RETENTION PROGRAM TO BE ADOPTED.
   (a)   The City of Munroe Falls shall adopt as its Record Retention Program
the City of Munroe Falls Records Retention Schedule (RC-2) approved by the Ohio
History Connection - State Archives.
   (b)   The information in the City of Munroe Falls Records Retention Schedule
(RC-2) will be the regulations and the time frames used for the City's record
retention program.
(Ord. 2022-13. Passed 11-15-22.)
CHAPTER 151
Division of Police
151.01   Established; composition.
151.02   Physical exams.
151.03   Chief of Police
151.04   Auxiliary police unit.
151.05   Maximum age for original appointment.
151.06   Volunteer Peace Officers’ Dependents Fund Board.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Composition; appointment and removal - see CHTR. Sec.
9.03
   Assistance of State Criminal Bureau - see Ohio R.C. 109.58 et seq.
   Peace officer training certificate required - see Ohio R.C. 109.77
   Police protection contracts - see Ohio R.C. 505.441, 737.04
151.01 ESTABLISHED; COMPOSITION.
   There is hereby created the Municipal Police Department consisting of a
Chief, two Sergeants, and such full-time and part-time police officers as are
determined necessary by the Director of Public Safety.
(Ord. 6-83. Passed 3-1-83.)
151.02 PHYSICAL EXAMS.
   All individuals appointed to the Police Department shall pass a physical
examination as provided by the Ohio Revised Code and a psychological
examination and the fees for such examinations shall be paid by the
Municipality.
(Ord. 6-83. Passed 3-1-83.)
151.03 CHIEF OF POLICE.
   The Chief of Police shall be the executive head of the Police Department. He
shall enforce the laws of the State of Ohio and the City of Munroe Falls and
shall perform such other duties as prescribed by statute or ordinance.
(Ord. 12-91. Passed 5-21-91.)
151.04 AUXILIARY POLICE UNIT.
   (a)   Pursuant to Ohio R.C. 737.051 and the Charter of the City of Munroe
Falls, there is hereby created an auxiliary police department comprised of two
classes; namely, Auxiliary 1 and Auxiliary 2.
(Ord. 37-92. Passed 6-16-92.)
   (b)   The Mayor shall be the executive administrator of the auxiliary police
unit, shall make all appointments and removals of auxiliary police officers,
and shall prescribe rules and regulations for the organization, training,
administration, control and conduct of the auxiliary police unit.
   (c)   The Police Chief shall have the exclusive control of stationing and
transferring of all auxiliary police officers under the general rules and
regulations as prescribed by the Mayor.
   (d)   The members of the auxiliary police unit are not eligible for
membership in the Police Relief and Pension Fund.
   (e)   All services performed by members of the auxiliary police unit shall
be on a volunteer basis within the Municipality.
   (f)   Each member of the auxiliary police unit shall be paid one dollar
($1.00) annually to be paid at the same time the member receives his or her
annual uniform allowance.
(Ord. 18-89. Passed 6-20-89.)
   (g)   Each member of the auxiliary police unit shall be given an annual
uniform allowance of one hundred and fifty dollars ($150.00), payable in April.
The uniform allowance shall be paid to a member only if that member has
completed 180 hours of service to the Municipality within in the auxiliary
police unit during the preceding calendar year.
   Each appointed member shall be provided upon initial appointment, at City
expense, with an initial uniform and accessories as prescribed by the Chief of
Police, at a cost not to exceed four hundred dollars ($400.00). Said uniform
and accessories shall be issued to the Auxiliary Officer but will remain the
property of the police department.
(Ord. 06-2002. Passed 5-6-02.)
   (h)   Each member of the auxiliary police unit shall be at least eighteen
years of age at the time of his or her appointment and shall abide by the rules
and regulations established by the Chief of Police for the auxiliary police
unit.
(Ord. 18-89. Passed 6-20-89.)
   (i)   Members of the auxiliary police unit are forbidden from wearing side
arms while on duty.
(Res. 9-66. Passed 4-19-66.)
   (j)   Auxiliary 1 shall be those members who have not obtained State
certification from an Ohio Peace Officer Training Council.
   (k)   Auxiliary 2 shall be members who have successfully completed police
training from an Ohio Peace Officer Training Council.
   (l)   Auxiliary 2 officers shall be considered Law Enforcement Officers.
Auxiliary 2 officers may be permitted to carry sidearms at the direction of the
Chief of Police and enforce all laws and ordinances.
(Ord. 37-92. Passed 6-16-92.)
151.05 MAXIMUM AGE FOR ORIGINAL APPOINTMENT.
   Pursuant to Ohio R.C. 124.90(A) and Ohio R.C. 124.41 the City has waived
those maximum age requirements set forth in Ohio R.C. 124.41 for an original
appointment to the Police Department.
(Ord. 14-2005. Passed 7-5-05.)
151.06 VOLUNTEER PEACE OFFICERS’ DEPENDENTS FUND BOARD.
   (a)   City Council approves the establishment of a Voluntary Peace Officers’
Dependents Fund Board to administer benefits to qualifying City of Munroe Falls
volunteer reserve police officers injured or killed in the line of duty. The
Board shall be composed of five members elected pursuant to R.C. Chapter 143
and any subsequent amendments thereto. The Board shall organize and conduct all
business in the manner prescribed by R.C. Chapter 143. The Board shall at all
times be considered a public body subject to all applicable codified ordinances
of the City of Munroe Falls regarding meeting procedures and notice
requirements that are otherwise not in conflict with the Ohio Revised Code.
   (b)   The Finance Director is hereby authorized to appropriate, encumber,
and pay funds toward all premiums and basic capital contributions owed to the
VPODF for 2016 and each year thereafter as determined and required by R.C. §§
143.06 and 143.07.
(Ord. 2016-07. Passed 7-12-16.)
CHAPTER 153
Division of Fire
153.01   Reserved.
153.02   Department established;duties.
153.03   Maximum age for original appointment.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Composition; appointment and removal - see CHTR. Sec.
9.04
   Volunteer Firemen's Dependents Fund - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 146
   Fire protection contracts - see Ohio R.C. 307.05, 505.44, 717.02
   Schooling, buildings and equipment - see Ohio R.C. 715.05, 737.23 et seq.
153.01 RESERVED.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: This section has been reserved for future legislation.)
153.02 DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED; DUTIES.
   (a)   (1)   There is hereby created and established a Fire Department
consisting of full-time, part-time and volunteer firefighters. There shall be a
Fire Chief, one Assistant Fire Chief, three Captains, three Lieutenants and not
more than 32 firefighters. Of these forty officers and members, there shall be
appointed a Fire Marshal, one or more Fire Safety Inspectors and one Chaplain.
Full-time, part-time and volunteer firefighters may perform fire, rescue,
emergency medical services and/or other emergency services as described in the
rules and regulations of the Fire Department.
      (2)   There is hereby created and established within the Fire Department
the position of Medical Advisor and Assistant Medical Advisor. This position
shall be an unpaid position and included with liability insurance purchased by
the City.
   (b)   The members and officers of the Fire Department shall be appointed by
the Mayor with the advice and approval of Council and shall continue in office
until removed therefrom for causes and under the procedures and powers provided
for the removal of officers by the Charter. All members, excepting officers,
shall be appointed for a six-month probationary period. The Mayor shall confer
with the Fire Department concerning the qualifications of the proposed
officers.
   (c)   All individuals appointed to the Fire Department, except Medical
Advisor and Assistant Medical Advisor, shall pass a physical examination as
provided by the Ohio Revised Code, and the fee for such examination shall be
paid by the Municipality.
   (d)   The Fire Chief shall take charge and custody of all fire apparatus and
equipment and supervise the maintenance thereof so that the same shall be in
good order and condition and ready for use at all times. The Chief shall have
full control of the Fire Department and its members during all fires and
emergencies and he shall have such other and further duties as may be provided
by law.
   (e)   The Fire Chief shall facilitate the promotion of rural and urban fire
prevention and fire protection, provide programs of education through the
schools, industrial, commercial and civic bodies and shall act as an agent for
the promotion and correlation of fire prevention and protection campaigns.
   (f)   The Fire Chief at all reasonable hours shall enter into all buildings
and upon all premises and vehicles within the Municipality’s jurisdiction for
the purpose of examination and report substandard conditions to the State Fire
Marshal.
   (g)   The duties of the Assistant Fire Chief, Captains, Lieutenants and
other members of the Fire Department shall be established by the Fire
Department regulations and as further prescribed by the Fire Chief.
   (h)   The Fire Chief shall assemble the officers and firefighters for the
purpose of instruction and drill in the operation of the Fire Department and
shall maintain a Certified Public Safety Service’s Fire Instructor on the
roster of the Fire Department.
   (i)   The wages and salaries of the Fire Department shall be defined by
ordinance providing for the compensation, overtime, vacation and other benefits
for appointment of officers and employees of the Municipality, except for the
position of the Fire Department Medical Advisor and Assistant Medical Advisor
which is a non-compensated position.
(Ord. 09-00. Passed 4-4-00.)
153.03 MAXIMUM AGE FOR ORIGINAL APPOINTMENT.
   Pursuant to Ohio R.C. 124.90(A) and Ohio R.C. 124.42 the City has waived
those maximum age requirements set forth in Ohio R.C. 124.42 for an original
appointment to the Fire Department.
(Ord. 15-2005. Passed 7-5-05.)
