CHAPTER 155
Department of Engineering and Building
155.01   Established.
155.02   Personnel.
155.03   Duties.
155.04   Building Official; duties.
155.05   Scope.
155.06   Engineer.
155.07   Engineering Assistant.(Repealed)
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Engineer to approve plats; inspection of streets and acceptance - see Ohio
R.C. 711.08, 711.191
   To devise and form plan of sewerage - see Ohio R.C. 729.31 et seq.
   General duties - see Ohio R.C. 735.32
   Registration as a professional engineer - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 4733
155.01 ESTABLISHED.
   There is hereby established a Department of Engineering and Building that
shall include the following departments:
   (a)   Office;
   (b)   Engineering;
   (c)   Building structures but not including heating, ventilation and air-
conditioning, electrical, plumbing and sanitation;
   (d)   Heating, ventilating and air-conditioning;
   (e)   Electrical;
   (f)   Plumbing and Sanitation; and
   (g)   Sanitary Sewerage.
(Ord. 17-86. Passed 6-17-86.)
155.02 PERSONNEL.
   Personnel of the Department of Engineering and Building shall be:
   (a)   The personnel under “Office” shall be the Clerk-Treasurer and his/her
Deputy and Clerks;
   (b)   The personnel under “Engineering” shall be the Municipal Engineer who
shall be registered as a Professional Engineer and Surveyor pursuant to
requirements of the Ohio Revised Code and a surveyor.
   (c)   The personnel under “Building Structures” shall be the Engineer, who
shall be designated as the Building Official and Plans Examiner and Building
Inspector and his alternates, if any.
   (d)   The personnel under “Heating, Ventilating and Air-Conditioning” shall
be the Heating Inspector and assistants to the Heating Inspector, if any.
   (e)   The personnel under “Electrical” shall be the Electrical Inspector,
and the Assistant Electrical Inspector, if any.
   (f)   The plumbing inspection duties shall be carried out through the
appropriate agency of Summit County Government.
   (g)   The sanitary sewerage inspection duties shall be carried out through
the Summit County Department of Environmental Services which is responsible for
connections to the County controlled sanitary sewers and appurtenances thereto.
(Ord. 17-86. Passed 6-17-86.)
155.03 DUTIES.
   Duties of the personnel shall be as follows:
   (a)   Duties of personnel under “Office” shall be to accept and process
applications for permits, to accept fees for such applications, to issue
permits and to keep the records of all permits issued and monies collected,
except those mandated and administered by Summit County Government.
   (b)   Duties of personnel under “Engineering” shall be to:
      (1)   Develop plans, specifications and cost estimates for such Municipal
capital improvements and maintenance programs as may be required.
      (2)   Review bids for work to be done for the Municipality and to make
recommendations to the Mayor and Council for award of such contractual work.
      (3)   Review plans and development proposals for the stability of
structures, and compliance with applicable codes and ordinances as to
sanitation, energy conservation, means of egress, safety to life and property
from fire hazards incident to the design, construction, erection, alteration,
enlargement, repair, removal, moving, demolition, conversion, equipment use and
occupancy of builidings and structures proposed, and to make recommendations
and state requirements to the architect, engineer, contractor, or owner
responsible for the proposal and to the Planning Commission.
      (4)   Notify in writing the responsible architect, engineer, contractor
or owner of the approval or disapproval of plans and proposals with copies of
the approval or disapproval directed to the Planning Commission and the Clerk-
Treasurer.
      (5)   Administer contracts entered into by the Mayor for the improvement,
construction, erection, alteration, enlargement, repair, maintenance, removal,
moving, demolition or conversion of Municipal properties, buildings and
structures.
      (6)   Prepare and administer applications for such grants and funding
programs for which the Municipality may qualify.
      (7)   Perform the administrative functions as the head of the Department
of Engineering and Building.
   (c)   Duties of personnel under “Building Structures” shall be to:
      (1)   After approval of plans has been secured and a permit for
construction has been issued, the Building Official shall make the following
inspections:
         A.   After the excavation has been made and prior to the construction
of the footings.
         B.   After completion of the foundation walls and prior to framing of
the structure.
         C.   After the completion of the framing and prior to the enclosure of
the framing.
         D.   After completion of the structure and prior to occupancy.
         E.   Any other additional inspections deemed necessary during the
course of construction.
   (d)   Duties of the personnel under “Heating, Ventilating and Air-
Conditioning” shall be to enforce the applicable codes and rules adopted by the
Municipality.
   (e)   Duties of the personnel under “Electrical” shall be to enforce the
applicable codes and rules adopted by the Municipality.
   (f)   Duties of the personnel under “Plumbing” shall be to enforce the
applicable codes and rules of the Summit County Department of Environmental
Services, the Summit County Board of Health, the Municipality and any other
applicable rules, code or ordinance.
(Ord. 17-86. Passed 6-17-86.)
155.04 BUILDING OFFICIAL; DUTIES.
   (a)   The Municipal Engineer shall be designated, in addition, as the
Building Official. The Building Official shall have authority, in conjunction
with the Superintendent of Roads and Utilities to order the enforcement of all
laws, ordinances, and regulations relating to the construction, alteration and
repairs, removal, moving, demolition, equipment, use and occupancy, location
and maintenance of buildings, and structures except as may be otherwise
provided.
   (b)   He shall, when requested by the Mayor or when the interest of the
Municipality so requires, make investigations in connection with others, under
his jurisdiction, referred to in this chapter and order written reports on the
same for the purpose of enforcing compliance with the provisions of this
chapter and other pertinent laws and ordinances and regulations assigned to him
for enforcement. He shall issue such notices or orders as may be necessary.
   (c)   The Building Official shall have the right to enter upon any premises,
building or structure at any reasonable time in the performance of his duties
to make an inspection except that he shall not enter upon any premises,
building or structure in circumstances and under conditions that are in
violation of the Constitution or laws of the State or of the Constitution or
laws of the United States of America.
   (d)   No person shall obstruct or abuse the Building Official in the
performance of his duty.
   (e)   The Building Official shall identify himself when requested by
presenting reasonable and customary evidence that he bears on his person.
155.05 SCOPE.
   The requirements of this chapter are supplementary with the Zoning
Ordinance, Platting Ordinance, Ohio R.C. 733.80 and with any other pertinent
rule or ordinance adopted by the Municipality and are not to be construed as
being at variance with any provision of such codes and ordinances.
(Ord. 17-86. Passed 6-17-86.)
155.06 ENGINEER.
   (a)   The position of Engineer in the Department of Engineering and Building
is hereby created.
   (b)   The Engineer shall be a registered professional engineer pursuant to
the requirements of the Ohio Revised Code.
   (c)   The Engineer shall be the head of the Department of Engineering and
Building and shall be appointed and may be removed by the Mayor, subject to
confirmation by Council. The Mayor, shall in the case of suspension, demotion
or removal of the Engineer furnish such individual a copy of the order of
suspension, demotion, or removal. Such order shall be filed with the Clerk of
Council. Within ten days following the filing of such order, such individual
may file an appeal, in writing, with the Clerk of Council. In the event such an
appeal is filed, the Clerk of Council shall forthwith notify the Mayor and
Council shall hear such appeal within thirty days from and after its filing
with the Clerk of Council, and by a two-thirds vote, it may affirm, disaffirm,
or modify the judgment of the Mayor.
   (d)   The salary of the Engineer shall be established by the Mayor with the
confirmation of Council.
(Ord. 12-01. Passed 5-1-01.)
155.07 ENGINEERING ASSISTANT. (REPEALED)
   EDITOR'S NOTE: The position of Engineering Assistant was repealed by
Ordinance 14-92, passed March 3, 1992.
CHAPTER 157
Treasury Investment Board
157.01   Established; duties.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Deposit of public moneys - see Ohio R.C. 117.17
   Weekly deposit of sewer rental money - see Ohio R.C. 729.52
   Disposition of fines and fees collected by Mayor - see Ohio R.C. 733.40
   Weekly deposit of water works money - see Ohio R.C. 743.06
157.01 ESTABLISHED; DUTIES.
   (a)   There is hereby created the Treasury Investment Board which shall
consist of the Mayor, the Clerk/Treasurer, the Law Director and the Council
Finance Chairperson.
   (b)   The Treasury Investment Board shall have the authority to create and
modify an investment policy for the Municipality. The policy shall establish
investment objectives and guidelines; authorized financial institutions and
dealers; maturity schedules; prohibited and allowable investments;
collateralization guidelines; and record keeping requirements.
   (c)   The investment policy shall be reviewed at least annually by the
Treasury Investment Board and any changes shall be reported to the Council of
the City of Munroe Falls and to the Auditor of State.
   (d)   The investment policy shall be distributed to all authorized financial
institutions and dealers prior to any investment transaction with that
particular financial institution or dealer.
(Ord. 43-96. Passed 12-3-96.)
CHAPTER 161
Employees Generally
161.01   Overtime compensation.
161.02   Fringe benefits.
161.03   Equal opportunity.
161.04   P.E.R.S. pick-up.
161.05   Cafeteria plans.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Welfare - see Ohio Const., Art. II, Sec. 34
   Workers' compensation - see Ohio Const., Art. II, Sec. 35, Ohio R.C. Ch.
4123
   Deductions for municipal income tax - see Ohio R.C. 9.42
   Public Employees Retirement System - see Ohio R.C. 145
   Expenses for attendance at conference or convention - see Ohio R.C. 733.79
   Vacation credit - see Ohio R.C. 9.44
161.01 OVERTIME COMPENSATION.
   Overtime compensation for employees of the Municipality shall be as follows:
   (a)   (1)   When any employee, excepting all Department Heads, is required
by the City to work more than 40 hours in a standard work week, the employee
shall be paid overtime pay at the rate of one and one-half (1-1/2) times the
employee's regular hourly pay. Holidays recognized by City resolutions and
vacation days scheduled at least two weeks in advance shall be counted in
calculating hours worked in the standard work week for overtime purposes.
(Ord. 16-95. Passed 4-4-95; Ord. 2015-06. Passed 7-7-15.)
      (2)   When a full time employee, excepting Department Heads, works on a
designated holiday, such employee shall be paid at a rate two and one-half (2-
1/2) times the employee's regular rate of pay. This rate includes the
employee's regular rate for the holiday so that the employee is entitled to an
additional one and one-half (1-1/2) times that rate for the hours worked.
(Ord. 03-2003. Passed 1-21-03.)
   (b)   Overtime compensation shall be calculated after the end of the
employee's work week and shall be payable with the next following pay.
(Ord. 16-95. Passed 4-4-95.)
   (c)   Overtime compensation may be converted by an employee to compensatory
time at the overtime compensation rate of one and one-half (1-1/2) times the
employee's regular hourly pay. Compensatory time must be scheduled with the
Department Head in advance of the time off. The employee must make this
election within the pay period in which the overtime is accumulated. No
employee shall be permitted to accumulate compensatory time in excess of 180
hours. All compensatory time must be utilized within one year after it is
earned.
(Ord. 2015-06. Passed 7-7-15.)
161.02 FRINGE BENEFITS.
   The benefits provided by the Municipality shall be made available to
employees as specified below without regard to race, sex, age, or physical or
mental handicap as follows:
   (a)   Paid Holidays. All full-time, non-bargaining unit employees shall be
entitled to the following thirteen paid holidays:
1.   New Year’s Day
2.   Martin Luther King Day
3.   Presidents’ Day
4.   Memorial Day
5.   Juneteenth
6.   Independence Day
7.   Labor Day
8.   Columbus Day
9.   Veterans Day
10.   Thanksgiving Day
11.   Day after Thanksgiving
12.   Christmas Eve
13.   Christmas Day
 
      (1)   In the event that any of the above thirteen holidays falls on a
weekend, the City shall recognize the Friday before or the Monday after as the
designated holiday. Per City Ordinance 2016-10, the Mayor may issue a memo as
to the annual holiday schedule to be observed for full-time non-bargaining
employees.
      (2)   Those employees eligible for hospitalization insurance shall be
required to contribute towards said coverage 15% of the total premium on a
monthly basis.
      (3)   Personal Day; a full time employee shall be eligible to receive one
personal day, i.e., 8 hours time off (per year) with pay provided the employee
used less than twenty-five hours of sick leave in the prior calendar year. The
personal day shall be used in the year for which it is first eligible or it is
forfeited.
   (b)   Vacations. Full time employees shall be entitled to vacations with pay
based upon the term of employment, as follows:
 
Years of Employment    Week(s)
After 1                2
After 5                3
After 10 years service 4
After 20 years service 5
After 24 years service 6
 
      (1)   Each full time employee may elect to work during their scheduled
vacation period at a rate twice their regular rate of pay for the vacation
period. Such compensation shall be in lieu of any compensatory time off for
such vacation.
      (2)   When any full time employee is called into work during a scheduled
vacation period by an authorized administrative authority, the employee shall
be granted additional vacation time equal to the time for which the employee
was called into work. (Ord. 57-95. Passed 9-6-95.)
      (3)   Unused vacation for all full time employees, except those employees
working under a labor contract, shall be cumulative. The maximum cumulative
hours to be carried over from anniversary date to the next anniversary date are
200 hours. (Ord. 01-2007. Passed 1-16-07.)
      (4)   The Mayor may, in his or her discretion, authorize paid vacation
benefits not to exceed four weeks per year to department heads irrespective of
the employee’s service/longevity.
   (c)   Sick leave. Each full time employee shall be entitled to sick leave of
one and one-quarter days each month. Unused sick leave shall be cumulative up
to 2,080 hours.
      (1)   The Mayor may require that a satisfactory doctor's statement
verifying that the employee was unable to work be filed with the Clerk-
Treasurer.
      (2)   No part time employee of the Municipality shall be entitled to sick
leave benefits through this subsection or through Ohio R.C. 124.38 for hours
worked for the Municipality.
      (3)   Each full time employee with accumulated sick leave of 480 hours or
more, may elect to convert sick leave to vacation time at the rate of one hour
of vacation for every four hours of sick leave up to a maximum of 132 hours per
year. Each full time employee may exercise this conversion one time per year.
      (4)   Upon retirement, the first 960 hours of sick leave accumulated
shall be compensate at fifty percent (50%) and all hours over 960 shall be
compensated at twenty-five percent (25%).
      (5)   Bereavement Leave. Three days funeral leave will be given to each
full time employee in the event of the death of a spouse, child, parent,
parent-in-law, brother, sister or grandparent and one day funeral leave for
grandparents-in-law, brother-in-law, or sister-in- law.
         Proof of death must be submitted to qualify for bereavement pay. Any
additional time required may be allotted at the reasonable discretion of the
employer. Such time can be drawn from any employee's sick time or vacation time
available.
   (d)   Hospitalization Insurance.
      (1)   All Department Heads and full-time employees of the municipality
shall be provided with current hospitalization and a life insurance plan from
time of initial employment provided the employee requests such coverage. In
addition, if the employee, employee’s spouse and/or the employee’s dependent is
excluded from coverage because payment was made or would have been made under
Medicare Parts A or B if benefits were claimed, the municipality shall provide,
if requested, payment for the cost of a Medifil Contract.
      (2)   Employees who are not otherwise subject to a collective bargaining
agreement shall pay a portion of their medical insurance costs. An employee
shall pay for the first benefit year (i.e. October 1, 1994 through September
30, 1995) as follows:
         A.   Single person coverage $75.00 per annum.
         B.   Two person coverage $150.00 per annum.
         C.   Family coverage (i.e. three or more persons covered) $245.00 per
annum.
         D.   In addition, employees shall be responsible for twenty percent of
the medical insurance premium cost increase, if any, occurred on or after
October 1, 1995 with the following limits:
            1.   Single person coverage $200.00 per annum.
            2.   Two person coverage $400.00 per annum.
            3.   Family coverage (i.e. three or more person covered) $600.00
per annum.
      (3)   Full-time City employees eligible for receiving medical insurance
through the City’s then current medical insurance contract may, so long as the
employee is covered under another employer provided health benefit plan at the
time, decline health care benefits provided by the City. The employee shall
provide the City with documentation that the employee is covered through
another employer provided health plan and that said coverage is the reason for
declining enrollment in the City Plan.
      (4)   (EDITOR'S NOTE: Division (d)(4) of this section was repealed by
Ordinance 04-2010, passed August 17, 2010.)
   (e)   Leaves of Absence.
      (1)   Full time employees may be granted leaves of absences by the Mayor,
with the approval of Council. The period of absence shall not exceed six
months. At the end of the period granted, the leave of absence shall terminate
unless extended by the Mayor with Council's approval and upon such terms and
conditions and for such additional period of time as may be set by the Mayor
with the approval of Council.
      (2)   All employees who have worked for the City of Munroe Falls for one
year and for at least 1250 hours over the most recent calendar year shall be
entitled annually, up to twelve weeks of unpaid leave for the family and
medical reasons, described in the Federal Family and Medical Leave Act to wit:
         A.   The birth of a child or to care for a newborn child.
         B.   Adoption of a child.
         C.   To care for a spouse, child, parent or other family member with a
serious health condition.
         D.   The employee has a serious health condition which makes the
employee unable to perform his or her job function.
      (3)   Employees using the benefit provided by the Family and Medical
Leave Act shall be required to apply to said leave his or her available unused
paid sick leave. If the employees paid sick leave is extinguished the Mayor may
require the employee to use his or her accrued paid vacation towards this
family leave. Any time remaining in the twelve weeks provided by the Family and
Medical Leave Act, after the application of unused sick leave and vacation, if
any, shall be unpaid leave. Computations for the Family and Medical Leave Act
shall be on a calendar year basis.
(Ord. 57-95. Passed 9-6-95.)
   (f)   Coffee Service. (EDITOR’S NOTE: Former subsection (f) hereof was
repealed by Ordinance 03-2007.)
   (g)   Travel Expenses.
      (1)   Reimbursable expenses will include, but are not limited to mileage
allowance in an amount equal to the mileage allowance permitted by the Federal
Government on Federal Tax Returns, lodging expenses, registration expense, meal
expenses, common carrier ticket expense, baggage transfer expenses, travel
fare, tools, rental expenses, gratuities not exceeding fifteen percent (15%) of
meals, and taxes incurred on food, lodging or transportation.
      (2)   The Director of Finance shall establish the procedures for
reporting and documenting all such travel expenses and shall make provision for
advancing normal estimated expenses to employees of the Municipality for
authorized business travel expenses.
   (h)   Call Out. In the event that an employee of the Municipality, excepting
Department Heads, is required to report at any time for unscheduled service and
for which a special or an additional trip to the assigned place of employment
is required, the employee shall be compensated as follows:
      (1)   Deputy Clerks, which includes Deputy Clerk, Deputy Clerk (Road/
Utilities, Engineering) and Deputy Clerk (Police Department), shall be paid at
a rate one and one-half times the employee's regular rate of pay for a minimum
of three hours work. (Ord. 18-2002. Passed 7-2-02.)
      (2)   Non-bargaining employees in the Department of Roads and Utilities,
excepting the Superintendent of Roads and Utilities, shall be paid at a rate of
one and one half times the employee’s regular rate of pay for a minimum of
three hours work. (Ord. 2002-26. Passed 8-20-02.)
      (3)   An employee of the Fire Department of the City of Munroe Falls
qualifying for first responder/incident command call-out compensation shall be
paid for no less than two hours work for each call-out. An employee shall be
eligible for a call-out to serve as first responder/incident command only if
the Munroe Falls Fire Chief is unavailable to respond or will have a delayed
response to the incident and the employee is a first responder at the direction
of the Fire Chief. Only one employee shall be eligible for first responder/
incident command call out for any occurrence.
      (4)   An employee of the Fire Department of the City of Munroe Falls,
excepting the Fire Chief, shall be paid for no less than one hour of work at
his or her regular rate of pay for each call out other than first responder/
incident command call out.
   (i)   Uniform Allowance. A uniform allowance shall be provided to members of
the Police Department and Fire Department for the purchase and the maintenance
of uniforms as follows:
      (1)   Police Department - Auxiliary Police Officer. Each member of the
Auxiliary Police unit shall be given an annual uniform allowance of one hundred
fifty dollars ($150.00) payable in April. The uniform allowance shall be paid
to a member only if that member has completed 180 hours of service to the
Municipality within the Auxiliary Police Unit during the preceding calendar
year.
      (2)   Police Department - Chief. The Police Chief shall be reimbursed for
actual expenses up to a maximum of nine hundred seventy-five dollars ($975.00)
per calendar year. If the reimbursement is less than the designated amount in
each year, the difference shall be payable on the last pay in December.
      (3)   Fire Department - Chief and Assistant Chief. (full-time). The Fire
Chief and Assistant Chief shall be reimbursed for actual expenses up to a
maximum of nine hundred seventy- five dollars ($975.00) per calendar year. If
the reimbursement is less than the designated amount in each year, the
difference shall be payable on the last pay in December.
      (4)   Fire Department-Part Time. All officers and fire personnel in good
standing shall be given an initial uniform allowance as follows:
         A.   Fire personnel initial Uniform Allowance: Two hundred fifty
dollars ($250.00) one time only, payable after completion of a probation period
as established by the Fire Chief.
         B.   Fire personnel Annual Uniform Allowance: Three hundred dollars
($300.00) payable in January each year.
         C.   Fire Marshal Annual Uniform Allowance: Fifty dollars ($50.00)
additional payable in January each year.
         D.   Fire Division Chaplain Annual Uniform Allowance: Fifty dollars
($50.00) additional payable in January each year.
         E.   Captains additional Uniform Allowance: Fifty dollars ($50.00)
additional payable in January each year.
   (j)   Longevity.
      (1)   Beginning with the first pay period for the year 2000 all full-time
employees shall receive longevity pay for service time with the City of Munroe
Falls through the following schedule added to the employees’ base hourly pay.
         A.   Over 5 years of service - .10 cents per hour added to base pay
         B.   Over 10 years of service - .25 cents per hour added to base pay
         C.   Over 15 years of service - .40 per hour added to base pay
         D.   Over 20 years of service - .55 cents per hour added to base pay
      (2)   To compute this benefit, service time shall consist of all full-
time service within the City of Munroe Falls and fifty percent (50%) of all
part-time service years.
      (3)   Subsections (k)(1) and (2) apply to all full-time non-bargaining
unit employees.
   (k)   Payment of Wages During Periods of Inclement Weather. If, in the
opinion of the Mayor, inclement weather conditions exist whereby creating
hazardous and unsafe travel to work, the following policy specifies the
guidelines for payment of wages for nonbargaining unit employees on such
occasions:
      (1)   Scheduled employees who are able to come in to work on such
inclement days shall be paid at their regular wage for actual time worked.
Those employees who are not able to come in to work due to inclement weather
shall have the option of receiving an excused day off without pay or using
vacation time. Roads and Utilities employees are expected to come in to work at
their scheduled shift.
      (2)   Employees who actually report to work and are then sent home prior
to the end of their regular work shift due to inclement weather conditions will
receive payment for the remaining portion of their shift.
(Ord. 18-2002. Passed 7-2-02; Res. 04-2010. Passed 8-17-10; Ord. 09-2011.
Passed 10-18-11; Ord. 01-2012. Passed 2-21-12; Ord. 2014-03. Passed 9-16-14;
Ord. 2016-10. Passed 12-6-16; Ord. 2021-05. Passed 10-5-21.)
161.03 EQUAL OPPORTUNITY.
   (a)   It is the policy of the Municipality to assure that applicants are
employed and that employees are treated during their employment without regard
to their race, creed, color, handicaps, national origin, sex, political
affiliation or beliefs. Such policy is to apply in all personnel matters
including employee up-grading, promotion, transfer, recruitment, recruitment
activities, rates of pay, or other forms of compensation and selection for
training, including on-the-job training.
   (b)   The Municipality's equal employment opportunity policy will be
disseminated to all employees of the Municipality and permanently posted at the
usual posting places for ordinances and resolutions.
(Ord. 16-95. Passed 4-4-95.)
161.04 P.E.R.S. PICK-UP.
   (a)   Effective as of 12:01 a.m. of April 30, 1984, and subject to the
provisions of subsection (c) hereof, the full amount of the statutorily
required contributions to Public Employees Retirement Systems of Ohio shall be
withheld from the gross pay of each person and shall be “picked up” (assumed
and paid to the Public Employees Retirement Systems of Ohio) by the
Municipality.
      (1)   This “pick-up” by the Municipality commencing as of April 30, 1984,
is and shall be designated as, public employee contributions and shall be in
lieu of contributions to the Public Employees Retirement Systems of Ohio by
each person. No person subject to this “pick-up” shall have the option of
choosing to receive the statutorily required contribution to the Public
Employees Retirement Systems of Ohio directly instead of having it “picked up”
by the Municipality or of being excluded from the “pick-up”.
      (2)   The Municipality shall, in reporting and making remittance to the
Public Employees Retirement Systems of Ohio, report that the public employees
contribution for each person subject to this “pick-up” has been made as
provided by statute.
   (b) The “pick-up” by the Municipality as provided by this section shall
apply to all full time and part-time employees of the Municipality who are
contributing members of the Public Employees Retirement Systems.
   (c)   The gross wage or salary of any person subject to the “pick-up”
provided by this section shall not change as a result of this “pick-up”.
(Ord. 16-95. Passed 4-4-95; Ord. 18-00. Passed 6-20-00; Ord. 2015-05. Passed 7-
21-15.)
161.05 CAFETERIA PLANS.
   (a)   All municipal employees both full-time and part-time as well as
elected officials are hereby eligible to participate in any flexible benefit
plan commonly known as a cafeteria plan and recognized by the Federal Internal
Revenue Code. All premium costs for any benefit provided through the cafeteria
plan shall be paid by the employee or elected official and shall not be in
addition to any compensation received by the employee or elected official.
   (b)   It is not mandatory for a cafeteria plan to be put in place by the
City of Munroe Falls; nor is the participation of an employee or elected
official required.
(Ord. 54-95. Passed 8-15-95.)

      (4)   Schedule 4: Private Water Mains (EDITOR'S NOTE: Former subsection

      (5)   Schedule 5: Deposits:
         Any individual subscriber, except the owner of the property, shall be
required to deposit $150.00 with the Munroe Falls Water Department when
establishing new water service.
      (6)   Schedule 6: Water Taps:
         The property owner or his agent shall do all excavating and
compacting, grading, planning or paving to restore the property to its original
quality. Water taps, up to one inch in diameter, shall be made by the Water
Department and all materials furnished to the curb box. The fee for said taps
shall be one hundred and twenty-five dollars ($125.00) for labor and, in
addition, the cost of materials plus forty percent (40%).
         All taps larger than one inch shall be done by the owner or his agent
upon the approval of the Director of Public Service. All pipe fittings and
appurtenances shall be furnished and installed by the owner or his agent. All
installations of water services shall be inspected by the Water Department and
the fee for such inspection shall be fifty dollars ($50.00).
      (7)   Schedule 7: Water Meters:
         All apartment buildings converted into condominiums or condominiums
built after January 1, 1984, shall install one individual water meter for each
unit or individual dwelling. Total building master meters will not be allowed.
         Apartment type buildings with multiple units shall have one master
meter per structure, and each unit or apartment shall have its own shut off
valves for hot and cold water lines.
         All 3/4" by 5/8" water meters with an adapter, which permits the
reading of the meter from outside the building, shall be furnished and
installed in all new residential construction by the owner or his agent upon
the approval of the Director of Public Service and payment of an inspection fee
of forty dollars ($40.00).
      (8)   Schedule 8: Labor Charges and Miscellaneous:
         All labor, and equipment shall be reimbursed at City cost, as
determined by the Director of Public Services.
         All material and supplies shall be at cost plus forty percent ($40%).
      (9)   Schedule 9: Turn-Off and Turn-On Charges:
         There will be a twenty-five-dollar ($25.00) charge, added to the next
water bill, to off-set the cost of labor and transportation for the Water
Department to turn-off and turn-on any water service, at the request of the
resident or business, for the purpose of maintenance, alternation and/or
repair. This charge covers one turn-off and one turn-on per project or
emergency call during regular Water Department business hours.
         There will be a fifty-dollar ($50.00) charge, added to the next bill,
to off-set the cost of labor call-out and transportation to turn-off any water
service, at the request of the resident or business owner, in cases of
emergency that occur outside the Water Department's regular business hours.
This charge offsets the cost of the off-hours shut-off and one turn-on during
regular Water Department business hours. Turn-on requests outside the Water
Department's regular business hours will incur an additional fifty-dollar
($50.00) charge.
         There will be a fifty-dollar ($50.00) charge, added to the current
water billing, for any water service turn-on that is currently shut-off for
non-payment of water bill charges. This charge must be paid, along with the
amount owed for water use, prior to any water service turn-on.
   (j)   In the event the City is required to post on a residential or
commercial structure a final notice for water disconnection, there shall be
charged a twenty-five-dollar ($25.00) fee to cover the cost associated with the
hand delivery of the first final notice.

163.15 PERFORMANCE BOND DEPOSIT FEE FOR BUILDINGS.
   (a)   For Multi-Family Commercial and Industrial. Prior to the issuance of a
zoning permit, a performance bond shall be required in an amount equal to one
dollar ($1.00) per square foot of gross land area to be occupied by the
project.
      Such performance bond shall be approved by the Law Director. Upon
completion of constructions, one-half of the bond shall be released and the
remainder retained for a period of one year. The remainder shall insure the
construction standard.
   (b)   For One- and Two-Family Dwellings.
      (1)   Prior to the issuance of a building permit, a performance bond
shall be required to be deposited with the Director of Finance in an amount
equal to ten dollars ($10.00) for each front foot of the lot upon which such
permit applies.
      (2)    The performance bond shall insure:
         A.   Proper repair of damage suffered by City streets, curbs,
sidewalks, trees or other City property due to the permitted construction.
         B.   Proper installation of new sidewalks, downspout drains, curb
cuts, driveway approaches and trees when required.
      (3)   The Director of Finance shall return the performance bond to the
applicant, or the applicant's written designate, if all of the following apply:
         A.   A permanent dwelling occupancy permit has been issued for the
permitted construction.
         B.   New sidewalks, etc. have been properly constructed when required.
         C.   All damage to City streets, sidewalks, or other City property,
caused by permitted construction, has been properly repaired.
      (4)    If the Director of Finance is unable to return the performance
bond for any reason, then the Director of Finance shall give written
notification to the applicant, or the applicant's written designate, of the
reasons for the retention of such funds.
         A.   If any deficiencies are not corrected within thirty days of the
date of the aforementioned written notice, the Director of Finance may transfer
the performance bond into an appropriate account to reimburse the City for the
expense of performing those items the applicant failed to perform.
         B.   Unused transferred performance bond, if any, shall be returned to
the applicant or the applicant's written designate.
(Ord. 47-2003. Passed 12-2-03.)
163.16 APPLICATION FEE FOR CONDITIONAL ZONING USE.
   (a)   All applications to request a conditionally permitted use in any zoned
district shall be made to the Planning Commission in writing and on the forms
prescribed therefore, and shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable fee of sixty-
five dollars ($65.00). Any decision made by Planning Commission shall be by
motion following a public hearing held as required to review the request.
   (b)   In the event that Planning Commission finds it necessary to maintain a
strict record of review procedures, or when the Planning Commission will deem
it necessary to cause special studies, reports, hearings, etc. to be made, the
applicant shall bear all such direct and related costs.
(Ord. 47-2003. Passed 12-2-03.)
163.17 APPLICATION FEE FOR ZONING VARIANCE.
   (a)   All applications to appeal a zoning requirement by requesting
variances or exceptions to the Zoning Code shall be made to the Board of Zoning
Appeals in writing and on the forms prescribed therefor, and shall be
accompanied by a non-refundable fee of sixty-five dollars ($65.00). Every
decision of the Board of Zoning Appeals shall be by Motion, and shall contain a
full record of the findings of the Board of Zoning Appeals by case number under
one or another of the following headings: interpretations; exceptions;
variances; together with all documents pertaining thereto.
   (b)   In the event that the Board of Zoning Appeals finds it necessary to
draw upon any planning, legal, engineering, or any other expert testimony, such
fee shall be increased to an amount that will cover all additional expenses of
such expert testimony and or their reports.
(Ord. 47-2003. Passed 12-2-03.)
163.18 APPLICATION FEE FOR ZONING AMENDMENT.
   (a)   All applications to request an amendment to the Zoning Code shall be
made to the Planning Commission in writing and on the forms prescribed
therefor, and shall be accompanied by a non-refundable fee of one hundred
twenty dollars ($120.00).
   (b)    The fee shall offset the City's costs for:
      (1)    Legal advertisement
      (2)    Required Mailings
      (3)   Updating maps and/or the Zoning Code.
(Ord. 47-2003. Passed 12-2-03.)

case shall such fee be less than one hundred dollars ($100.00).

163.21 AMBULANCE SERVICE FEES.
   (a)   Each person receiving emergency medical service from the City shall
pay a utilization charge therefore determined as follows:
      (1)   The Medical utilization fee for each response by the City to a call
for emergency medical services charged shall be as follows:
         A.   For Basic Life Support (BLS) services with transport, the fee
shall be six hundred dollars ($600.00).
         B.   For Advanced Life Support (ALS1) services with transport, the fee
shall be seven hundred dollars ($700.00).
         C.   For Advanced Life Support 2 (ALS2) services, the fee shall be
eight hundred fifty dollars ($850.00).
      (2)   Transportation fee per mile to a medical facility shall be fifteen
dollars ($15.00).
      (3)   Other.
         A.   All individuals, who receive the services listed above, or those
financially responsible for those individuals, will be charged the fees
corresponding to the services provided.
         B.   Residents (and their dependents) will be charged the fees
corresponding to the services provided. However, any balance due from these
individuals above their insurance coverage will be waived after all covered
expenses have been paid the City of Munroe Falls.
      (4)   Non-emergency call-outs. Any individual with more than two EMS
call-outs in any calendar year that are deemed to be non-emergency events by
the Fire Chief, in consultation with the Medical Director, shall be charged
$200.00 per call-out. This fee will be assessed to the individual who calls
dispatch requesting EMS services.
      (5)   Refusal of transport. Any individual who refuses transport against
the advice of the EMS personnel responding to the call-out shall be assessed a
fee of $350.00 per call-out. This fee will be assessed to the individual who
calls dispatch requesting EMS services.
   (b)   The user fees established herein shall be collected, and upon receipt
thereof, shall be credited to the Emergency Medical Services Fund as an offset
to the cost of providing the Fire Department service for which the fee is being
charged.
   (c)   The fees established in the subsection shall be levied beginning on
August 19, 2003. In the event conditions, policies and practices in the health
care field change and are impacted by Medicare, then the higher rates between
the City and Medicare shall apply.
(Ord. 29-2003. Passed 8-5-03; Ord. 07-08. Passed 7-1-08; Ord. 2014-05. Passed
11-4-14; Ord. 2015-08. Passed 11-17-15; Ord. 2016-06. Passed 7-19-16; Ord.
2023-05. Passed 12-19-23.)

163.24 STORM SEWER PREVENTATIVE MAINTENANCE AND OPERATION FEES.
   (a)   The following fees shall be charged to the owners of property within
the City limits of Munroe Falls, Ohio.
      (1)   Effective as of the September 2024 billing cycle there is hereby
levied and imposed the following fees shall apply to all zoning lots and tracks
within the corporate limits of the City of Munroe Falls, except as may be
altered by credits or exemptions recommended by the City Engineer and approved
by City Council.
         A.   Residential property, including single-family, two-family, three-
family homes and condominiums, except condominiums having units on multiple
stories, shall be billed as follows:
 
Single-Family 1 ERU ("equivalent rate unit")
Two-Family    2 ERUs
Three-Family  3 ERUs
Condominium   1 ERU per unit
 
         B.   Non-residential property, including all other properties
including commercial, industrial, schools, churches, governmental, apartments,
and condominiums having units on multiple stories, shall be billed by dividing
the total impervious area of the parcel by three thousand (3,000) square feet
to determine the total ERUs to charge. The minimum fee shall be one (1) ERU.
         C.   There will be no service fee for parcels of land with fewer than
two hundred (200) square feet of impervious surface area.
         D.   The monthly service charge per equivalent rate unit for
residential property shall be six dollars ($6.00) and the equivalent rate unit
for non-residential property shall be six dollars ($6.00) per ERU.
         E.   Effective on January 1, 2025, the monthly service charge per
equivalent rate unit shall increase by ten cents ($0.10) on the first of every
January and each year thereafter.
         F.   For non-residential properties ERU's the calculated ERU's will be
charged as follows:
            The minimum fee shall be one (1) ERU.
            Effective as of the September 2024 billing cycle through December
31, 2025, 25% of the calculated ERU's.
            Effective January 1, 2026, 50% of the calculated ERU's.
            Effective January 1, 2027, and thereafter, the total calculated
ERU's.
            1.   The charges established shall be billed on a monthly basis and
shall appear on the utility bill rendered by the City as a separate line item
from water and shall be considered an integral part of such bill.
            2.   A late fee of 10% shall be added to accounts that remain
unpaid after the specified due date.
            3.   Accounts that remain delinquent after ninety (90) days shall
be recorded with the Summit County Fiscal Office as a lien on the subject
parcel(s). A notice of the proposed lien will be sent to the property owner of
the subject parcel(s).
            4.   An additional administrative fee of twenty-five dollars
($25.00) will be assessed on all accounts recorded as a lien with the Summit
County Fiscal Office.
(Ord. 19-2007. Passed 10-2-07; Ord. 2024-04. Passed 8-6-24.)

CHAPTER 164
Public Records Policy
164.01   Scope.
164.02   Fees.
164.03   Availability.
164.04   Public records requests.
164.05   Response and denials.
164.06   Remedy.
164.07   Training and education.
164.01 SCOPE.
   (a)   Each office, department, or function that maintains records has a
designated employee who serves as the custodian of all records maintained by
the office, department, or function.
      (1)   Each record custodian has a copy of the City of Munroe Falls public
records policy.
   (b)   The City’s public record policy, as well as the Schedules of Records
Retention and disposition (RC-2) are located at every location in which the
public may access the City’s records.
   (c)   The City public records policy is located in the Codified Ordinances.
   (d)   The City displays a poster which generally describes the City's public
records policy at every location in which the public may access the City's
records.
(Ord. 08-2009. Passed 5-19-09.)
164.02 FEES.
   (a)   The City, in accordance with Ohio R.C. 149.43, has established in
Section 163.01 of these Codified Ordinances, fees for providing copies or
reproductions of public records maintained by the City.
(Ord. 08-2009. Passed 5-19-09.)
164.03 AVAILABILITY.
   (a)   All public records, as well as a copy of the current records retention
schedule maintained by the City shall be promptly prepared and made available
for inspection to any person during regular business hours. Promptness is to be
determined by the facts and circumstances of each public records request.
Regular business hours for the City are Monday through Friday (except
holidays), from 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m.
   (b)   For the purpose of enhancing the ability of the City to identify,
provide for prompt inspection, as well as provide copies of the requested items
in a reasonable period of time, the City shall provide to the requester a
Public Records Request Form for the requester to complete.
      (1)   Prompt inspection and copies of records within a reasonable amount
of time contemplates the opportunity for legal review.
      (2)   Although the City may ask the requester to make the request in
writing, for the requestor's identity, and may inquire about the intended use
of the information requested, the requester shall be advised that:
         A.   The requests are not mandatory; and
         B.   The requestor's refusal to complete the public records request
form does not impair the requestor's right to inspect and/or receive copies of
the public records.
      (3)   Any person, including corporations, individuals, and even
governmental agencies, may request public records, and will be allowed prompt
inspection of public records and copies within a reasonable amount of time upon
request.
   (c)   In the event a request is made to inspect and/or obtain a copy of a
record maintained by the City whose release may be prohibited or exempted by
either State or Federal law, the request shall be forwarded to legal counsel
for the City for research and/or review. The person submitting the request
shall be advised that their request is being reviewed by legal counsel to
ensure that protected and/or exempted information is not improperly released by
the City.
   (d)   Records whose release is prohibited or exempted by either State or
Federal law, or not considered public records as defined by R.C. 149.43(A)(1),
shall not be subject to public inspection. The following represents a partial
list of records maintained by the City that may not be inspected or copied:
      (1)   Medical records;
      (2)   Trial preparation records;
      (3)   Records containing information that is confidential under Ohio R.C.
2710.03 or 4112.05;
      (4)   Peace officer, firefighter, or EMT residential and familial
information;
      (5)   Information pertaining to the recreational activities of a person
under the age of 18;
      (6)   Records the release of which is prohibited by State or Federal law;
      (7)   Confidential law enforcement investigatory records meaning any
record that pertains to a law enforcement matter of a criminal, quasi-criminal,
civil, or administrative nature, but only to the extent that the release of the
record would create a high probability of disclosure of any of the following:
         A.   The identity of a suspect who has not been charged with the
offense to which the record pertains, or of an information source or witness to
whom confidentiality has been reasonably promised;
         B.   Information provided by an information source or witness to whom
confidentiality has been reasonably promised, which information would
reasonably tend to disclose the source's or witness's identity;
         C.   Specific confidential investigatory techniques or procedures or
specific investigatory work produce;
         D.   Information that would endanger the life or physical safety of
law enforcement personnel, a crime victim, a witness, or a confidential
information source.
(Ord. 08-2009. Passed 5-19-09.)
Statutory reference:
   Availability of public records for inspection and copying, see Ohio R.C.
149.43
164.04 PUBLIC RECORDS REQUESTS.
   (a)   Mailed Requests for Public Records.
      (1)   Upon receiving a written request for copies of a public record made
in accordance with Ohio R.C. 149.43 via the United States Postal Service, the
City shall promptly respond to the request.
      (2)   An authorized employee of the City shall, by any means practical,
contact the requestor and advise them that advance payment is required prior to
providing copies of public records, and, in addition, the fee shall also
include the cost of postage and the envelope.
      (3)   When practical, the City may forward copied records by any other
means reasonably acceptable to the requestor.
         A.   If a person requests a copy of a public record, the City shall
permit the requestor to choose to have the public record duplicated on paper or
upon the same medium upon which the City maintains the public record or upon
any other medium on which the record can reasonably be duplicated as an
integral part of the normal operations of the City, or the responsible City
employee for the public record.
      (4)   Persons seeking copies of public records are not permitted to make
their own copies of the requested records by any means. In accordance with Ohio
R.C. 149.43(B)(7), the City limits the number of requested public records, to
be transmitted through the U.S. Mail, to a maximum of ten records per month,
unless the requestor certifies that the records or information in them will not
be used for commercial purposes.
         A.   "Commercial purposes" shall be narrowly construed and does not
include reporting or gathering news, reporting or gathering information to
assist citizen oversight or understanding of the operation or activities of
government, or nonprofit educational research.
      (5)   Authorized City employees shall comply with the following
procedures upon receiving a valid public record request through the United
States Postal System:
         A.   City employees shall promptly process requests.
            1.   Requestors shall be charged the postage fees required to
properly send the requested records through the mail.
   (b)   Written or verbal requests for copies made by the public records
requester or their designee shall be processed in the same manner as mailed
requests.
Statutory reference:
   Availability of public records for inspection and copying, see Ohio R.C.
149.43
164.05 RESPONSE AND DENIALS.
   (a)   Requests for inspection and/or copies of public records, which are not
maintained by the City shall be processed in the following manner:
      (1)   If the City receives a request for a record that it does not
maintain or the request is for a record which is no longer maintained, the
requestor shall be so notified in writing utilizing the notice of denial or
redaction form that one of the following applies:
         A.   Their request involves records that have never been maintained by
the City;
         B.   Their request involves records that are no longer maintained or
have been disposed of or transferred pursuant to applicable Schedules of Record
Retention and Disposition (RC-2);
         C.   Their request involves a record that has been disposed of
pursuant to an application of the One-Time Records Disposal (RC-1);
         D.   If the record that is requested is not a record used or
maintained by the City, the requestor shall be notified that in accordance with
Ohio R.C. Section 149.40, that the City is under no obligation to create
records to meet public record requests.
   (b)   Ambiguous or Overly Broad Request for Public Records. If a requestor
makes an ambiguous or overly broad request or has difficulty in making a
request for copies or inspection of public records such that the City staff
member responsible for the requested public record cannot reasonably identify
what public records are being requested:
      (1)   The City may deny the request;
      (2)   However, the City shall provide the requestor with an opportunity
to revise the request by informing the requestor of the manner in which records
are maintained by the City in the ordinary course of business.
   (c)   Denial of a Record Maintained by the City. The City may deny request
for a record maintained by the City if:
      (1)   The record that is requested is prohibited from release due to
applicable State or Federal law.
         A.   Employees of the City shall consult legal counsel if they are
unsure of whether the record requested should be withheld from disclosure.
            1.   Employees may check the appropriate box on the notice of
denial or redaction form if they are simply applying the statutory exclusion.
            2.   Otherwise, legal counsel will respond with the legal authority
for a denial.
      (2)   As governed by Ohio R.C. 149.43(B)(3), if a request is ultimately
denied, in part or in whole, the City shall provide the requestor with an
explanation, including legal authority, setting forth why the request was
denied.
         A.   If the initial request was provided in writing, then the
explanation shall also be provided in writing.
         B.   The explanation shall not preclude the City from relying upon
additional reasons or legal authority in defending an action commenced pursuant
to R.C. 149.43.
   (d)   Redacting Exempted Records/Procedure.
      (1)   "Redaction" means obscuring or deleting any information that is
exempt from the duty to permit public inspection or copying from an item that
otherwise meets the definition of a "record" in Ohio R.C. 149.011.
         A.   A redaction shall be deemed a denial of a request to inspect or
copy the redacted information, except if Federal or State law authorizes or
requires a public office to make the redaction.
         B.   If a request is ultimately denied, in part or in whole, the City
of Munroe Falls shall provide the requestor with an explanation, including
legal authority, setting forth why the request was denied.
      (2)   If a public record contains certain information that is exempt from
the duty to permit public inspection or to copy the public record, the City
shall make available of the information within the public record that is not
exempt.
      (3)   When making the public record available for public inspection or
copying that public record, the City shall notify the requestor of any
redaction or make the redaction plainly visible.
      (4)   The releasing employee shall then reproduce a copy of the page with
the redactions, the resulting copy shall be the page that is released to the
requestor.
      (5)   The first reproduction page with the original redactions made by
the employee is the work sheet. It shall be attached to the original record,
and maintained in accordance with the retention period established for the
original document.
(Ord. 08-2009. Passed 5-19-09.)
Statutory reference:
   Availability of public records for inspection and copying, see Ohio R.C.
149.43
164.06 REMEDY.
   (a)   Grievances.
      (1)   If a person allegedly is aggrieved due to the inability to inspect
a public record or due to the inability to receive a copy of the public record,
the person shall be advised that they may:
         A.   Contact the Law Director.
         B.   If the person is not satisfied after contacting the Law Director
they shall be advised that Ohio R.C. 149.43, provides a legal means for
addressing their complaint in these disputes.
(Ord. 08-2009. Passed 5-19-09.)
Statutory reference:
   Availability of public records for inspection and copying, see Ohio R.C.
149.43
164.07 TRAINING AND EDUCATION.
   The City continues to update and address all education, training,
disclosure, and policy requirements mandated by Ohio R.C. 109.43 and Ohio R.C.
143.43(E)(1)(2).
(Ord. 08-2009. Passed 5-19-09.)
CHAPTER 165
Campaign Finance
165.10   Definitions.
165.11   Limits on non-cash monetary and in-kind contributions and loans.
165.12   Limits on cash contributions.
165.99   Penalties.
165.10   DEFINITIONS.
   For the purposes of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning:
   (a)   “Anything of value” means:
      (1)   Money, bank bills or notes, United States Treasury Notes, and other
bills, bonds or notes issued by lawful authority and intended to pass and
circulate as money;
      (2)   Goods and chattels;
      (3)   Promissory notes, bills of exchange, orders, drafts, warrants,
checks or bonds given for the payment of money;
      (4)   Receipts given for the payment of money or other property;
      (5)   Rights in action;
      (6)   Things which savor of the realty and are, at the time they are
taken, a part of the freehold, whether they are of the substance or produce
thereof or affixed thereto, although there may be no interval between the
severing and taking away;
      (7)   Any interest in realty, including fee simple and partial interests,
present and future, contingent or vested interest, beneficial interests,
leasehold interests and any other interest in realty;
      (8)   Any promise of future employment;
      (9)   Every other thing of value.
   (b)   “Campaign committee” means a candidate or a combination of two or more
persons authorized by a candidate under Ohio R.C. 3517.081 to receive
contributions and make expenditures.
   (c)   “Candidate” means any qualified person certified in accordance with
the provisions of the Revised Code for placement on the official ballot of an
election to be held in the City, or any qualified person who represents himself
to be a write-in candidate, or who knowingly assents to such representation by
another at an election to be held in the City or any person who, at any time
before or after an election, receives contributions or makes expenditures or
other use of contributions, has given consent for another to receive
contributions or make expenditures or other use of contributions, or appoints a
campaign treasurer, for the purpose of bringing about his nomination or
election as Mayor or a member of City Council in the City.
   (d)   “Contribution.”
      (1)   Means a loan, gift, deposit, forgiveness of indebtedness, donation,
advance, payment, transfer of funds, in-kind contribution or transfer of
anything of value, and the payment by any person other than the person to whom
the services are rendered, which contribution is made, received or used for the
purpose of influencing the results of an election.
      (2)   “Contribution” does not include:
         A.   Services provided without compensation by individuals
volunteering a portion or all of their time on behalf of a person;
         B.   Ordinary home hospitality;
         C.   The personal expenses of a volunteer paid for by that volunteer
campaign worker;
         D.   The personal expenses of a candidate paid for by the candidate
from the candidate's personal funds;
         E.   An expenditure by a political action committee if the purpose of
the expenditure is to inform only its members by means of mailed publications
of its activities or endorsements;
         F.   An expenditure by a political party if the primary purpose of the
expenditure is to inform the public by means of mailed publications or other
direct communication of its activities or endorsements, or for voter contact
such as sample ballots, absentee voter ballots application mailings, voter
registration or get-out-the-vote activities.
   (e)   “Election period communication” means any communication to the public,
whether by printed, electronic or telephonic means, that refers to a municipal
candidate by the candidate's name or contains the candidate's image, likeness
or voice, at any time beginning 45 days prior to the election through the day
of the election at which the candidate appears on the ballot. The preceding
shall apply, regardless of whether the communication contains words expressly
advocating support of or opposition to a candidate, including educational and
informational communications, endorsements and encouragements to vote.
   (f)   “In-kind contribution” means anything of value other than money that
is used to influence the results of an election or is transferred to or used in
support of or in opposition to a candidate, campaign committee, legislative
campaign fund, political party, or political action committee or political
contributing entity and that is made with the consent of, in coordination,
cooperation, or consultation with, or at the request or suggestion of the
benefited candidate, committee, fund, party or entity. The financing of the
dissemination, distribution or republication, in whole or part, of any
broadcast or of any written, graphic or other form of campaign materials
prepared by the candidate, the candidate's campaign committee or their
authorized agents is an “in-kind contribution” to the candidate and expenditure
by the candidate. “In-kind contribution” shall not include items or services
provided by a State political party for direct mail purposes.
   (g)   “Municipal candidate” means any candidate at an election for
nomination or election to an office of the City of Munroe Falls or who has
filed a declaration of candidacy or intent to run as a write-in candidate.
   (h)   “Political action committee” means a combination of two or more
persons, the primary or incidental purpose of which is to support or oppose any
candidate, political party or issue, or to influence the result of any
election, and that is not a political party, a campaign committee or a
legislative campaign fund.
   (i)   “Political party” means any group of voters meeting the requirements
set forth in Ohio R.C. 3517.01 for the formation and existence of a political
party. The definitions set forth in Ohio R.C. 3517.01 shall apply to this
subchapter and Charter Section 5 except to the extent modified in this section.
(Ord. 09-2009. Passsed 11-3-09.)
165.11   LIMITS ON NON-CASH MONETARY AND IN-KIND CONTRIBUTIONS AND LOANS.
   (a)   No candidate for Mayor shall accept or solicit, as a non-cash monetary
(i.e., checks, money orders, credit cards) or in-kind campaign contribution or
loan, more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) from any person, campaign
committee, political party or political action committee.
   (b)   No candidate for a Council position shall accept or solicit, as a non-
cash monetary or in-kind campaign contribution or loan, more than one hundred
dollars ($100.00) from any person, campaign committee, political party or
political action committee.
   (c)   No person, political action committee, political party or political
campaign shall contribute funds or in-kind contributions in excess of said
amounts.
   (d)   Contributions from the candidate and labor of volunteers are exempt
from these provisions.
   (e)   The contributions set forth in this section shall be per election.
(Ord. 2009-24. Passed 11-3-09.)
165.12   LIMITS ON CASH CONTRIBUTIONS.
   (a)   No candidate for Mayor or City Council shall accept, as a campaign
contribution, more than fifty dollars ($50.00) in cash (i.e., hard currency)
from any person.
   (b)   No person shall contribute cash in excess of said amount.
   (c)   The contributions set forth in this section shall be per election.
(Ord. 2009-24. Passed 11-3-09; Ord. 2020-02. Passed 6-16-20.)
165.99   PENALTIES.
   (a)   In addition to any penalties applicable under state law, the following
penalties apply to contribution limits under sections of this code:
      (1)   For a contribution in excess of the limits in Sections
165.11 and
165.12, the candidate shall pay the City General Fund three dollars ($3.00) for
every dollar accepted in excess of the limit, unless the excess is completely
refunded within ten business days after notification to the recipient of the
contribution that a contribution in excess of the permitted amount had been
received.
      (2)   For intentional or persistent violations of contribution limits, a
candidate shall pay the City General Fund five hundred dollars ($500.00) or
five times the amount accepted in excess of the limit, whichever is greater.
   (b)   No person shall knowingly fail to file or file a false report required
under this chapter. A violation of this chapter is a misdemeanor of the first
degree.
   (c)   Enforcement. Suspected violations of this chapter shall be submitted
to the Clerk of Council, who shall transmit such information to the Director of
Law, who shall investigate the claim and enforce the provisions of this
chapter.
(Ord. 09-2009. Passed 11-3-09; Ord. 2020-02. Passed 6-16-20.)
TITLE SEVEN - Judicial
         
Chap. 171.   Mayor's Court
CHAPTER 171
Mayor's Court
EDITOR'S NOTE: The Mayor has jurisdiction to hear and determine any prosecution
for the violation of a Municipal ordinance, and has jurisdiction in all
criminal causes involving moving traffic violations occurring on State highways
located within the corporate limits, subject to the right of the defendant to
trial by jury and before an impartial magistrate.
   Ohio R.C. 2945.17 provides that an accused has a right to be tried by a jury
at any trial in any court for the violation of any Ohio statute or of any
Municipal ordinance, except in cases in which the penalty involved does not
exceed a fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00). Ohio R.C. 2937.08 and Criminal
Rule 23(A) provide that if the court in which a defendant is charged with an
offense is not a court of record (the Mayor's Court), and the charge is such
that a right to a jury trial exists, such matter shall not be tried before him
and shall be transferred to a court of record in the County if the defendant:
   (a)   Does not waive his right to trial by jury in a serious offense case
for which the penalty established by laws includes confinement for more than
six months, or
   (b)   Demands a jury trial in a petty offense case in which the penalty
prescribed is a fine greater than one hundred dollars ($100.00) and/or
imprisonment for not more than six months. “Such demand must be in writing and
filed with the clerk of court not less than ten days prior to the date set for
trial, or on or before the third day following receipt of notice of the date
set for trial, whichever is later. Failure to demand a jury trial as provided
in this subdivision is a complete waiver of the right thereto.”
      In Ward v. Village of Monroeville, Ohio, 93 S. Ct. 80 (1972), the United
States Supreme Court held that where the mayor before whom the defendant was
compelled to stand trial was responsible for municipal finances and the mayor's
court provided a substantial portion of municipal revenues, defendant was
denied a trial before a disinterested and impartial magistrate as guaranteed by
the due process clause of the United States Constitution.
   The Supreme Court of Ohio has adopted the “Ohio Traffic Rules” which
prescribe the procedure to be followed in the Mayor's Court in traffic cases.
Rule 9(A) thereof states the jury demand shall be made pursuant to Criminal
Rule 23 referred to above. Rule 9(B) sets forth the conditions under which the
Mayor may hear a traffic case incorporating therein the holding in Ward v.
Village of Monroeville as further interpreted in State, ex rel. Brockman v.
Procter, 35 Ohio St. 2d 79 (1973): “Where, in a mayor's court, a defendant is
entitled to a jury trial and a jury demand is made pursuant to Criminal Rule
23, the Mayor shall transfer the case pursuant to subdivision (C). If a jury
demand is not made pursuant to Criminal Rule 23, and (or?) the defendant waives
his right to jury trial in writing, a mayor may try the case if (1) his
compensation as a judge is not directly dependent upon criminal case
convictions, or (2) he is not the chief executive and administrative officer of
the municipality and as such responsible for the financial condition of the
municipality. Guilty and no contest pleas may be taken by any mayor including
mayors whose compensation as a judge is directly dependent upon criminal case
convictions and mayors who as chief executive and administrative officer of the
municipality are responsible for the financial condition of the municipality.”
   The procedure for transferring a case to a court of record is set forth in
Rule 9(C): “Where a transfer is required, the Mayor's Court shall make a
written order directing the defendant to appear at the transferee court,
continuing the same bail, if any, and making appearance before the transferee
court a condition of bail, if any. Upon transfer, the mayor's court shall
transmit to the clerk of the transferee court the ticket and all other papers
in the case, and any bail taken in the case. Upon receipt of such papers the
clerk of the transferee court shall set the case for trial and shall notify the
defendant by ordinary mail of his trial date.”
   Rule 13 provides that a court shall establish a traffic violation bureau and
specifies certain restrictions as to the designated offenses and schedule of
fines to be accepted as waiver payment in lieu of court appearance.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Disposition of fines and costs - see Ohio R.C. 733.40
   Mayor's powers and duties - see Ohio R.C. 1905.20 et seq.
   Trial - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 2938
   Notification to Director of liquor law convictions - see Ohio R.C. 4301.991
   Record of traffic violations - see Ohio R.C. 4513.37

181.01 AUTHORITY TO LEVY TAX: PURPOSES OF TAX; RATE.
181.011 AUTHORITY TO LEVY TAX.
   (a)   The tax on income and the withholding tax established by this Chapter
181 are authorized by Article XVIII, Section 3 of the Ohio Constitution. The
tax on income and the withholding tax established by this Chapter 181 are
deemed to be levied in accordance with, and to be consistent with, the
provisions and limitations of Ohio Revised Code 718 (Ohio R.C. Chapter 718).
This chapter is deemed to incorporate the provisions of Ohio R.C. Chapter 718.
   (b)   The tax is an annual tax levied on the income of every person residing
in or earning or receiving income in the municipal corporation, and shall be
measured by municipal taxable income. The Municipality shall tax income at a
uniform rate. The tax is levied on municipal taxable income, as defined herein.
(Ord. 2015-11. Passed 2-2-16.)
Statutory reference:
   Authority to tax income and withhold tax, see Ohio R.C. 718.04
181.012 PURPOSES OF TAX; RATE.
   (a)   The purpose of this tax is for general municipal operations,
maintenance, new equipment services, facilities, and capital improvements.
   (b)   Tax rate: two percent (2.0%), effective January 1, 2017 through
December 31, 2017; two and one-quarter percent (2.25%), effective January 1,
2018.
(Ord. 2015-11. Passed 2-2-16; Ord. 2017-03. Passed 1-19-17.)
Statutory reference:
   Authority to tax income and withhold tax, see Ohio R.C. 718.04
181.013 ALLOCATION OF FUNDS.
   The funds collected pursuant to this tax shall be allocated in accordance
with the allocation policy as amended from time to time by City Council.
(Ord. 2015-11. Passed 2-2-16.)
181.014 STATEMENT OF PROCEDURAL HISTORY; STATE MANDATED CHANGES TO MUNICIPAL
INCOME TAX.
   (a)   Significant and wide-ranging amendments to Ohio R.C. Chapter 718 were
enacted by Am. Sub. H.B. 5, passed by the 130th General Assembly, and signed by
Governor Kasich on December 19, 2014, and H.B. 5 required municipal
corporations to conform to and adopt the provisions of Ohio R.C. Chapter 718 in
order to have the authority to impose, enforce, administer and collect a
municipal income tax.
   (b)   As mandated by H.B. 5, municipal income tax Ordinance 2015-11,
effective January 1, 2016, comprehensively amends Chapter 181 in accordance
with the provisions of Ohio R.C. Chapter 718 to allow the Municipality to
continue the income tax and withholding tax administration and collection
efforts on behalf of the Municipality.
(Ord. 2015-11. Passed 2-2-16.)
181.02 EFFECTIVE DATE.
   (a)   Ordinance 2015-11, effective January 1, 2016, and corresponding
changes to Ohio R.C. Chapter 718, apply to municipal taxable years beginning on
or after January 1, 2016. All provisions of this Chapter 181 apply to taxable
years beginning 2016 and succeeding taxable years.
   (b)   Ordinance 2015-11 does not repeal the existing sections of Chapter 181
for any taxable year prior to 2016, but rather amends Chapter 181 effective
January 1, 2016. For municipal taxable years beginning before January 1, 2016,
the Municipality shall continue to administer, audit, and enforce the income
tax of the Municipality under Ohio R.C. Chapter 718 and ordinances and
resolutions of the Municipality as that chapter and those ordinances and
resolutions existed before January 1, 2016.
(Ord. 2015-11. Passed 2-2-16.)
Statutory reference:
   Related provisions, see Ohio R.C. 718.04
181.03 DEFINITIONS.
   (a)   Any term used in this chapter that is not otherwise defined in this
chapter has the same meaning as when used in a comparable context in laws of
the United States relating to Federal income taxation or in Ohio R.C. Title
LVII, unless a different meaning is clearly required. If a term used in this
chapter that is not otherwise defined in this chapter is used in a comparable
context in both the laws of the United States relating to Federal income tax
and in Ohio R.C. Title LVII and the use is not consistent, then the use of the
term in the laws of the United States relating to Federal income tax shall
control over the use of the term in Ohio R.C. Title LVII.
   (b)   For purposes of this section, the singular shall include the plural,
and the masculine shall include the feminine and the gender-neutral.
   (c)   As used in this chapter:
      (1)   “Adjusted Federal taxable income,” for a person required to file as
a C corporation, or for a person that has elected to be taxed as a C
corporation under division (c)(23)D. of this section, means a C corporation’s
Federal taxable income before net operating losses and special deductions as
determined under the Internal Revenue Code, adjusted as follows:
         A.   Deduct intangible income to the extent included in Federal
taxable income. The deduction shall be allowed regardless of whether the
intangible income relates to assets used in a trade or business or assets held
for the production of income.
         B.   Add an amount equal to 5% of intangible income deducted under
division (c)(1)A. of this section, but excluding that portion of intangible
income directly related to the sale, exchange, or other disposition of property
described in section 1221 of the Internal Revenue Code;
         C.   Add any losses allowed as a deduction in the computation of
Federal taxable income if the losses directly relate to the sale, exchange, or
other disposition of an asset described in section 1221 or 1231 of the Internal
Revenue Code;
         D.   1.   Except as provided in division (c)(1)D.2. of this section,
deduct income and gain included in Federal taxable income to the extent the
income and gain directly relate to the sale, exchange, or other disposition of
an asset described in section 1221 or 1231 of the Internal Revenue Code;
            2.   Division (c)(1)D.1. of this section does not apply to the
extent the income or gain is income or gain described in section 1245 or 1250
of the Internal Revenue Code.
         E.   Add taxes on or measured by net income allowed as a deduction in
the computation of Federal taxable income;
         F.   In the case of a real estate investment trust or regulated
investment company, add all amounts with respect to dividends to, distributions
to, or amounts set aside for or credited to the benefit of investors and
allowed as a deduction in the computation of Federal taxable income;
         G.   Deduct, to the extent not otherwise deducted or excluded in
computing Federal taxable income, any income derived from a transfer agreement
or from the enterprise transferred under that agreement under Ohio R.C.
4313.02;
         H.   1.   Except as limited by divisions (c)(1)H.2., 3. and 4. of this
section, deduct any net operating loss incurred by the person in a taxable year
beginning on or after January 1, 2017.
               The amount of such net operating loss shall be deducted from net
profit that is reduced by exempt income to the extent necessary to reduce
municipal taxable income to zero, with any remaining unused portion of the net
operating loss carried forward to not more than five consecutive taxable years
following the taxable year in which the loss was incurred, but in no case for
more years than necessary for the deduction to be fully utilized.
            2.   No person shall use the deduction allowed by division (c)(1)H.
of this section to offset qualifying wages.
            3.   a.   For taxable years beginning in 2018, 2019, 2020, 2021, or
2022, a person may not deduct, for purposes of an income tax levied by a
municipal corporation that levies an income tax before January 1, 2016, more
than 50% of the amount of the deduction otherwise allowed by division (c)
(1)H.1. of this section.
               b.   For taxable years beginning in 2023 or thereafter, a person
may deduct, for purposes of an income tax levied by a municipal corporation
that levies an income tax before January 1, 2016, the full amount allowed by
division (c)(1)H.1. of this section.
            4.   Any pre-2017 net operating loss carryforward deduction that is
available must be utilized before a taxpayer may deduct any amount pursuant to
division (c)(1)H. of this section.
            5.   Nothing in division (c)(1)H.3.a. of this section precludes a
person from carrying forward, for use with respect to any return filed for a
taxable year beginning after 2018, any amount of net operating loss that was
not fully utilized by operation of division (c)(1)H.3.a. of this section. To
the extent that an amount of net operating loss that was not fully utilized in
one or more taxable years by operation of division (c)(1)H.3.a. of this section
is carried forward for use with respect to a return filed for a taxable year
beginning in 2019, 2020, 2021, or 2022, the limitation described in division
(c)(1)H.3.a. of this section shall apply to the amount carried forward.
         I.   Deduct any net profit of a pass-through entity owned directly or
indirectly by the taxpayer and included in the taxpayer’s Federal taxable
income unless an affiliated group of corporations includes that net profit in
the group’s Federal taxable income in accordance with Section
181.063(e)(3)B. of this chapter.
         J.   Add any loss incurred by a pass-through entity owned directly or
indirectly by the taxpayer and included in the taxpayer’s Federal taxable
income unless an affiliated group of corporations includes that loss in the
