921.01 DEFINITIONS.
   (a)   “Village” means the Village of Munroe Falls, Ohio.
   (b)   “Council” means the Council of the Village of Munroe Falls, Ohio.
   (c)   “Superintendent” means the Superintendent of Roads and Utilities.
   (d)   “Munroe Falls Water Department” or “MFWD” means such organization of
the Municipal government.
   (e)   “Foreman” means the foreman of the Munroe Falls Roads and Utilities
Department.
   (f)   “Owner” means the legal owner of record.
   (g)   “Unit” or “apartment” means that portion of a duplex, twin-plex,
triplex, or an apartment building occupied by a tenant.
   (h)   “Condominium” means any multiple dwelling structure in which each
dwelling structure would normally be owned by the occupant.
   (i)   “Main” means the vehicle by which the water is distributed to hydrant
runs and consumer's service.
   (j)   “Hydrant feeder branches” means the water line that exclusively
supplies a fire hydrant from a water main.
   (k)   “Private main” means a vehicle by which the water is distributed to
hydrant feeder branches and consumer's service constructed and owned privately
by an individual or corporation.
   (l)   “Private lines” means services constructed and owned by the consumer.
   (m)   “Service” means the vehicle by which the water reaches the property
line from the main.
   (n)   “Interior piping” means all water piping on the premises.
   (o)   “House lines” means that portion of exterior piping between the
service and entrance to the building.
   (p)   “Premises” means the property served by one meter.
   (q)   “Clerk” means the Clerk-Treasurer or authorized assistants.
   (r)   “Engineer” means the Village Engineer.
   (s)   “Fire service un-metered” means any connection to public water mains
that will provide a water supply to a privately owned water system that
provides a means of fire-fighting or fire protection to private property.
   (t)   “Fire protection systems” includes such items as private fire
hydrants, standpipes, sprinklers and any other fire protection or suppression
system using water as its agent.
   All basic rules and regulations in the following pages shall apply to the
Munroe Falls Water Department and its administration thereof.
921.02 RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   (a)   The following rules and regulations are to be considered part of the
contract between the Water Department and all users.
   (b)   The Superintendent shall direct the operation of the Water Department
system and shall exercise all of the powers conferred on the MFWD and shall
prepare such rules and regulations as shall be necessary for the safe,
economical and efficient management and operation of the Water Department
system and the protection of the supply.
   (c)   Assessment of Charges for Water: The Superintendent shall assess and
the clerk shall collect charges for water according to the rules and
regulations of the MFWD as assessed by ordinance.
   (d)   Contracts: All contracts for water shall be between the Munroe Falls
Water Department and the owner or tenant of the property.
   (e)   Owner Requests: All requests pertinent to the water system such as
turning on or turning off water, installing or removing of meters, etc.,
originating with the owner, must be in writing and signed by the owner or his
authorized agent.
   (f)   Discontinuance of Service in Occupied Houses: Requests for
discontinuance of service in legally occupied houses will not be honored or
accepted for such purposes as eviction, enforcing collection of rents or as a
result of differences between owner and occupant. The Munroe Falls Water
Department will not be liable for damages as a result of enforcement of this
regulation in such cases.
   (g)   Records - Accounting and Underground: The MFWD shall maintain such
readings and records of meters as shall facilitate the collection of charges
for water and maintain a complete system of records and underground maps
completely indexed and filed.
   (h)   Pressure and Supply - No Guarantee: The MFWD does not guarantee any
fixed pressure or a continuous supply, these being subject to the varying
conditions which may arise in the operation and maintenance of the water
supply. Consumers whose operations require a continuous supply of water or
definite pressures should provide against interruption by the installation of
tanks or auxiliary supplies or pressure regulators sufficient to carry them
over the period of interruption.
   (i)   Access to Premises: The MFWD reserves the right, through its assigned
agents, to enter, at any reasonable hour, the premises to which its service
extends for the purpose of reading, repairing, installing, removing and
inspecting operation and maintenance of the water system. If such access is
unavailable, the water shall be shut off and not turned on again until the
request of the MFWD has been granted. A turning on charge shall be payable at
time of turn on.
   (j)   In case of breaks in mains, services, pumping and auxiliary machinery,
reservoirs or other equipment, the water may be shut off, when necessary,
without notice. No claim will be allowed for damages arising from the turning
off or turning on of water or from flushing fire hydrants.
   (k)   Discontinuance of Supply of Water: The supply of water through any
service may be turned off by the Munroe Falls Water Department for the
following causes:
      (1)   For the use of water on any premises not included in original
application. Except as provided herein, an application for water service is
intended to furnish water to a single family residence, multi-family residence,
apartment building, a business or an industry, and for condominiums.
         A.   Whenever a single family home is altered to provide an apartment,
then such will be considered as a multiple unit for billing purposes. A meter
for each unit will not be required but a minimum billing will consist of the
residential minimum charge per unit.
         B.   Whenever a business or industrial property is subdivided to
provide additional businesses or industries, then a separate meter may be
required for each business or industry as determined by the Engineer or
Superintendent of Utilities and a minimum billing that will consist of the
business or industrial charge per unit.
      When a subdivision in either A. or B. above is no longer occupied, a new
application to the MFWD will be required to change the billing classification.
      (2)   For failure to maintain in good order connections, service pipes or
fixtures owned by the applicant.
      (3)   For cross-connection or inter-connection with any other supply of
water.
      (4)   For installation of pipes or fixtures in such a way that a
possibility of back siphoning or backflow exists.
      (5)   For molesting any service pipe, pipe, meters, curb stop,
corporation stop or seal, or any appliance of the MFWD.
      (6)   For nonpayment of water or other charges occurring under the
application.
      (7)   For absence of reasonable access for the purpose of inspection or
reading, servicing, installing or removal of meters.
      (8)   For making any additions or alterations in or about service pipe or
curb stop without notice thereof being previously given to and permission in
writing obtained from MFWD.
      (9)   For inability to obtain meter readings for two consecutive reading
periods due to lack of access to or obstruction of a meter.
      (10)   For failure of owner of property to execute a contract for a
supply of water or for failure of owner to guarantee payment of final billing
for water or other service charges to his premises through a tenant.
      (11)   For failure to vacate property as scheduled, otherwise a service
charge may be assessed. (A.O.)
      (12)   For occupying premises without obtaining an occupancy permit or
any other permit required by the Municipality or any other governmental agency
relative to the premises being occupied.
(Ord. 36-88. Passed 10-4-88.)
   (l)   Operation of or Tampering with MFWD Property: No person shall operate,
open or otherwise tamper with any valve, stop, seal or other device or
unlawfully secure a supply of water through such valve, corporation stop, curb
stop or other device, after such have been closed for the violation of any
rules of the MFWD.
   (m)   Abandon Services: Buildings being torn down or demolished will be
inspected and all services shut off at the main at the expense of the owner.
Abandoned services discovered not shut off at the main shall be shut off by the
MFWD and the cost of shutting off such service together with other damages as
may be sustained by reason of leaks on the abandoned service, shall be charged
to the owner of the premises or property.
   (n)   Miscellaneous Property Ownership: All paraphernalia, equipment and
miscellaneous property derived from or received from the MFWD shall not be
damaged or destroyed and shall be surrendered upon demand.
   (o)   Trespassing on Water Department Property: No person shall enter upon
Water Department property, excepting designated public areas, unless authorized
by the MFWD.
   (p)   Use of Fire Hydrants: Fire hydrants are intended primarily for the use
of the Fire Department. Penalties for their unauthorized use are provided.
Opening of fire hydrants or drawing water therefrom by any unauthorized person
is strictly prohibited. No one shall store any article or material of any kind
in front of such hydrant, between the curb line and the center of the street or
within five feet of any hydrant.
   No persons, except an authorized employee of the Water Department or the
Fire Department, shall open, operate or remove the nozzle cap from any hydrant
to which water is supplied by the MFWD.
   At the discretion of the Superintendent, a special permit may be issued for
the use of a fire hydrant for securing a supply of water for construction
purposes where a permanent connection cannot be made.
   No leakage or wasting of water will be tolerated. Temporary meters shall be
installed for this purpose whenever possible and rates for water used will be
those rates used for Public, Commercial and Industrial metered water service.
   (q)   Free Water: The MFWD shall furnish water, without charge for the
following purposes only:
      (1)   For all Fire Department purposes.
      (2)   For all uses of the Roads and Utilities Department.
      (3)   For Village buildings, and other purposes authorized by Council or
the Mayor.
921.03 RATES AND CHARGES.
   (a)   Water Rate Schedule, Composition of:
      (1)   All charges for water and for service rendered by the MFWD shall be
billed in accordance with the schedule of rates on file in the office of the
Water Department.
      (2)   The final billing or a new service during a quarter shall be
computed on a pro-rated basis as defined in the rate schedule.
      (3)   Special charges may be made for temporary unusual use of water,
when un-metered. Such charges shall be based on the usage as determined by the
Superintendent.
   (b)   Services and Curb Meter Installation Charges:
      (1)   The MFWD shall furnish and install service and meters up to and
including three-fourths inch at the rates on file in the office of the Water
Department.
      (2)   All meters larger than three-fourths inch shall be furnished and
installed by the owner at his expense, to the MFWD specifications.
      (3)   All repairs or renewals of service, chargeable to an owner, will be
billed at cost plus forty percent (40%).
   (c)   Water Charges and Bills:
      (1)   All bills for water usage shall show a net amount and a gross
amount due. Payment of the net amount must be received in the office of the
MFWD on or before the due date shown on the bill.
      (2)   All payments received after the due date, excepting payments by
mail postmarked on or before the due date, shall be for the gross amount. The
gross amount shall be the net amount plus a ten percent (10%) late charge.
      (3)   Notice shall be given to delinquent accounts but all accounts
remaining unpaid thirty days after the due date shall be shut off without
further notice. A turn off and turn on charge shall be added to the amount due
and the full amount shall be paid before the water will be turned on. Unusual
and extraordinary circumstances will be handled as described in subsection (n)
hereof.
(Ord. 42-90. Passed 11-6-90.)
      (4)   In addition to subsection (c)(3) hereof, when delinquent accounts
are not paid the City shall:
         A.   Cause them to be certified to the County Auditor or Fiscal
Officer for placement as a lien upon the property served in accordance with the
procedures set forth in Ohio R.C. 743.04; and/or
         B.   Collect them by actions at law, in the name of the City from an
owner, tenant, or other person who is liable to pay the bills or charges, as
set forth in Ohio R.C. 743.04.
         C.   If the City causes the delinquent account to be certified to the
County Auditor or Fiscal Officer, per this section, the amount certified will
be the amount owed on the account plus a one hundred dollar ($100.00) penalty
fee.
(Ord. 13-2005. Passed 7-5-05.)
   (d)   Payment for Water Services: Charges for new or renewal of up to and
including two inch service shall be paid before service turn on. For larger
services, an advance payment of not less than fifty percent (50%) of the
estimated cost of the work shall be required. Water will not be turned on
permanently until all service charges are paid.
   (e)   Payment of Miscellaneous Charges: All miscellaneous charges shall be
“Net” thirty days after the bill is rendered and are not subject to discount.
   (f)   Bills Against Vacant Property: A rebate or abatement will not be
allowed on service to vacant premises. Owners shall be held responsible for all
charges of the MFWD occurring against the property until written notice shall
be given to the MFWD to discontinue the supply.
   (g)   Charges for Water Found On: Where the water has been turned off for
any reason by the MFWD, it shall be so recorded and the charge for water ceases
from that date. However, whenever water is found turned on to a service
recorded as being turned off, on the records of the MFWD, the account shall be
charged for water from the recorded date of the turn off of the service and a
fine will be levied.
   (h)   Billing and Delivery: Every account shall be charged and billed
separately, except as provided in the schedule of rates. The MFWD will deliver
bills for water and miscellaneous charges by depositing same with the post
office. Failure to receive bills shall not relieve any owner from his
obligation in the payment of such bills or constitute a claim to waiver of the
service charge.
   (i)   Payment by Tenant: If the owner of any premises so elects, he may have
his tenant or lessee pay the water and/or miscellaneous charges, as they occur.
However, such tenant or lessee does so as the agent of the owner and such owner
is not thereby relieved from payment of any bills that might occur.
   (j)   Readings for Billings:
      (1)   Readings for residential water bills shall be taken quarterly and
when closing an account. At the request of the owner, or his agent unscheduled
readings of the meters may be made upon payment of a fee of five dollars
($5.00) for each reading.
      (2)   Commercial and industrial accounts shall be read monthly.
   (k)   Adjustments:
      (1)   The amount of water registered by any meter shall be charged and
paid for in full, irrespective of whether such water, after having been
registered, was lost by leakage, accident or otherwise. When meters fail to
register correctly and during the time meters are removed for test or repairs,
the charges for water will be assessed on an estimated amount based on the
average consumption shown when the meter was in proper working order.
      (2)   When upon examination, meters fail to register or the accuracy does
not meet the requirements of the MFWD, the account will be examined for a
period of one year preceding the removal. Should there be a marked difference
in consumption as shown by the defective meter and one in good repair, an
additional charge or credit for over or under registration of the meter for not
more than one year shall be made.
   (l)   Refunds and Abatements: A refund or abatement on a bill metered for
water can be made for only one of the following reasons:
      (1)   Where an error has been made in the reading of the meter or in the
preparation of the bill.
      (2)   When the meter, upon test, shows an average over-registration of
greater than two percent (2%).
      (3)   When payment was duplicated or charged incorrectly. The original
receipt must accompany the application for a refund. In general, all
overpayments will be credited to the account and shown as a credit against the
account on the next bill rendered but may, if approved by the Superintendent,
be refunded. Rebate form shall be completed by the clerk and maintained for
audit purposes.
   (m)   Complaints of Overcharge: Complaints of overcharge should be made
immediately upon receipt of the bill and before the bill is paid. All bills
against which no complaints are made shall be considered correct. Exceptions
may be made by authority of the Superintendent. However, mistakes in favor of
the MFWD, if proven, may be corrected.
   (n)   Credits to Accounts:
      (1)   Remittance to the MFWD for a given account must first be applied
against unpaid water bills.
      (2)   Bills for water must be paid in the order in which they are
contracted and accordingly, the MFWD may refuse to accept payment of a current
bill when there are one or more bills delinquent against an account. The gross
billing shall apply until all bills are current. Partial payments of water
bills will be accepted only under unusual and extraordinary circumstances.
   (o)   Bill Payment: All payments shall be in currency or by check drawn to
the order of the MFWD. All checks will be accepted subject to collection at the
bank.
   (p)   Bill Period:
      (1)   The period covered by a bill, except final bills, will terminate as
of the date of the bill.
      (2)   In computing partial bills, either on a consumption or time basis,
the date of bill will be used as the fixed date for starting or ending of a
billing period. Except that final bills, terminating within ten days after date
of bill, may be billed as of bill date. Likewise, new accounts opened within
this period may be billed from start of normal billing period.
(A.O.)
   (q)   Water Deposits.
      (1)   The deposit, less any charges due, required to obtain water service
shall be returned to the depositor by regular mail to the last known address of
the depositor or directly to the depositor if the depositor appears at the
MFWD. This deposit refund shall be paid no sooner than thirty days after water
service is terminated.
      (2)   If the MFWD is unable to pay the deposit refund as provided in
Section
921.03(q)(1), the MFWD shall keep the deposit refund for the credit of the
depositor for a period of five years. Thereafter, this deposit refund shall be
forfeited by the depositor and placed in the General Fund of the Village.
(Ord. 42-90. Passed 11-6-90.)
921.04 APPLICATION FOR A SUPPLY OF WATER.
   (a)   Water:
      (1)    Application for a supply of water shall be made at the office of
the MFWD by the owner of the premises to be supplied, or his duly authorized
agent, on the form provided. These rules and regulations shall be part of every
application for a supply of water. A signed application is required.
      (2)   Separate application must be made and an account opened for each
service from a main or private line.
         A.   A service shall serve property owned by the applicant only.
         B.   The application must register and state if the premises has more
than one residence or apartment. Each residence or apartment, when rented, must
pay at least the minimum billing.
   (b)   Service: A separate service shall be installed for each building
occupied as a dwelling, apartment house, office or store on a single parcel of
land containing more than one building. The applicant may be supplied with
water by a single service, provided the additional building or buildings are
without street frontage and written approval is given by the Superintendent.
When any land and/or building so served in common with other buildings is sold,
the MFWD will discontinue the supply of water to the portion sold and the new
owner shall make application in the usual manner for a supply of water. In the
event it is necessary for the new service to cross property other than that
owned by the applicant, the applicant shall file with the MFWD an easement
granted by the owner of the land or property so crossed for the construction of
such new service.
   (c)   Service From an Adjoining Street:
      (1)   A premise shall be served with water through a service from the
water main in the street upon which such premises has frontage.
      (2)   If however, there is no water main in the street upon which a
premises has frontage, then the owner of the premises may, with the approval of
the Superintendent and an easement or written consent of the owner or owners of
a lot or lots contiguous to the applicant's premises and the adjoining street,
obtain water from the adjoining street. Otherwise, the MFWD will not be
responsible for furnishing a supply of water to the premises. The full cost of
installation of such service shall be the responsibility of the owner of the
premises so served. The owner must also, at his or her own expense, furnish to
the Village Engineer a complete and detailed set of drawings showing the
location and depth of such line.
      (3)   After these prerequisites are accomplished, the MFWD will open an
account, install the meter, and set a curb box in the adjoining street.
      (4)   Thereafter, when a water main is laid on the street upon which the
aforesaid premises has frontage, the owner shall purchase a standard service
from the new water main and the MFWD may disconnect the service from the main
in the adjoining street. The cost of the disconnection shall be paid prior to
the use of the new service and the owner shall be liable for the assessment for
the new main and service as any other owner.
   (d)   Service and Meter Sizing: The applicant shall furnish detailed plans
of existing and proposed water lines and such additional information as may be
necessary for the MFWD to determine the size of the service, depth, location
and type of meter and the necessary changes in the piping schedule.
   (e)   Miscellaneous Use:
      (1)   Application must be made for the use of water for the erection,
repairing or altering of any building or structure, for street and sewer work,
for the operation of steam engines and for any other purpose that requires the
temporary use of water from a fire hydrant. Such service shall be metered.
      (2)   Public and private swimming pools will not be supplied with water
from any source by house fixtures or from a fire hydrant without first having
been inspected by the Electrical and Plumbing Inspector to insure proper
grounding of the pool. The customary inspection fee for this type of service
shall be charged to the owner of the pool.
921.05 SERVICE.
   (a)   Installation:
      (1)   Service installed and not used over a period of two years or more
shall not be connected to house lines without inspection and approval of the
Superintendent and Engineer.
      (2)   Whenever Council authorizes the permanent surfacing of a street,
the cost of which is to be assessed against abutting property, the MFWD, prior
to the surfacing may install a service complete to the property line for each
lot facing it. Such service may be assessed against such lots and placed on the
tax duplicate for collection. If no assessments are made for the improvement,
the MFWD may at the discretion of the Superintendent, install such services and
place the cost on record for future collection.
      (3)   Records of locations of these services will be obtained and kept by
the MFWD and Engineer and furnished the owner upon request. Since correctness
of location cannot be guaranteed, the owner should locate the service prior to
installation of house line. If, after diligent search by the owner, the service
cannot be located, the MFWD, upon request will attempt to locate it.
      (4)   If a service was installed to the property line when the street was
improved and such service was not assessed against the property at that time, a
permit may be granted for its use and the charge for the service shall be the
cost as carried on the books of the MFWD.
      (5)   When a request is made for a new service to a premise which is
already serviced, the applicant must, at the time of making application, pay
the cost of abandoning the old service in accordance with the charges for such
work, consisting of labor and equipment used for removal of old service.
   (b)   Size and Type of Tap-in Required:
 
Type of Connection                  Size of Connection Size of Service Pipe
Single Family -    Corporation Stop 1"                 1"
Multi-Family)
Commercial ) -     Corporation Stop As approved by the MFWD and Engineer (but
                                    no less than 1 inch)
Industrial )
 
   The size of the service line to supply water to a premises shall be
determined by the MFWD and the Engineer. Wyed connections at the main will not
be allowed. The house line shall be connected at the property line by the owner
at his expense.
   (c)   Requirements for Inside Meter Installation:
      (1)    All services shall have a curb stop or valve and valve box located
in the right-of-way.
      (2)   All services shall enter the lot to be served at the center of the
front line of the lot unless otherwise designated by the owner but in no case
shall they be placed diagonally. Service and house lines, between the curb stop
and house, shall not be installed under driveways or laid at right angles to
the curb or property line. However, when subsurfaces or other conditions make
it impracticable, the service may be otherwise laid upon the approval of the
plans submitted by the owner showing the proposed location of the service.
      (3)   A service will not be installed in the same ditch with a sewer
lateral.
      (4)   All rules and regulations governing the installation of services on
mains will govern the installation of services on water main extensions by
private parties and private line installations.
   (d)   Curb Stop Operation: The curb stop or gate valve, as well as the
corporation stop, are under the control of the MFWD and must not be tampered or
interfered with or operated by unauthorized persons. Only authorized employees
shall turn on water into the premises to be supplied, except that a plumber may
turn on water for testing purposes. The plumber must turn off the water upon
completion of testing unless permission to leave on was granted by the MFWD.
   (e)   Fire Service Size: Unless specifically approved by the Superintendent,
Engineer or the Fire Department the largest service allowed for fire or
sprinkler systems is eight inches.
   (f)   Repair and Maintenance:
      (1)   All services, including all fixtures for the delivering and
supplying of water shall be maintained in perfect order by the owner at his
expense, except as herein provided.
      (2)   All repairs to services in public streets, courts or rights-of-way
will be made by the MFWD, between the main line and curb stop, at Municipal
expense.
      (3)   Restoration of service will be made at the established rates on
file in the office of the Clerk at the owner's expense.
      (4)   Repairs to services in public streets, courts or rights-of-way by
the MFWD are to include the repair of curb meter settings and connections
thereto.
      (5)   A service damaged by electrolysis beyond the curb stop shall be
repaired and protected to the satisfaction of the MFWD at the owner's expense.
      (6)   The MFWD assumes no liability for and will not thaw any frozen
services. The entire cost shall be borne by the owner and will be under the
supervision of the MFWD on work beyond the curb stop.
   (g)   Abandoned Service: Any service, the use of which has been permanently
discontinued, shall be turned off by the MFWD at the corporation stop on the
main and permanently disconnected from such corporation stop. The cost of all
necessary labor shall be charged to the owner.
921.06 INTERIOR PIPING.
   (a)   Inspection.
      (1)   All water piping beyond the street property line, known as “house
line”, shall be installed under the joint supervision of and inspection by the
MFWD and the Building Inspector.
      (2)   The house line shall be inspected by the MFWD prior to covering and
tested with water pressure.
      (3)   The MFWD reserves the right to refuse a supply of water to premises
on which the plumbing does not meet the requirements of the Building Department
or the Board of Health of the political subdivision.
   (b)   House Lines:
      (1)   Pipes shall be of sufficient size to give adequate service at any
fixture with a pressure of 125 pounds. At the curb line, house lines from one
inch service to stop and waste valve in the basement shall not be less than
that specified for service. House lines, serving interior meter settings, shall
not be laid beneath concrete floors or driveways. House lines to the rear of
the buildings serving interior meter settings shall be laid outside the
building foundation.
      (2)   All house lines, up to and including two inches shall be “K” type
copper. House lines larger than two inches, up to and including four inches may
be “K” type copper. House lines larger than four inches shall be ductile iron.
Fittings may be of brass, copper, ductile or cast iron.
         The house line shall be laid with at least four and one-half feet of
cover. When, for some uncontrollable reason, the line must be laid with less
cover than above, it shall be protected by a minimum covering of six inches of
zonelite or other suitable insulating material around the pipe.
         All pipe and fixtures shall be effectively protected against damage by
freezing as directed by the MFWD and the Engineers.
   (c)   Connection to Existing Services:
      (1)   Connections to existing services shall be made at the curb stop. If
tests show leakage between the curb stop and the stop and waste, repairs shall
be made by the owner at his expense.
      (2)   When tests made by the MFWD indicate that there is a leak on the
house line between the curb stop or gate valve and the meter, a notice to
repair will be served upon the owner and/or occupant of the premises. If the
notice is not complied with within ten days, the MFWD may shut off the curb
stop or gate valve control in the service. A charge shall be made before the
supply is resumed.
      (3)   No attachment for withdrawing water shall be made to the service or
the house line between the main and the meter.
   (d)   Stop and Waste Control Valves: Each one and one fourth inch and larger
service, supplying a one or two story building, shall have an approved stop and
waste valve installed within one foot of the entrance of service to the
building. Such stop and waste valve shall be easily accessible and so installed
that the water can be shut off and drained from the meter and house piping.
Buildings of over two stories supplied by a one and one fourth inch or larger
service and buildings served by manifold meters must have, in addition to the
stop and waste valve, a gate valve installed on the inlet side of each meter.
Other services shall have gate valves installed on the inlet and on the outlet
sides of the meter, with one inside valve within three feet of the outside
building wall.
   (e)   Manifolds: When it is desirable to split the use and billing of water,
a manifold, adjacent to the place where the house line enters the structure,
shall be provided. Each branch of the manifold shall be equipped with a stop
and waste valve, meter setting and gate valve on the outlet side of the meter.
No house lines or meters shall be placed in unheated areas.
   Manifold meter settings for apartment type buildings will not be allowed.
Apartment type buildings will have one master meter to meter water service.
Each unit or apartment within an apartment building will have its own shut off
valves in hot and cold water supply lines.
   Condominiums will be considered as single family dwellings and each unit of
such a building or structure must have its own meter.
   (f)   Meters: Provision must be made in all piping for the installation of a
meter in accordance with these rules and regulations.
   (g)   Cross Connections or Contamination:
      (1)   Provision must be made to protect the water supply from
contamination due to backflow from toilet fixtures, laundry tubs, etc. Piping
of elevated or pressure tanks, hydraulic lifts, etc., must be so installed that
backflow into the water supply is impossible.
      (2)   No cross connection shall be made or allowed to exist between the
Municipal water supply and any other water supply for any purpose whatsoever. A
cross connection may be defined as a physical tie between piping delivering
water from the Municipal supply and that derived from some other source.
      (3)   If the MFWD supply is delivered to a tank which is also supplied
with water from another source such tank shall be open to atmospheric pressure
and the Municipal supply shall enter the tank above the overflow level.
      (4)   Supply lines to wading and swimming pools shall discharge above the
overflow level of the pool.
      (5)   Fixtures, devices or construction which provide a cross connection
between the MFWD supply and a drainage system, other water system, or any means
that may contaminate the MFWD supply is unlawful and will not be allowed.
      (6)   Before any proposed changes in any existing industrial or
commercial piping systems involving possible cross connections are made,
inspection of the system must be made by an approval obtained from the MFWD.
   (h)   Valves: All valves must be accessible and each underground valve shall
have a standard valve box, similar to and interchangeable with the boxes used
by the MFWD. No arrangement of piping whereby different pressure zones are
connected will be allowed.
   (i)   Relief Valves: Where a check valve is installed on the piping between
the main and a hot water tank, a pressure relief valve shall be installed on
the hot water tank and as regulated by the Building Code.
   (j)   Suction Tanks and Air Chambers: If ordered by the Superintendent,
services supplying pumps shall have suction tanks installed on the line.
Likewise, the Superintendent may order air chambers to be installed to reduce
water hammer caused by quick-closing devices installed by the consumer.
   (k)   Steamer Connections: All services with steamer connections shall have
a check valve installed in such a manner as to prevent backflow into the main.
   (l)   Unmetered Fire Lines:
      (1)   Services supplying tight sprinkler systems installed by a company
approved by the State and the National Board of Fire Underwriters may not be
metered. Such unmetered service must be equipped with a standard detector check
valve approved by the National Board of Fire Underwriters and the MFWD, and
installed in accordance with drawing entitled “Detector Check Valve
Installation Acc. No. F-5940" or as it may be revised.
       (2)   All outlets except sprinklers on existing and new unmetered fire
services, may be sealed by the MFWD.
      (3)   No person shall break any seal on any fixture to which water is
supplied by the MFWD through an unmetered service, except in case of fire, make
any tap or connection for withdrawing water, nor take water from such unmetered
service, except in case of fire or for testing purposes. A charge may be made
against the owner for each seal found broken, except when used for fire
fighting or testing purposes. The owner shall notify the MFWD whenever an
unmetered service is used for fire fighting or testing purposes.
      (4)   All interior piping shall be subject to the inspection of the MFWD.
The MFWD reserves the right to turn off existing services or to refuse to turn
on a new service if it believes that any of the foregoing rules are being
violated.
      (5)   All mechanical equipment involved in sprinkler systems shall be
physically cleaned and lubricated at least once a year to insure their proper
operation at which time the MFWD will be called for inspection.
921.07 METERS.
   (a)   Location.
      (1)   All services, except tight sprinkler and fire fighting lines, shall
be metered. The required meter installation will be determined by the MFWD and
the Engineer from the data furnished by the applicant. Installations requiring
three-fourths inch or smaller meters may be installed by the MFWD.
         All meters paid for and installed become the property of the MFWD and
are not subject to removal for any cause without approval of MFWD and must be
of a type specified by the MFWD.
      (2)   A.   The Badger Read-O-Matic or their equal shall be standard in
all new residential construction. All meters of this type shall register in
gallons on the inside meter and the outside register.
         B.   Meters and their component parts shall be ordered according to
subsection (a)(1) hereof and paid for in the usual manner. However, only five-
eighths inch by three-fourths inch and three-fourths inch by one inch meters
and their component parts will be stocked by the MFWD.
         C.   Meters installed in commercial construction shall be of the
visual outside structure reading type registering in gallons.
         D.   Residents of the Municipality may request and the Clerk shall
take orders for the Read-O-Matic Meter. In residences where it is not possible
to gain entry for the purposes of meter reading for two consecutive reading
periods, or six months, or for any other reason deemed necessary by the MFWD,
the owners must have a visual type of reader installed outside the structure,
when so ordered by the Superintendent.
         E.   Meters now installed in a premises, if not damaged, may be
exchanged for the automatic reading type without charge, at the discretion of
the Superintendent except for the automatic reading recorder and its
installation fee.
         F.   All meters of the type mentioned above shall have an outside
register on the exterior of the building on a sidewall where completely visible
and accessible at a height of three to five feet above finished grade level and
not be obstructed by shrubs, trees, bushes, etc.
            If more than one meter per structure is required then each meter
shall be clearly identified as to unit.
      (3)   Installations requiring meters larger than three fourths inch shall
be furnished and installed by the owner at his expense and shall meet MFWD
specifications.
      (4)   All one and one quarter inch or smaller meters, shall be located
within one foot of the entrance of the house line into a structure and not more
than three feet above the floor on an outside wall.
      (5)   In manifold settings, meters shall be closely grouped and located
near the house line entrance. Meters shall be installed in a conspicuous and
accessible location approved by the MFWD with adequate head room and with
provisions for ingress and egress heated to protect the meters properly.
   (b)   Magnetic Meters. Except as otherwise determined by the MFWD, meters
five-eighths to three-fourths inch in size, inclusive, shall be disc meters.
All meters larger than three inches in size shall be compound meters approved
by the MFWD.
   (c)   Larger Settings.
      (1)   Shall be visual outside structure reading type when available.
      (2)   All meter installations one and one-fourths inch and larger shall
be made in accordance with the approved plan of the MFWD entitled “Industrial
Meter Installation Drawing, Acc. No. F-5938" or as it may be revised. The work
shall be done by the owner at his expense under the direct supervision of the
MFWD.
      (3)   When it is necessary or desirable that such installation be made
outside the building, a properly constructed concrete block or brick vault
shall be built. This vault must conform to the requirements of the MFWD and
shall be in accordance with the drawing entitled “Industrial Meter Installation
Drawing, Acc. No. F-5938" or as it may be revised. In any case, the manhole
must be of sufficient size to remove the meter without disassembly for repair.
      (4)   Pit meter setting may be approved if the vault is properly
insulated against freezing. Where drainage is a problem, each location shall be
subject to approval by the Superintendent.
   (d)   By-pass. Meter settings one and one-half inch and larger shall include
a by-pass with shut off valves installed on each side. The by-pass valve shall
be sealed shut and if the seal is unlawfully broken, the owner may be charged a
fee. In the event it is necessary for the consumer to break the by-pass seal,
he shall immediately notify the MFWD giving the reason for breaking the seal.
   (e)   Sealing. All meters shall be sealed upon installation, both at the
coupling on supply or inlet side of the meter and at the bonnet set screws.
Such seals shall not be broken or disturbed in any manner except by an employee
of the MFWD. Any premises where seals are found broken or meters are damaged,
tampered with, disconnected or removed, will be subject to a discontinuance of
water supply until all damages, as well as the cost of water used, are paid. A
fee will be charged for breaking or tampering with a seal.
   (f)   Stoppage. Notice of any stoppage or irregularity of a meter shall be
given immediately to the MFWD.
   (g)   Lost or Damaged. The owner shall be responsible for the protection
from damage or theft of any meter installed on his premises and shall be
required to pay all damage or loss to the MFWD through injury of a meter due to
freezing or other causes due to neglect or for loss or theft of a meter.
921.08 PRIVATE LINES.
   (a)    Where Installed.
      (1)   “Private lines” are mains (including fire protection) constructed
by the consumer.
      (2)   Private lines are to be laid at the sole expense of the applicant
with the specific consent of the Superintendent and Engineer in accordance with
the requirements of the MFWD. In general, such private lines may be allowed
upon approval as follows:
         A.   With easements to MFWD on private property within the Municipal
limits.
         B.   Extensions beyond the ends of existing or extended water mains in
dedicated streets are not considered private lines even though they are
extended by an individual or a corporation.
   (b)   Transfer of Service. When a main is laid in front of the property
served by a private line smaller than the normal requirements for a water main
in the street, all services shall be transferred to the new main and the
private line abandoned. The abandoned line may be salvaged by the owner. All
services which have been installed according to MFWD requirements will be
transferred from the private line to the water main without charge. Services
not so installed will be renewed by the MFWD at standard service rates, charges
to include pro-rated main footage and tap-in fees.
   (c)   Installation. All private lines shall be installed at the sole expense
of the applicant. Such expense shall include all cost of excavating of trench,
laying of pipe, backfilling of trench and providing for such service
connections as the MFWD shall direct. The MFWD shall approve and inspect all
connections. The MFWD will supervise tap-in to existing main and will inspect
construction of the line at the expense of the applicant.
   (d)   Application. When requesting a private line, the applicant shall
submit an application which shall include releases from exemption of
assessments for all property abutting the private line and a plan of the
proposed line. When application has been duly signed by all parties concerned
and approved by the MFWD and the Engineer the applicant shall make the required
payments to the MFWD for the work to be done.
   (e)   Size and Inspection. Private lines shall not be less than three-
fourths inch nor more than twelve inches in diameter for residential
consumption and shall meet the specifications of the MFWD. All private lines
from the curb box to meter shall be installed subject to the supervision of the
MFWD and trenches shall not be backfilled until the work has been approved.
   Water will not be supplied until inspected and approved and all charges of
the Village have been paid.
   (f)   Ownership.
      (1)   Private lines up to two inches of “K” type copper may be installed
in the Municipality up to 100 feet in length with proper inspection and without
a plan or curb meter.
      (2)   Private lines larger than two inches may not extend more than 100
feet from the property line inward without a detailed diagram of underground
connections.
921.09 WATER MAINS.
   (a)   Installation.
      (1)   Water mains may be laid or extended by the Municipality or by
private parties in accordance with plans, profiles and specifications prepared
and/or approved by the Municipal Engineer and approval by the Mayor and
Council.
         Plan scale shall be no less than one inch equals fifty feet
horizontally and one inch equals five feet vertically.
      (2)   The cost of installation of water mains shall be paid by one of the
following methods:
         A.   As set forth in “Subdivision Regulations”.
         B.   At Municipal expense if desired to improve the water system.
         C.    By assessment of abutting properties.
         D.   By abutting property owners or private parties. In this instance,
final approval of the installation of water mains shall be contingent upon
completion of the following:
            1.   Deposit with the Municipal Clerk-Treasurer the money necessary
to pay the fees for work to be performed by the Municipal Engineer, in the
amount estimated by the Engineer. Such work by the Engineer shall include, but
is not limited to, the preparation and/or approval of plans, profiles and
specifications, staking of the project from the centerline of the street and
inspection of construction.
            2.   All easements needed must be acquired from abutting property
owners and assigned to the Municipality before construction may begin.
            3.   Deposit with the Clerk-Treasurer a performance bond in the
amount of the cost of construction as estimated by the Municipal Engineer. This
performance bond to be replaced with a maintenance bond in an amount required
by the Municipal Engineer when construction is completed.
   (b)   Water Main Specifications.
      (1)   The water main shall be ductile cast iron pipe with standard cement
lining seal coat inside and outside, no smaller than eight inches in inside
diameter, unless otherwise approved.
         Each length of pipe shall be marked with the following;
            Manufacturer's name
            Pipe class
            Date of manufacture
      (2)   All ductile cast iron pipe shall meet the requirements of the
American National Standards Institute as provided in A.N.S.I. Specifications A
21.50 and A 21.51 for push-on or mechanical joint pipe with rubber gasket
joints as provided in A.N.S.I. Specifications A 21.11.
      (3)   All ductile cast iron pipe shall be designed for a working pressure
of 250 p.s.i. for laying in a flat bottomed trench with bell holes and with a
tamped backfill cover of approximately five feet.
      (4)   Ductile cast iron pipe of six inches to twelve inches nominal
inside diameter shall meet the thickness requirements of A.N.S.I. thickness,
Class 2, unless noted as otherwise on detail plans.
      (5)   Cement lining of the pipe shall conform to the requirements of
A.N.S.I. Specifications A 21.4 for standard thickness of cement mortar lining
with a seal coat of bituminous material.
   (c)   Repairs. Repairs to all water mains in public streets within the
Municipality, if by natural causes, will be made by and at the expense of the
MFWD.
   (d)   Valve Operation and Tapping. No person, other than an employee of the
MFWD or person authorized by the Superintendent, shall operate any valve in the
water mains, or make taps or other connections on any main of the Municipal
water system, without authority from the MFWD to do so. Rates for tap-in are on
file in the office of the MFWD.
   (e)   Main Valves.
      (1)   Water valves equivalent to the size of the water main shall be
installed at all street intersections and at any other place along the line
that the Engineer directs.
      (2)   The water valve shall be consistent with the type presently used in
the Munroe Falls Water Department system and shall come complete with valve box
and cover. Valves shall meet the requirements of AWWA Standard C 509 for
resilient seating gate valves.
      (3)   All valves shall open counter-clockwise or “left”.
   (f)   Fittings. All water main fittings shall meet the requirements of
A.N.S.I. specifications A 21.10 and A 21.11 for ductile iron fittings with
standard cement lining and tar coating inside and outside.
   (g)   Private Lines. Water mains, known as “private lines” may be laid by
private parties and connected to the distribution system as herein provided in
Section
921.08.
   (h)   Fire Hydrants - Installation and Use.
      (1)   Public fire hydrants installed on mains serviced by the MFWD shall
meet MFWD requirements. Hydrant runs branching from mains six inches or larger
shall be at least six inches in diameter. Each branch shall have a full size
gate valve with valve box to permit repair of hydrant without shutting off the
main. All fire hydrants must have Akron Standard Threads on connections of the
2-1/2" nozzles, Steamer connections will be 4-1/2" National Standard Threads.
      (2)   Fire hydrants should be spaced at a maximum of 375 feet with a ten
foot variance. When an extended main becomes a dead end main, a fire hydrant
must be installed at the end of the extension for flushing.
      (3)   Relocations of fire hydrants, requested by property owners will be
made by the MFWD upon approval of the Superintendent and the prepayment of any
charges by the applicant. (A.O.)
      (4)   All fire hydrants within the municipality shall be maintained and
repaired by the MFWD unless on private property. All maintenance and repairs of
hydrants on private property are subject to the provisions set forth in Section
921.09(i).
(Ord. 07-2007. Passed 6-19-07.)
      (5)   Anyone damaging a fire hydrant shall be charged the total labor and
material cost of repairing plus the cost of the estimated loss of water.
      (6)   If permission should be granted to take water from a fire hydrant,
leakage will not be tolerated either from the hydrant, connecting hose or
truck. All damage caused by such leakage shall be borne by the holder of the
permit. No person shall draw water from a fire hydrant without use of a tapered
nozzle cap, fitted with a control valve, commonly termed a “Contractor's
Connection”. The use of the main hydrant valve to control the flow of water
will not be allowed.
      (7)   Whenever a temporary meter is set on a “Contractor's Connection”,
the user of water through the meter shall be held responsible to properly
protect the meter, meter connection and fire hydrant from all damages. Only a
hydrant wrench may be used to open a hydrant and care must be used to open the
hydrant completely to avoid waste of water through bottom drain. (A.O.)
   (i)   Private Fire Hydrants: Inspection and Maintenance.
      (1)   All hydrants served by private water mains shall and will be
inspected, tested, and flushed annually, but not later than October 15th
(fifteenth) of each year, by the City of Munroe Falls or a duly authorized
agent/employee, at the cost established in Section
163.22.
      (2)   All repairs deemed necessary are the responsibility of the property
owner. Such maintenance or repairs must be performed by the Munroe Falls Water
Department or a professional, licensed by the State of Ohio. Any and all
repairs not completed by the property owner within thirty (30) days of the
initial inspection will be performed by the City of Munroe Falls or a duly
authorized agent/employee at the cost established in Section
163.22. Costs for such work will be assessed to the property owner’s property
taxes for collection.
      (3)   This section does not apply to hydrants on sprinkler systems.
(Ord. 05-2007. Passed 6-19-07.)
CHAPTER 922
Stormwater Management Utility
922.01   Findings.
922.02   Purpose.
922.03   Definitions.
922.04   Establishment of a Stormwater Management Utility and Stormwater
Management Enterprise Fund.
922.05   Jurisdiction.
922.06   Impervious surface area and equivalent rate unit.
922.07   Schedule of fees and charges.
922.08   Disposition of service charges and fees.
922.09   Credits.
922.10   Exemptions.
922.01 FINDINGS.
   The City of Munroe Falls does hereby find that:
   (a)   Ohio Revised Code authorizes the City of Munroe Falls to acquire,
construct, establish, enlarge, improve, maintain, own, operate, and contract
for the operation of a public enterprise (Stormwater Management Utility),
including stormwater management programs and structural and natural stormwater
and drainage systems of all types, to furnish service to the City and its
citizens.
   (b)   The establishment, by City ordinance, of a Stormwater Management
Utility that shall be accounted for as a separate enterprise fund, will
facilitate the provision of stormwater management programs and structural and
natural stormwater and drainage system services.
   (c)   This Council deems it necessary that the City of Munroe Falls
establish and revise from time to time a schedule of rates and charges to fund
the stormwater management program activities and structural and natural
stormwater and drainage system services provided by the Stormwater Management
Utility.
(Ord. 2024-03. Passed 6-18-24.)
922.02 PURPOSE.
   This chapter establishes a Stormwater Management Utility as an identified
fiscal and accounting fund for the purpose of comprehensively addressing the
stormwater management needs of the City through programs designed to protect
and manage water quality and quantity by controlling the level of pollutants in
stormwater runoff, and the quantity and rate of stormwater received and
conveyed by structural and natural stormwater and drainage systems of all
types. It sets forth a schedule of charges and defines the control, collection,
and disbursal of funds including penalties, appeals, exemptions, and credits.
(Ord. 2024-03. Passed 6-18-24.)
922.03 DEFINITIONS.
   For purposes of this chapter, the following words, terms, and phrases shall
have the meanings given to them in this section, except where the context
clearly indicates a different meaning:
   (a)   "Condominium" means a form of ownership in which individuals purchase
and own individual units in a multi-unit complex and jointly own and share
financial responsibility for certain common areas. Residential condominiums in
multifamily buildings differ from apartments in that each unit is individually
owned, and any land in the project is owned in common by all householders.
   (b)   "Credits" shall mean on-going reductions in the stormwater management
service charge applicable to a given zoning lot or tract in recognition of on-
site or off-site systems.
   (c)   "Developed land" shall mean a zoning lot or tract altered from its
natural state to include impervious surface area equal to or greater than 200
square feet.
   (d)   "Drainage system" shall mean natural and structural channels, swales,
ditches, swamps, rivers, streams, creeks, wetlands, branches, reservoirs,
ponds, drainage ways, inlets, catch basins, gutters, pipes, culverts, bridges,
head walls, storm sewers, lakes, and other physical works, properties, and
improvements that transfer, control, convey or otherwise influence the movement
of stormwater runoff.
   (e)   "Equivalent Rate Unit (ERU)" shall mean 3,000 square feet of
impervious surface or fraction thereof.
   (f)   "Impervious surface area" shall mean developed areas of land that
prevent or significantly impede the infiltration of stormwater into the soil.
Typical impervious surface areas include, but are not limited to: roofs,
sidewalks, walkways, patios, swimming pools, private driveways, parking lots,
access extensions, alleys and other paved, engineered, compacted or gravel
surfaces containing materials that prevent or significantly impede the natural
infiltration of stormwater into the soil.
   (g)   "Natural state" shall describe existing land, water, soil, and
vegetation characteristics that have not been substantially modified or
disturbed by development activities and the hydrologic function is in an
unaltered or natural condition.
   (h)   "Non-Residential property" shall mean all properties including
commercial, industrial, schools, churches, governmental, apartments, and
condominiums having units on multiple stories.
   (i)   "Residential property" shall mean one-, two-, and three-family
residential dwellings and condominiums, except condominiums having multiple
stories.
   (j)   "Service area" shall mean all land within the corporate limits of the
City, including all land areas legally annexed thereto.
   (k)   "Service charge" shall mean a stormwater management service charge,
applicable to a zoning lot or tract, that generally reflects the impact on or
demand for stormwater management services provided by the City to properly
control and manage stormwater runoff quantity and/or quality associated with
the zoning lot or tract. The service charge will vary from one zoning lot or
tract to another, based on the impervious surface area.
   (l)   "Stormwater" shall mean the runoff from precipitation that travels
over natural state or developed land surfaces and enters a drainage system.
   (m)   "Stormwater management program" shall mean an identified set of
measures and activities designed to protect, restore, and/or manage stormwater
quality by controlling and/or reducing pollutants; and to reduce and/or manage
stormwater quantity by controlling velocity, volume, and rate.
   (n)   "Stormwater Management Utility" shall mean an organizational structure
that is responsible for funding, administering, and operating the City's
stormwater management program, and that is supported through a rate structure
based on the impervious surface area found on zoning lots or tracts located
within the service area.
   (o)   "Tract" shall mean a parcel of land not previously recorded as a
zoning lot.
   (p)   "Undeveloped land" shall mean all land that is not altered from its
natural state to an extent that results in 200 or more square feet of
impervious surface area.
   (q)   "Zoning lot" shall mean a legally subdivided lot (not a tract) shown
on a legally recorded plat or deed, or a combination of such legally subdivided
and recorded adjacent lots.
(Ord. 2024-03. Passed 6-18-24.)
922.04 ESTABLISHMENT OF A STORMWATER MANAGEMENT UTILITY AND STORMWATER
MANAGEMENT ENTERPRISE FUND.
   (a)   There is hereby established a City Stormwater Management Utility that
shall be responsible for implementing, operating, and administering the City's
stormwater management program as defined herein.
   (b)   There is hereby established a City Stormwater Management Enterprise
Fund for the purpose of dedicating and protecting funding applicable to the
responsibilities of the Stormwater Management Utility, including but not
limited to, rents, rates, fees, charges, and penalties as may be established,
after due notice and a public hearing by the City Council. Funding may also
include other funds transferred or allocated to the Stormwater Management
Utility by the City Council. All revenues and receipts of the Stormwater
Management Utility shall be placed in the Stormwater Management Enterprise Fund
and all expenses of the utility shall be paid from the Stormwater Management
Enterprise Fund, except that other revenues, receipts, and resources not
accounted for in the Stormwater Management Enterprise Fund may be applied to
stormwater management activities as deemed appropriate by the City Council.
(Ord. 2024-03. Passed 6-18-24.)
922.05 JURISDICTION.
   The jurisdiction (service area) of the Stormwater Management Utility shall
extend to the corporate limits of the City.
(Ord. 2024-03. Passed 6-18-24.)
922.06 IMPERVIOUS SURFACE AREA AND EQUIVALENT RATE UNIT.
   (a)   Impervious surface area on a given zoning lot or tract directly
relates to the volume, rate and pollutant loading of stormwater runoff
discharged from that zoning lot or tract to the City's structural and natural
drainage systems and facilities. Therefore, impervious surface area shall be
the primary parameter for establishing a rate structure to distribute the cost
of services associated with the operation, repair, improvement, and maintenance
of public drainage systems and facilities through a schedule of rates, fees,
charges, and penalties related to the operation of a Stormwater Management
Utility and Stormwater Management Enterprise Fund as established in Section
922.04.
   (b)   Based on an analysis by the City of impervious surface area on
properties throughout the City, an impervious surface area of 3,000 square
feet, shall be designated as one equivalent rate unit (ERU).
(Ord. 2024-03. Passed 6-18-24.)
922.07 SCHEDULE OF FEES AND CHARGES.
   See Section
163.24 Stormwater Preventative Maintenance and Operation fees.
(Ord. 2024-03. Passed 6-18-24.)
922.08 DISPOSITION OF SERVICE CHARGES AND FEES.
   Stormwater Management Utility service charge and fee revenues shall be
assigned and dedicated solely to the Stormwater Management Enterprise Fund in
the City budget and accounting system, which shall be and remain separate from
other funds, and shall be used only to fund identified stormwater management
program activities. The service charges and fees paid to and collected by
virtue of the provision of this chapter shall not be used for general or other
governmental or proprietary purposes of the City, except to pay for costs
incurred by the City in rendering services associated with the Stormwater
Management Utility.
(Ord. 2024-03. Passed 6-18-24.)
922.09 CREDITS.
   (a)   The established rate may be reduced for a property (including
condominiums), other than conventionally developed residential property, where
approved runoff control measures have been implemented and maintained. Review
and analysis of these measures shall be calculated on an individual case basis
by the City Engineer, according to established policies and standards, and the
decision of the City Engineer shall be provided to the property owner in
writing. The maximum rate reduction shall not exceed fifty percent (50%) of the
established rate. Eligibility for credit may be revoked if, as determined by
the Director of Public Service, any condition of granting the credit has
changed.
   (b)   Any property owner aggrieved by a decision of the City Engineer as
provided herein may file an appeal in writing to the Director of Public Service
within 30 days of the decision of the City Engineer.
   (c)   The Director of Public Service is authorized to hear appeals regarding
disputes and complaints brought by property owners concerning the application
of the Stormwater Management Utility fees, including the authority to make
adjustments as appropriate which may include but shall not be limited to:
      (1)   Calculation of the total number of billing units assigned to a
property that are claimed to be incurred due to alleged inaccuracies in data
utilized.
      (2)   Adjustments arising from a break in billing units due to change in
property ownership, account responsibility, or similar matters.
   (d)   Any appeal must be filed in writing, must describe the specific error
alleged, and contain reasoning from the property owner that justifies the
appealed issue. The Director of Public Service may request additional
information from the appealing party and the decision of the Director of Public
Service shall be final.
(Ord. 2024-03. Passed 6-18-24.)
922.10 EXEMPTIONS.
   Except as provided in Section
922.07, no public or private property shall be exempt from Stormwater
Management Utility service charges, with the following exceptions:
   (a)   Public road rights-of-way that have been conveyed to and accepted for
maintenance by the Ohio Department of Transportation, and that are available
for use by the general public for transportation purposes, shall be exempt from
City Stormwater Management Utility service charges.
   (b)   Public road rights-of-way that have been conveyed to and accepted for
maintenance by the City of Munroe Falls, and that are available for use by the
general public for transportation purposes, shall be exempt from City
Stormwater Management Utility service charges.
   (c)   Railroad rights-of-way used for trackage and related appurtenances
shall be exempt from City Stormwater Management Utility service charges.
(Ord. 2024-03. Passed 6-18-24.)
CHAPTER 925

EDITOR'S NOTE: There are no sections in
Chapter 925. The Rules and Regulations as promulgated by the Summit County
Department of Environmental Services regulate the use of sanitary sewerage in
the City. The chapter has been established to provide a place for cross
references and future legislation.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Power to regulate sewage system - see Ohio R.C. 715.40, 717.01
   Compulsory sewer connections - see Ohio R.C. 729.06

CHAPTER 931
Backflow Prevention
931.01   Definitions.
931.02   Cross-connections prohibited.
931.03   Survey and inspection.
931.04   Where protection is required.
931.05   Type of protection required.
931.06   Backflow prevention devices.
931.07   Installation.
931.08   Inspection and maintenance.
931.09   Booster pumps.
931.10   Violations.
931.01 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this Chapter:
   (a)   “Air Gap Separation” means the unobstructed vertical distance through
the free atmosphere between the lowest opening from any pipe or faucet
supplying water to a tank, plumbing fixture, or other device and the flood
level rim of the receptacle.
   (b)   “Approved” means that a backflow prevention device or method has been
accepted by the Superintendent of Roads and Utilities as suitable for the
proposed use.
   (c)   “Auxiliary Water System” means any water system on or available to the
premises other than the public water system and includes the water supplied by
the system. These auxiliary waters may include water from another supplier's
public water system; or water from a source such as wells, lakes or streams; or
process fluids; or used water. They may be polluted or contaminated or
objectionable or constitute a water source or system over which the supplier of
water does not have control.
   (d)   “Backflow” means the flow of water or other liquids, mixtures, or
substances into the distributing pipes of a potable water supply from any
source other than the intended source of the potable water supply.
   (e)   “Backflow Prevention Device” means any device, method or type of
construction intended to prevent backflow into a potable water system.
   (f)   “Consumer” means the owner or person in control of any premises
supplied by or in any manner connected to a public water system.
   (g)   “Consumer's Water System” means any water system, located on the
consumer's premises, supplied by or in any manner connected to a public water
system. A household plumbing system is considered to be a consumer's water
system.
   (h)   “Contamination” means an impairment of the quality of the water by
sewage or process fluid or waste to a degree which could create an actual
hazard to the public health through poisoning or through spread of disease by
exposure.
   (i)   “Cross Connection” means any arrangement whereby backflow can occur.
   (j)   “Munroe Falls Water Department” means the owner or operator of the
public water system.
   (k)   “Degree of Hazard” is a term derived from an evaluation of the
potential risk to health and the adverse effect upon the potable water system.
   (l)   “Superintendent of Roads and Utilities” means the Superintendent of
Roads and Utilities of the City of Munroe Falls or his duly authorized
representative.
   (m)   “Double Check Valve Assembly” means an assembly composed of two
single, independent acting, check valves including tightly closing shutoff
valves located at each end of the assembly and suitable connections for testing
the water tightness of each check valve.
   (n)   “Health Hazard” means any conditions, device, or practice in a water
system or its operation that creates, or may create, a danger to the health and
well being of users. The word “severe” as used to qualify “health hazard” means
a hazard to the health of the user that could reasonably be expected to result
in significant morbidity or death.
   (o)   “Interchangeable Connection” means an arrangement or device that will
allow alternate but not simultaneous use of two sources of water.
   (p)   “Non-Potable Water” means water not safe for drinking, personal or
culinary use.
   (q)   “Person” means any state, public or private corporation, individual,
partnership or other legal entity.
   (r)   “Pollution” means the presence in water of any foreign substance that
tends to degrade its quality so as to constitute a hazard or impair the
usefulness or quality of the water to a degree does not create an actual hazard
to the public health but which does adversely and unreasonably effect such
waters for domestic use.
   (s)   “Potable Water” means water which is satisfactory for drinking,
culinary, and domestic purposes and meets the requirement of the Environmental
Protection Agency.
   (t)   “Process Fluids” means any fluid or solution which may be chemically,
biologically or otherwise contaminated or polluted in a form or concentration
such as would constitute a health, pollution or system hazard if introduced
into the public or a potable consumer's water system. This includes, but is not
limited to:
      (1)    Polluted or contaminated waters;
      (2)    Process water; including swimming pools;
      (3)    Used waters originating from the public water system which may
have deteriorated in sanitary quality;
      (4)    Cooling waters;
      (5)    Contaminated natural waters taken from wells, lakes, streams or
irrigation systems;
      (6)    Chemicals in solution or suspension;
      (7)    Oils, gases, acids, alkalis and other liquid and gaseous fluids
used in industrial or other processes or for fire fighting purposes.
   (u)   “Public Water System” has the meaning ascribed to such term in rule
3745-81- 01- of the Administrative Code of Ohio.
   (v)   “Reduced Pressure Principle Backflow Prevention Device” means a device
containing a minimum of two independently acting check valves together with an
automatically operated pressure differential relief valve located between the
two normal check valves. During normal flow and at the cessation of normal
flow, the pressure between these two checks shall be less than the supply
pressure. In case of leakage of either check valve, the differential relief
valve, by discharging to the atmosphere, shall operate and maintain the
pressure between the check valves at less than the supply pressure. The unit
must include tightly closing shutoff valves located at each end of the device,
and each device shall be fitted with properly located test cocks.
   (w)   “Service Connection” means the terminal end of a service line from the
public water system. If a meter is installed at the end of the service, then
the service connection means the downstream end of the meter.
   (x)   “Supplier of Water” means the owner or operator of a public water
system.
   (y)   “System Hazard” means a condition posing an actual or potential threat
of damage to the physical properties of the public water system or potable
consumer's water system.
   (z)   “Pollution Hazard” means a condition through which an aesthetically
objectionable or degrading material not dangerous to health may enter the
public water system or a potable consumer's water system.
   (aa)   “Used Water” means any water supplied by a supplier of water from a
public water system to a consumer's water system after it has passed throughout
the service connection and is no longer under the control of the supplier.
(Ord. 04-99. Passed 2-2-99.)
931.02 CROSS-CONNECTIONS PROHIBITED.
   (a)   No Water service connection shall be installed or maintained to any
premises where actual or potential cross-connections to the public potable or
consumer's water system may exist unless such actual or potential cross
connections are abated or controlled to the satisfaction of the Superintendent
of Roads and Utilities.
   (b)   No connection shall be installed or maintained whereby an auxiliary
water supply may enter a public potable or consumer's water system unless such
auxiliary water supply and the method of connection and use of such supply
shall have been approved by the Superintendent of Roads and Utilities and by
the Director of the Environmental Protection Agency as required by Ohio R.C.
6109.13.
(Ord. 04-99. Passed 2-2-99.)
931.03 SURVEY AND INSPECTION.
   (a)   The consumer's premises shall be open at all reasonable times to the
Munroe Falls Water Superintendent for the conduction of surveys and
investigations of water use practices within the consumer's premises to
determine whether there are actual or potential cross-connections to the
consumer's water system through which contaminants or pollutants could backflow
or be back siphoned into the public potable water system.
   (b)   On request by the Munroe Falls Water Superintendent, the consumer
shall furnish information on water use practices within the consumer's
premises.
   (c)   It shall be the responsibility of the water consumer to conduct
periodic surveys of water use practices on the consumer's premises to determine
whether there are actual or potential cross-connections to the water consumer's
or adjacent water consumer's water systems through which contaminants or
pollutants could backflow into on-site water systems or the public potable
water system. The water consumer shall be responsible for immediately notifying
the Munroe Falls Water Department of actual or potential cross-connections not
being monitored by the Munroe Falls Water Department.
(Ord. 04-99. Passed 2-2-99.)
931.04 WHERE PROTECTION IS REQUIRED.
   (a)   An approved backflow prevention device shall be installed on each
service line to a consumer's water system serving premises, where in the
judgement of the Superintendent of Roads and Utilities or the Director of the
Ohio Environmental Protection Agency, or his duly authorized representative,
actual or potential hazard of the potable water system exists.
   (b)   An approved backflow prevention device shall be installed on each
service line to a consumer's water system serving premises where any of the
following conditions exist:
      (1)    Premises having an auxiliary water supply, unless such auxiliary
supply is accepted as an additional source by the Superintendent of Roads and
Utilities and the source is approved by the Ohio Environmental Protection
Agency.
      (2)    Premises on which any substance is handled in such a fashion as to
create an actual or potential hazard to the public potable water system. This
shall include premises having sources or systems containing process fluids or
waters originating from the public potable water system which are no longer
under the sanitary control of the Superintendent of Roads and Utilities.
      (3)    Premises having internal cross-connections that, in the judgement
of the Superintendent of Roads and Utilities, are not correctable, or have
intricate plumbing arrangements, which make it impractical to determine at that
time or in the future whether or not cross connections exist.
      (4)    Premises where, because of security requirements or other
prohibited restrictions, it is impossible or impractical to make a complete
cross connection survey.
      (5)    Premises having a repeated history of cross-connections being
established and re-established.
      (6)    Others specified by the Superintendent of Roads and Utilities or
the Director of the Ohio Environmental Protection Agency or his duly authorized
representative.
   (c)   An approved backflow prevention device shall be installed on each
service line to a consumer's water system serving, but not necessarily limited
to, the following types of facilities unless the Superintendent of Roads and
Utilities or the Director of Ohio Environmental Protection Agency, or his duly
authorized representative, determines that no actual or potential hazard to the
public potable water system exists:
      (1)    Hospitals, mortuaries, clinics, nursing homes.
      (2)    Laboratories.
      (3)    Piers, docks, waterfront facilities.
      (4)    Sewage treatment plants, sewage pumping stations or storm water
pumping stations.
      (5)    Food or beverage processing plants.
      (6)    Restaurants or other where food is commercially prepared.
      (7)    Chemical Plants.
      (8)    Metal plating industries.
      (9)    Petroleum processing or storage plants.
      (10)    Radioactive material processing plants or nuclear reactors.
      (11)    Car washes.
      (12)    Fire sprinkler systems
      (13)    Lawn sprinkler systems.
      (14)    Swimming Pools.
      (15)    Others specified by the Superintendent of Roads and Utilities or
the Director of Ohio Environmental Protection agency or his duly authorized
representative.
   (d)   An approved backflow prevention device shall be installed at any point
of connection between the public potable or consumer's water system and an
auxiliary water system, unless such auxiliary system is accepted as an
additional source by the Superintendent of Roads and Utilities and the source
is approved by the Ohio Environmental Protection Agency.
(Ord. 04-99. Passed 2-2-99.)
931.05 TYPE OF PROTECTION REQUIRED.
   (a)   The type of protection required under Section
921.04(a), (b) and (c) of these regulations shall depend on the degree of
hazard which exists as follows:
      (1)    An approved air gap separation shall be installed where the public
potable water system may be contaminated with substances that could cause a
severe health hazard;
      (2)    An approved air gap separation or an approved reduced pressure
principle backflow prevention device shall be installed where the public
potable water system may be contaminated with a substance that could cause a
system or health hazard.
      (3)    An approved air gap separation and/or an approved reduced pressure
principle backflow prevention device and/or approved double check valve
assembly shall be installed where the public potable water system may be
polluted with substances that could cause a pollutional hazard not dangerous to
health.
   (b)   The type of protection required under Section
921.04(d) of these regulations shall be an approved air gap separation or an
approved interchangeable connection.
   (c)   Where an auxiliary water system is used as a secondary source of water
for a fire protection system, the provisions of subsection (b) hereof for an
approved air gap separation or an approved interchangeable connection may not
